questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to ER with a history of trauma to the flanks whilst playing cricket. His pulse is 80 bpm and BP is 120/85 mmHg. A FAST scan is done, which reveals the presence of free fluid in the spleen window. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
CT scan is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically stable patient with minimal free fluid in the abdomen. It should be done to locate the source of bleeding and grading.

FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma.

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

Technique:

  • The patient is placed in a supine position
  • With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer the following regions are scanned :
    • Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presents with worsening redness of her face for the past week. She had started using makeup two weeks ago daily. On noticing the redness, she has been applying more makeup to cover it up. On examination, you notice erythema of the face with mild scaling.  Which of the following is the long-term management for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has allergic contact dermatitis due to cosmetics. The long-term management for allergic contact dermatitis is avoidance of allergens.

This patient has erythema and scaling on her face after she started using makeup. These symptoms are consistent with those of allergic contact dermatitis. The symptoms worsened when she used more makeup (allergen) to cover up her symptoms.

Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. Allergic contact dermatitis to cosmetics usually causes erythema and scaling. The severity of symptoms depends on the product used and where it was applied.

The incidence of cosmetic contact dermatitis has reduced due to strict manufacturing regulations. However, the use of fragrances to improve product appeal may still cause dermatitis. The most common causes of cosmetic allergic contact dermatitis are fragrances and preservatives. 

Long-term treatment of allergic contact dermatitis involves avoidance of the allergen. Patch testing can confirm the specific allergen involved. The International Nomenclature Cosmetic Ingredient (INCI) name of the allergen can be provided to the patient since this is the name that will be used on product labels. 

An acute flare-up can be managed with topical corticosteroids, topical calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus). For severe, extensive involvement, systemic corticosteroids can be used. 

The following image shows allergic contact dermatitis in response to poison ivy. 

Other options: 

Option A - Systemic corticosteroids are indicated when there is involvement of more than 20% of the body surface area. In addition, it is useful for acute relief of symptoms, not long-term management. 

Option C - The use of barrier creams is not helpful once the patient has been sensitized to the allergen. 

Option D - Cyclosporin can be administered if there is chronic contact dermatitis and when allergens cannot be avoided, as in airborne contact dermatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the beneficiaries of the scheme that has the logo shown below?

choices.text: It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
It provides health insurance of upto 1,00,000 Rs. per family per year.
Service is provided to families with a maximum of 5 members.
The insurance is provided in the form of cash to the families.

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the Ayushman Bharat scheme. The correct statement is Option A - It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) aims to build a comprehensive need-based health care service and targets to build a 'New India 2022'. Its components are:

  • The first component is the creation of 1,50,000 Health & Wellness Centres (HWCs) to deliver comprehensive primary health care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services.
  • The second component is the Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), which provides health insurance cover of Rs. 5 lakhs per year to over 10 crore poor and vulnerable families for seeking secondary and tertiary care.

Benefits under the scheme:

  • The government provides health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year(Option B).
  • All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per the defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members (Option C).
  • Priority is given to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empaneled private hospitals in times of need.
  • It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, the cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services (Option D).
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • A 24X7 helpline number is available for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy comes from a remote village to the district hospital with multiple cuts and abrasions on his feet. He cannot remember how he acquired these wounds and does not feel any sensation in his foot. After addressing the wound, you provide him with Micro Cellular Rubber (MCR) footwear and advise him to follow up. What is the web-based system launched by the government that can help you track this patient?
questions.solution:
Nikusth is a real-time leprosy reporting software for monitoring leprosy patients with a patient tracking mechanism launched by the Health & Family Welfare Minister, Government of India.

Sparsh leprosy awareness campaign and the Nikusth system are related to Hansen's disease/leprosy.

"Sparsh Leprosy Awareness Campaign" (SLAC) was introduced in 2017 on the occasion of Anti-Leprosy day (observed on last Sunday of January) to promote awareness. NLEP introduced this campaign in order to address the issue of the high level of stigma attached to leprosy and to increase awareness about various aspects of leprosy.

Other options:

NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring of TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB)

Axshya is the project that works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

Note: 

Nikshay Poshan Yojana

Under Nikshay Poshan Yojana, a financial incentive of Rs. 500 per month is provided for nutritional support to each notified TB patient for the duration of anti-TB treatment. For pediatric TB patients who do not have bank accounts, the money shall be deposited in parent's/guardian's accounts whose details are to be sought and entered in Nikshay against the patient’s records. The processing of payment is on the 7th of every month.

Nishchay is a pregnancy test kit introduced by the government.

questions.text:
A patient presented with multiple itchy lesions, as shown in the image below. KOH stain revealed the presence of predominant macroconidia and scanty microconidia. The hair shaft showed ectothrix, but the nails were spared. Which of the following is likely to be the cause of this condition?

KOH - Potassium hydroxide
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the involvement of the hair and skin but not the nails along with the microscopic examination findings point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection.

The given image shows annular lesions with central clearing, which is seen in dermatophytosis. Dermatophytes involve only the superficial cornified layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

  • Trichophyton: Infection involves the skin, hair, and nails. The species include Trichophyton rubrum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Trichophyton tonsurans, Trichophyton schoenleinii, and Trichophyton violaceu. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum: Infection involves skin and hair. The species include Microsporum gypseum, Microsporum canis, and Microsporum nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton: Infection involves skin and nails. Only Macroconidia. Epidermophyton floccosum is the only species in this genus.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellophane tape (cellophane tape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Endothrix refers to dermatophyte infections of the hair that invade the hair shaft and internalize into the hair cell. As the name suggests, endothrix causes infection inside the hair shaft and ectothrix causes infection outside the shaft.

  • T. tonsurans, T. violaceum, T. schoenleinii, Trichophyton yaoundei, and Trichophyton soudanense cause endothrix type of tinea capitis.
    • Remember: TV is always kept inside the house (ENDO) — so T. tonsurans and T. violaceum cause endothrix.
  • Microsporum audouinii, M.canis, Microsporum equinum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.

Sporothrix does not cause superficial mycoses.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A patient presents with a cough with rusty sputum and fever for the past few weeks. She gives a history of recent travel to Japan and the consumption of raw crabs.  A complete blood count reveals eosinophilia. All of the following are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: It is a food-borne trematode infection.
Eggs are coughed up in sputum.
Embryonated eggs are the infective form.
Praziquantel is the treatment of choice.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke). All the given options are true about this condition, except that embryonated eggs are the infective form.

Metacercariae encysted in crab or crayfish is the infective form.

P. westermani is a trematode. Transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae encyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Treatment: Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

The following image shows the life cycle of P. westermani, the oriental lung fluke.

questions.text: Which of the following options represents the Australia antigen in the given image of viral structure?
questions.solution:
The Australia antigen, which is another name for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), is marked as '1' in the given image. This antigen was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person, hence the name Australia antigen.

Under electron microscopy, the serum from hepatitis B patients shows three types of particles:

  • Spherical particle: 22 nm; most abundant; containing only HBsAg
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22 nm; containing only HBsAg
  • Double-walled spherical structure: 42 nm diameter; the complete hepatitis B virus; called the Dane particle, since it was first described by Dane

The illustration given below shows the sphericle structure of the hepatitis B virus.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is detectable in large quantities in the serum. It is present in active infection and also may be present in the chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). 

Hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is a capsid/core protein found on nucleocapsid. 

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is the envelop antigen. It is a protein on the nucleocapsid. It is a marker of active viral replication. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

The nucleocapsid contains the DNA, which appears partially double-stranded and partially single-stranded. It is associated with a viral DNA polymerase that has both DNA-dependent DNA polymerase and RNA-dependent reverse transcriptase functions.

The image given below shows the hepatitis B virus genome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida came to the clinic for a routine follow-up at 26 weeks of gestation. On examination, her abdominal girth was less for gestational age and the fetal parts were easily palpable. On further evaluation, it is found that she has a family history that is positive for the PKHD1 mutation. Which of the following is false about the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It can be diagnosed by an antenatal ultrasound in severe cases.
It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
Respiratory insufficiency is a common cause of mortality.
Systemic hypertension is a common feature.

questions.solution:
A family history of PKHD1 mutation is suggestive of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD). Since the woman has signs of oligohydramnios, it is likely that this fetus has ARPKD.

Severe cases of ARPKD can be diagnosed in-utero with an ultrasound after 24 weeks of gestation.

ARPKD is a hereditary renal disease of childhood caused by a mutation in the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6. It codes for fibrocystin/polyductin (FPC), a membrane protein present in the cells of the cortical and medullary collecting ducts.

Affected fetuses show greatly enlarged kidneys and reduced fetal urine production. This leads to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia. About 30% of neonates die soon after birth due to respiratory insufficiency. Most deaths occur in the first month of life. Some patients are born with end-stage renal disease. 

Some patients are diagnosed after the neonatal period. The complications in this age group include progressive renal failure, liver disease, and hypertension. The important features of ARPKD liver disease are congenital hepatic fibrosis and dilatation of intra-hepatic bile ducts.(Caroli disease)

Investigations include CT, MRI, and ultrasonography. Molecular diagnosis is difficult due to the large and complex structure of the PKHD1 genome. However, presymptomatic screening of family members of affected individuals is a feasible option. 

There is no specific treatment for ARPKD. Treatment involves neonatal intensive care, blood pressure control, dialysis, and kidney transplantation. Liver transplantation is considered in patients with significant liver disease.

 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text:
Which of the following indicates the therapeutic index of a drug?

ED50 - Median effective dose

LD50 - Median lethal dose
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio. The therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

Mathematically, you can calculate TI in the following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 or TD50/ED50

where LD50 is the mean lethal dose, TD50 is the mean toxic dose, and ED50 is the median effective dose 

Median lethal dose (LD50) and median toxic dose (TD50)

  • LD50 is the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die.
  • In human trials, TD50 can be considered. It is the dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.
  • Larger the LD50 or TD50, the safer the drug. 

Median effective dose (ED50)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect
  • ED50 is the quantity of a drug that can produce the desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

The therapeutic window refers to a range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman presented with features suggestive of thyrotoxicosis. Which of the following is not a treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
Radioactive iodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation. Therefore, it is not a treatment option in this patient.

Thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy:

The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil (PTU).

Methimazole and its prodrug (carbimazole) are usually avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenic risk. However, methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for PTU-associated liver failure. 

Subtotal thyroidectomy can be performed during the mid-trimester.

Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and causes the destruction of the fetal thyroid. Therefore, it is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

Treatment of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

Trimester Treatment for thyrotoxicosis
First trimester
  • Propylthiouracil
Second trimester
  • Methimazole
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy
Third trimester
  • Methimazole

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

Related Pearl: Classification of Anti-Thyroid Drugs

  • Thiocyanates
  • Perchlorates
  • Nitrates

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs inhibiting peripheral conversion:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)
  • Propranolol
  • Glucocorticoids

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

questions.text: Calculate the tidal volume if the respiratory rate is 15/min and the alveolar ventilation is 6 L/min. (Consider dead space volume to be 150 mL)
questions.solution:
Alveolar ventilation = RR X (VT –VD)

In the given case,

  • Respiratory rate (RR)= 15/min
  • Alveolar ventilation = 6 L/min
  • Dead space volume (VD) = 150 mL
  • Tidal volume (VT) =?

Thus,

6000 (in mL/min) = 15 X (VT -150)

6000/15 = VT -150

400 + 150 = VT

550 mL = VT

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with burns was brought to the casualty department. As shown in the image below, there was sparing of the front and back of the chest and face. Painful erythema was present on both palms.  Also, there was uniform involvement of both lower limbs circumferentially, genitalia, and the front and back of the abdomen. Lesions were painful and showed blanching on pressure. What fluid resuscitation plan would you choose as per the 2018 ATLS guidelines, if the patient weighed 50 kg?

choices.text: 2.75 L over 8 hours, followed by 2.75 L over 16 hours
4.5 L over 8 hours, followed by 4.5 L over 16 hours
6 L over 8 hours, followed by 6 L over 16 hours
9 L over 8 hours, followed by 9 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
The given image shows second-degree burns, as evident from the moist appearance of the skin, associated with pain and blanching on pressure. The total volume of fluid needed is 5.5 L, of which 2.75 L is given in the first 8 hours and 2.75L is given in the next 16 hours as indicated by 

Step 1: Calculating the percentage of burns using the Wallace rule of nines:

  • This includes only second- and third-degree burns.
  • Right lower limb + left lower limb and anterior-posterior lower torso + genitalia = 18 + 18 + 18 + 1 = 55%

STEP 2: Calculating fluid using the resuscitation formula for thermal burns:

According to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines, the fluid resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 2 mL/kg/TBSA% given IV.

Fluid requirement = 2 mL x body weight x TBSA

                          = 2 mL x 50 kg x 55%

                          = 5.5 L

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema.

Superficial (epidermal) burns are excluded from this calculation.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified into three degrees:

  • First-degree burns: There is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. Capillary refilling time remains normal.
  • Second-degree burns (partial-thickness burns): There is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided as follows:
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful, with blisters. Capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns: There is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: There is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text:
An alleged female convict is arrested for a crime she did not commit. She was tortured by the investigating officer and was raped by him in police custody. Under which section will the inquest be done in this scenario?

IPC - Indian Penal Code

CrPC - Criminal Procedure Code

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of custodial rape. A magistrate inquest is done under BNSS Section 196 (Section 176 CrPC).

Custodial rape is defined as the offence committed by persons who are in supervisory positions indulging in sexual intercourse with women in their custody by inducing or seducing the woman by taking advantage of his official position.

BNSS 196 (Section 176 CrPC) deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

Indications for Magistrate Inquest:

  • Custodial rape
  • Death in police custody or police interrogation
  • Death in police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, Borstal school
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital
  • Dowry death
  • Cases of exhumation.

Other options:

Option A- BNS Section 63 (Section 375 IPC)deals with the definition of rape. In BNS 63, the Age of Consent of 15 years is replaced by 18 years in BNS. Exception 2 of Section 63 states that “sexual intercourse or acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under 18 years of age, is not rape”.

Option B- BNS Section 68 (Section 376 IPC) deals with the punishment of rape by a person in authority. It is termed custodial rape.

Option D- BNSS Section 194 (Section 174 CrPC) deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offence.

Related Pearl: Sexual Offences

BNS Section Section it deals with

Punishment

 Previous IPC section
63 Definition of Rape   375

64(1)

 Punishment for Rape

Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 10 years which may extend to imprisonment for life.

 376
65(1) Persons committing the offence of rape on a woman under16 years of age Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years which may extend to imprisonment for life. 376
66 The person committing an offense of rape and inflicting injury which causes death or causes the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state. Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years may extend to imprisonment for life or with death. 376A
65(2) The person committing an offense of rape on a woman under 12 years of age Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years but which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine or with death 376AB
67 Sexual intercourse by the husband upon his wife during separation, without her consent Imprisonment for not less than 2 years but which may extend to 7 years and with a fine. 376B
68 Sexual intercourse by a person in authority (police officer, public servant, member of armed forces, management or staff of a jail, remand home or other places of custody and management or staff of a hospital) who induces or seduces any female inmate of such jail, remand home, place, or institution to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offense of rape. Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 5 years but which may extend to 10 years and with a fine. 376C
70(1) Gang Rape Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 20 years which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine 376D
70(2) Gang rape on a woman under 18 years of age Rigorous imprisonment for life and with fine 376DA
71 Repeat offenders Imprisonment for life or with death 376E
74 Assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty Imprisonment for not less than one year, extending up to five years and with fine. 354

 

As per the The Gazette of India, from the Ministry of Law and Justice, Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita Document 2023

questions.text: A woman visits the OPD claiming that she was bitten by an insect while trekking outside. She explains that the insect did not have a scutum and that its head was not visible from above. She may develop any of the following diseases due to this, except _____.
questions.solution:
The description of the insect given is that of a soft tick. The diseases transmitted by soft ticks are Q fever, relapsing fever, and Kyasanur Forest disease. 

Onchocerciasis is transmitted by black fly (Simulium); hence, it is unlikely in this patient.

Hard ticks are covered by a chitinous shield on their dorsal surface, which is called the scutum. They have a head or capitulum present at the anterior end, which is visible from above. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks:

  • Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
  • Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)
  • Viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)
  • Tularemia
  • Tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis.

The images given below show a hard tick (top) and soft tick (bottom).

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Hard tick (Ixodes species) Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease
Soft Tick (Argas species) Q fever, relapsing fever, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be casued by hard tick as well)
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox
Itch mites Scabies
Cyclops Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum)
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrance, Jiggar, Chigoe flea)  Tungiasis, Ulcer in the feetnails

questions.text: What is the finding shown in the given image, and in which race is this feature most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars. These are called Carabelli’s cusps. They are most commonly seen in people of the Caucasian race. The lateral incisors in the upper jaw are usually smaller than the central incisors. Caucasians also tend to have long, pointed canine roots. 

In bull-teeth or ‘taurodontism’, the pulp cavity of the molars is wide and deep, and the roots are fused and bent. A congenital lack of the third upper molar is most common in Mongoloids. In Mongoloid teeth, enamel pearls, small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface, are much more frequent. 

Other features of Mongoloid dentition:

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a depression centrally
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • Wide and deep pulp cavity of the molars - bull-teeth or ‘taurodontism’
  • Congenital lack of the third upper molar - a common but nonspecific feature

Negroid races tend to have large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

Aboriginal races tend to have large teeth with wide crowns. They do not show taurodontism.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is correctly matched with its layer of origin?
questions.solution:
The area marked ‘2’ depicts the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids. In ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome, excess cortisol is produced from this layer. 

Parts of the adrenal glands:

  • The adrenal cortex is arranged in a zonal configuration in three zones - 
    • Outer zona glomerulosa- secretes mineralocorticoids (aldosterone)
    • Middle zona fasciculata- secretes glucocorticoids (cortisol, corticosterone)
    • Inner zona reticularis- secretes androgens (dehydroepiandrosterone)
  • The adrenal medulla- stores and secretes catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine)

On histological examination, the different layers are identified as:

  • Outer zona glomerulosa - small, compact cells
  • Central zona fasciculata - larger lipid-rich cells arranged in radial columns
  • Inner zona reticularis - pigmented, compact cells
  • Adrenal medulla - thin layer of large chromaffin cells

Option A: Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine producing tumour derived from chromaffin cells and arises from the adrenal medulla.

Option C: In Conn’s syndrome, excess aldosterone is secreted from zona glomerulosa.

Option D: Neuroblastoma arises from the adrenal medulla.

The cells of the glomerulosa are arranged in round-to-oval clusters that resemble renal glomeruli, and hence, this layer is called "glomerulosa".

questions.text: You are a molecular biochemist working on genetic elements and the organization of human recombinant chimeric DNA (cDNA). In a sample of extracted DNA element, you determine the percentage of thymine residues to be 22%. What would be the expected percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in DNA will be 28%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species,

Purines = Pyrimidines

Sum of purine = Sum of pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

In the question it is given that thymine is 22%, therefore adenine is also 22%.

Hence adenine + thymine = 44% and Guanine + cytosine = 56%. 

No of Guanine = No of Cytosine, so the percentage of cytosine = 56/2 = 28%.

Chimeric DNA (also known as recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant.
 
The practical applications of recombinant DNA technology include:
  • Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
  • Producing proteins such as:
    • Interferons, tPA (tissue plasminogen activator)
    • Insulin, growth hormone
    • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  • Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)
  • Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  • Gene therapy and stem cell therapy

questions.text: As per Sade classification, what is the grade assigned to atelectasis of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The term atelectasis is used to define the tympanic membrane touching the promontory. This is classified as grade 3 by Sade classification.

  • Pars Tensa retraction is graded using Sade grading
  • Pars flaccida retraction is graded using Tos grading

Sade’s classification of retraction of pars tensa:

  • Grade 1 – Mild retraction not touching the long process of the incus 
  • Grade 2 – Retracted drum touching the long process of the incus
  • Grade 3 – Touching promontory but mobile on segalization—atelectasis of the middle ear
  • Grade 4 – Plastered to promontory (immobile)—adhesive middle ear

Tos’ classification of retraction of pars flaccida:

  • Grade 1 – Mild attic retraction not touching the neck of the malleus.
  • Grade 2 – Touching neck of the malleus
  • Grade 3 – Limited outer attic wall erosion
  • Grade 4 – Severe outer attic wall erosion

questions.text: A 1-week old infant born prematurely has frequent episodes of cessation of breathing lasting more than 20 seconds. There is associated bradycardia. What is the treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the clinical features is apnea of prematurity. Treatment includes administration of caffeine citrate.

Apnea of prematurity results from immature respiratory control and most frequently occurs in infants <34 weeks of gestational age. It is defined as cessation of breathing for longer than 20 seconds or for any duration if accompanied by cyanosis or bradycardia. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. It is seen in preterm infants and usually resolves by the 37th week of gestation.

A gentle tactile stimulation or provision of flow and/or supplemental oxygen by nasal cannula is often adequate therapy for mild and intermittent episodes.

Recurrent apnea of prematurity may be treated with caffeine or theophylline. Caffeine citrate is preferred due to its longer half-life and lesser side effects. A loading dose of 20 mg/kg followed by a 5 mg/kg/hr maintenance dose is used.  Apart from this, aminophylline can be given intravenously as a loading dose of 5-7 mg/kg followed by a maintenance dose of 1-2 mg/kg every 6-12 hours.

In apnea of prematurity, methylxanthines such as theophylline and caffeine increase the central respiratory drive by lowering the threshold of response to hypercapnia. They also enhance the contractility of the diaphragm and prevent diaphragmatic fatigue. 

Doxapram, which is a potent respiratory stimulant, can be used in those not responding to methylxanthines.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched voice. She is a singer and a known smoker. Her laryngoscopy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscopy findings show diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds suggestive of Reinke's edema.

It occurs due to edema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords in the glottis.

Key clinical features

  • History of smoking and/or voice abuse.
  • Hoarseness is the most common symptom.
  • Patients use false cords for voice production and this gives them a low-pitched and rough voice.

On indirect laryngoscopy, both vocal cords show diffuse symmetrical swellings. They appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

Treatment

  • Voice rest and cessation of smoking
  • Decortication of the vocal cords, i.e. removal of a strip of epithelium
  • Speech therapy for proper voice production.

Other options

Option B: Laryngeal papilloma/ squamous papilloma are benign tumors of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They occur in children (juvenile papillomatosis) as well as adults. Patients present with hoarseness, dyspnea or stridor.

Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white “grape-like” projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. 

The image below shows laryngeal papilloma. 

Option C: A Vocal polyp is caused by vocal abuse or misuses such as sudden shouting resulting in hemorrhage and submucosal edema. It presents with hoarseness and diplophonia. In case of a large polyp, dyspnea, stridor or choking may occur.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as soft, smooth, mobile, and pedunculated mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly unilateral.

Treatment is by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows a vocal polyp.

Option D: Vocal nodules (Singer's or Screamer's nodes) are also caused by vocal abuse or misuse. It most commonly affects teachers, actors, singers, vendors, and talkative school children. Patients complain of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and neck pain during prolonged talking.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as a greyish or white pin-head-sized mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly symmetrical (bilateral).

Small vocal nodules are treated conservatively with speech therapy. Large ones are treated by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows symmetrical vocal nodules.

questions.text: A histologist is studying the structure derived from the bone shown in the microscopic image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the canal marked by the square in the given image?

choices.text: Volkmann's canals communicate with each other by means of this canal.
It is found in compact bone.
It contains small blood vessels and nerves.
It is surrounded by multiple lamellae of calcified matrix.

questions.solution:
The given image shows the haversian canal, and the incorrect statement regarding the canal is option A. The haversian canals communicate with each other through the transverse perforating canals, called Volkmann's canals, and not vice-versa.

The haversian system or osteon comprises most of the compact bone. Each haversian system contains a central canal, within which the small blood vessels, nerves, and endosteum are present. This canal is surrounded by multiple layers or lamellae of the calcified matrix containing type I collagen fibers. These canals communicate with each other via Volkmann's canal.

Successive lamellae are separated from each other by lacunae that contain osteocytes. These osteocytes communicate with each other, the central canal, and the periphery of the osteon via the dendritic processes present within the canaliculi. The parallel lamellae present between osteons is called interstitial lamellae, and the parallel lamellae present near the periosteum are called the circumferential lamellae.

On microscopy, the osteon can be identified by the following characteristics:

  • Presence of the haversian canal with concentric lamellae around it
  • Volkmann's canal
  • Osteocytes with canaliculi
  • Interstitial lamellae
  • Circumferential lamellae

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with AIDS presents to the local clinic with fever, nausea, vomiting, and confusion. A diagnosis of invasive cryptococcosis was made. Which of the following is false regarding the causative agent?

choices.text: Can de demonstrated by India ink
Can be cultured in Niger seed agar

questions.solution:
Cryptococcus neoformans cannot be diagnosed with the (1→3)-β-D-glucan assay. 

(1→3)-β-D-Glucan assay is used for the diagnosis of Candida infections, invasive aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. It is not useful in the case of invasive cryptococcosis.

C. neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that is found as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. Infection is initiated by inhalation of the yeast cells. Cryptococci have been classified into 5 serotypes (A, B, C, D, and AD) based on their capsular polysaccharide:

  • Three of these serotypes, A, D, and AD, are classified as varieties of C. neoformans: C. neoformans var. grubii (serotype A), C. neoformans var. neoformans (serotype D), and a hybrid of serotypes A and D (serotype AD). Although serotype AD is very similar to serotypes A and D, the isolates still comprise a discrete group that can be distinguished.
  • Serotypes B and C are now classified as a different species: Cryptococcus gattii.

The image given below shows the life cycle of C. neoformans:

Pathogenic varieties of Cryptococcus, including C. neoformans and C. gattii, are laccase positive. They also have the ability to grow at 37°C, and these factors are used to differentiate them from non-pathogenic cryptococci.

The primary pulmonary infection may be asymptomatic or may mimic an influenza-like respiratory infection, often resolving spontaneously. Cutaneous infection results in ulcers and granulomata. In immunocompromised individuals, the yeasts may multiply and disseminate to other parts of the body, but preferentially to the CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, which presents with headache and nuchal rigidity.

Diagnosis is established by microscopic examination of cerebrospinal fluid, which shows gram-positive round budding yeast cells on gram staining. India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells (option B). The image given below shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained with India ink:

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of Cryptococcus. The image given below shows a mucicarmine-stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci:

The culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37°C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white. The cryptococcal antigen can also be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test (option C). Niger seed agar is a solid medium used for selective and differential isolation of C. neoformans from clinical specimens (option D). C. neoformans and C. gattii produce brown colonies on this medium due to the formation of melanin, which is produced because laccase uses caffeic acid as the substrate.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole can be administered along with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

questions.text: A woman underwent a routine PAP smear, which showed a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). On colposcopy, the entire squamocolumnar junction was not visible. Biopsy from the visible part suggested a cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 3 (CIN 3) lesion with suspected microinvasion. What is the preferred treatment modality in this case?
questions.solution:
Conization is the preferred treatment modality when microinvasion is suspected in a patient with CIN 3 lesion and when the entire squamocolumnar junction is not visible.

Cone biopsy involves a wide cone excision that includes the entire outer margin of the lesion and the entire endocervical lining, by using the cold-knife technique under general anesthesia. Disadvantages include bleeding, infection, cervical stenosis, and cervical incompetence.

Indications of conization

    • Endocervical dysplasia
    • Transformation zone not completely visualized
    • Discrepancy between cytology, colposcopy, and biopsy findings
    • Suspected microinvasion

Other options:

Option A: Cryotherapy is done in CIN lesions not extending into the endocervical canal and in ectocervix lesions not associated with unsatisfactory colposcopic examination or abnormal glandular cytology. It is generally not favored in CIN 3 because of the high risk of disease persistence after treatment and because it does not allow for the collection of a histologic specimen, which would help rule out occult invasive cancer.

Option B: Laser ablation is done in low-grade lesions, where the entire transformation zone is visible by colposcopy with no evidence of microinvasive, invasive, or glandular disease. The cytology and histology should correlate positively.

Option D: Hysterectomy is not preferred in CIN lesions, except in cases with recurrent or persistent lesions, where repeat excision is not feasible technically, in older and parous women who have completed families after ruling out invasive cancers.

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: The autopsy of a 14-year-old boy who died in a motor vehicle accident showed the following lesions on the inner surface of the aorta. What do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The above image shows yellow spots on the inner surface of the aorta, which represent fatty streaks. They indicate a collection of foamy macrophages in the intima of the vessel wall. 

Fatty streaks may be present in the aorta of infants, virtually all adolescents, and even individuals without known risk factors. These lesions are not indicative of atherosclerosis, but some of them may evolve into atheromatous plaques later in life by smooth muscle proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition.

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower gastrointestinal bleed. Sigmoidoscopy shows ulcers in the sigmoid colon. The histopathological image of the biopsy from the ulcer is given below.  Which of the following is the infective form of this organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of E. histolytica.

In amebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

The following are the characteristic features of the various life stages of E. histolytica.

Trophozoite:

  • It is found only in tissues.
  • Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance.
  • The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called the linin network, thus giving a cartwheel appearance.
  • Pseudopodia are present, which exhibit gliding motility.

The image given below shows the trophozoite form of E. histolytica.

Precystic stage:

  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars.
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst.

Cystic stage:

  • The mature cyst has 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.
  • Chromatid bars disappear.

The image given below shows the cyst form of E. histolytica.

Treatment involves three classes of drugs: 

  • Luminal amebicides like diloxanide furoate, paromomycin which act in the lumen
  • Tissue amebicides like emetine and chloroquine
  • Both luminal and tissue amebicides like metronidazole and tinidazole.

The following image shows the life cycle and complications of E. histolytica.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms of various protozoa

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Entamoeba histolytica Mature quadrinucleate cyst Trophozoites, quadrinucleate cyst
Giardia lamblia Quadrinucleate cyst Trophozoites, cyst
Trichomonas vaginalis Trophozoites Trophozoites
Naegleria fowleri Trophozoite Trophozoite in CSF
Acanthamoeba Trophozoites and cysts Trophozoite in CSF
Leishmania donovani Promastigote amastigotes in macrophage
Trypanosoma cruzi Metacyclic Trypomastigote Trypomastigote
Trypanosoma brucei Metacyclic Trypomastigote Trypomastigote
Balantidium coli Cysts Cysts
Plasmodium spp. Sporozoites Schizont, immature trophozoite, mature trophozoite, gametocyte
Babesia spp. Sporozoites Maltese cross form
Toxoplasma gondii All 3 morphological forms - oocyst, tachyzoite, bradyzoite Tachyzoites, tissue cysts
Cryptosporidium parvum Sporulated oocyst Sporulated oocyst
Cyclospora cayetanensis Sporulated oocyst unsporulated oocyst
Isospora belli Sporulated oocyst unsporulated oocyst
