Macrophages

Few

Several, some with ingested red blood cells

Eosinophils

Present

Absent

Charcot-Leyden crystals

Present

Absent

Motile organisms

Many motile amoeba

Scanty, nonmotile (Shigella is a non motile bacteria)

Amoeba

Motile trophozoites with ingested red blood cells

Absent

questions.text: A 25-year-old girl comes to the gynecology clinic with complaints of having a menstrual period at 20-day intervals. Her periods are of 5 days duration, regular, with no history of pain or heavy bleeding. What is this type of menstrual irregularity known as?
questions.solution:
This type of menstrual irregularity is known as polymenorrhea. It denotes frequent episodes of menstruation, occurring at intervals of 21 days or less.

Definitions of various menstrual cycle irregularities:

  • Amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstruation. 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to occasional episodes of bleeding (usually not excessive) that occur between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed cycles but having scanty episodes of bleeding.
  • Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed menstrual cycles with excessive bleeding (>80 mL in amount) and/or increased duration of flow (>7 days).
  • Metrorrhagia refers to normal cyclical bleeding with superimposed irregularly timed episodes of bleeding.
  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals.
  • Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed cycles with intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.

questions.text: A woman with a history of severe postpartum hemorrhage during her delivery 2 years ago has now been diagnosed with Sheehan syndrome. Which of the following is incorrect about this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding Sheehan syndrome is the presence of galactorrhea. Lactational failure is seen in Sheehan syndrome.

Pituitary apoplexy is hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction consequent to traumatic major blood loss. If this major blood loss occurs during delivery, it is called Sheehan syndrome.

The pituitary undergoes hyperplastic enlargement during pregnancy, which increases the risk for hemorrhage and infarction.

The most prominent symptoms are the inability to nurse (lactational failure) due to absent prolactin secretion and postpartum amenorrhea due to absent FSH and LH secretion.

Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoglycemia due to secondary adrenal insufficiency. Cortisol levels are affected leading to hypovolemia, hypoglycemia, and hyponatremia. Aldosterone is unaffected, and there is no salt wasting. Adrenal insufficiency is the most life-threatening complication. Hence, the first hormone to be replaced is glucocorticoids. 

Note: Galactorrhea and amenorrhea, with raised prolactin levels, are seen in prolactinomas.

questions.text: A patient with hematemesis due to esophageal varices was given terlipressin, which mediates its action via the vasopressin V1 receptor. This receptor is an example of G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), which works as shown below. Which subtype of GPCR is it?
questions.solution:
The answer is Option C-Gq.

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times. They also serve as receptors for various peptide hormones, neurotransmitters, amino acids, etc.

Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go.

GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and results in Ca2+ channel opening.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and results in K+ channel opening.
  • G0 causes Ca2+ channel inactivation.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C, which generates the second messenger's inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). The water-soluble IP3 diffuses to the cytosol and mobilizes Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum depots.

The image given below shows the effects of phospholipase C after activation by Gq.

Related Pearl: Membrane receptors and their mechanisms

1. G protein coupled receptor(GPCR)

   Effect 2nd messenger  Action
Gs Activates adenylate cyclase Stimulation of cAMP production Activates protein kinase A
Gi Inhibits adenylate cyclase Inhibition of cAMP production -
Gq Activates phospholipase C Liberate DAG and IP3 which mobilize Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum Activates protein kinase C


2. Guanylyl cyclase receptor

Effector 2nd messenger
Guanylyl cyclase Stimulation of cGMP production


3. Receptor tyrosine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger
Tyrosine kinase MAP kinase


4. Cytokine receptor tyrosine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger
JAK, tyrosine kinase STAT, MAP kinase


5. Serine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger
Serine kinase Smads

questions.text: Which of the following structures is spared in the unhappy triad of O'Donoghue?
questions.solution:
The posterior cruciate ligament is spared in the unhappy triad of O’Donoghue.

The unhappy triad of O’Donoghue comprises injury to

  • Anterior cruciate ligament,
  • Medial collateral ligament, and
  • Medial meniscus.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text:
During your ward rounds, a clinician demonstrates percussion over the chest wall. A dull note is elicited on an area corresponding to the sternocostal surface of the heart, which is not covered by the lungs. Which chambers of the heart mainly form the sternocostal surface?

RA-Right Atrium, LA-Left atrium, RV-Right Ventricle, LV-Left Ventricle
questions.solution:
The sternocostal surface of the heart is mainly formed by RA and RV.

Surfaces of the heart:

Sternocostal/Anterior surface: It is mainly formed by RA and RV, and partly by LV and Left auricle. The LA is not seen on this surface as it is covered by the aorta and pulmonary trunk. Most of this surface is covered by lungs, but a part of it lying beneath the cardiac notch of the left lung is not covered by the lungs; this uncovered part is called the area of superficial cardiac dullness as it elicits a dull note on percussion. 

Diaphragmatic/Inferior surface: It rests on the central tendon of the diaphragm. It's formed in its left 2/3 by LV and right 1/3 by RV. It is traversed by a posterior interventricular groove. 

Left surface/Base: It is formed mostly by LV and at the upper end, by left auricle. It is crossed by the coronary sulcus in its upper part. It is related to the left phrenic nerve, left pericardiophrenic vessels, and pericardium.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with confusion and dyspnea; he was diagnosed with pneumonia. His blood pressure is 128/76 mmHg, and his respiratory rate is 32 breaths/min. His blood urea level is 10 mmol/L. What would be the best management plan for him?

choices.text: Treat as an outpatient with supportive therapy.
Treat as an outpatient with antibiotics.
Admit to the intensive care unit.

questions.solution:
This patient with pneumonia should be admitted to ICU as his CURB-65 score is 4.

CURB-65 criteria are used to assess the severity of illness in a case of pneumonia, especially community-acquired pneumonia.

It includes 5 variables:

  1. C - Confusion 
  2. U - Urea >7mmol/L
  3. R - Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  4. B - Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg
  5. 65 - Age ≥65 years
  • Patients with scores of 0 are considered as low risk and home treatment can be considered.
  • Patients with a score of 1- 2 will require short inpatient hospitalization or closely supervised outpatient treatment
  • Patients with scores of 3-5 have severe pneumonia. It will require hospitalization and admission to the intensive care unit.

The Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI) is another index to assess the severity of illness and the risk of mortality in the case of pneumonia.
It includes 20 variables and depending on the score, patients are assigned to one of the 5 classes:

  • Class, I, II, III - at low risk of death and can be treated on an outpatient basis
  • Class IV & V - require hospitalization

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with type 2 neurofibromatosis was referred to the Department of Otorhinolaryngology for hearing rehabilitation after excision of bilateral acoustic neuromas. The surgery notes mentioned that the 8th nerve was severed during the surgery. After further evaluation, a decision to insert an implant to aid hearing was made. Where will the implant be placed?
questions.solution:
The implant of choice, in this case, would be an auditory brainstem implant (ABI), which is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle. It is designed to directly stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem.

This type of implant is required when cranial nerve VIII has been severed in surgery for vestibular schwannomas. In unilateral acoustic neuromas, ABI is not necessary as hearing is possible from the contralateral side. The receiver or stimulator has a removable magnet so that MRI can be safely performed if required.

ABIs help in communication, awareness, and recognition of environmental sounds, but are not as efficient as multichannel cochlear implants. 

Cochlear implants are electronic devices for severe to profound SNHL and those who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. The electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of the cochlea. A prerequisite for this is that cranial nerve VIII and the higher auditory pathway should be intact.

 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought with complaints of upper respiratory tract infections, fever, and sandpaper rash over her trunk and extremities. The findings of oral examination are shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Scarlet fever is the most probable diagnosis. The picture shows a strawberry tongue, which is pathognomic of the disease.

It is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, which produces pyrogenic exotoxins. The clinical features of scarlet fever are fever, rhinitis, strawberry tongue, and an erythematous sandpaper rash, which later desquamates. The tongue is coated and papillae are swollen and remain prominent after desquamation, giving rise to the strawberry appearance.

Other options:

Option A: Measles typically presents with fever, cough, rhinitis,  conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa

Option C: Kawasaki disease features include conjunctival and oral erythema, desquamative rash, cervical lymphadenopathy, and edema of hands and feet. 

Option D: Erythema infectiosum features include fever, headache, and rash over the face, which has a typical slapped cheek appearance. This condition is caused by parvovirus B19 infection.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes

Cutaneous infections/diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes

Direct infections of skin or subcutaneous tissue

  • Cellulitis
  • Impetigo
  • Ecthyma, Erysipelas
  • Vulvovaginitis
  • Perianal infection
  • Streptococcal ulcers
  • Blistering distal dactylitis
  • Necrotizing fasciitis

Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

Tissue damage from circulating toxin

  • Scarlet fever
  • Toxic‐shock‐like syndrome
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

Skin lesions due to allergic hypersensitivity to Streptococcal antigens

  • Erythema nodosum
  • Vasculitis

Skin disease provoked or influenced by Streptococcal infection (mechanism uncertain)

  • Psoriasis, especially guttate forms
  • Kawasaki disease

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, bluish discoloration was noted over the left 9th and 10th rib area. On asking the patient to take a deep breath, he winced due to pain in the left shoulder region.  Identify the most likely sign elicited here.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette refers to pain over the left shoulder tip on inspiration. This is known as Kehr's sign, which is seen in splenic trauma.

Blunt trauma to the spleen results in torsion of short gastric vessels in the gastrosplenic ligament, leading to subphrenic hematoma. The irritation at the left hemidiaphragm by subphrenic hematoma leads to a positive Kehr's sign.

Initial investigation for abdominal injury in patients who are hemodynamically unstable is focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) to explore for free fluid.

In all hemodynamically stable patients, CT is the investigation of choice for identifying and characterizing splenic injuries.

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I

Subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area)

Or

Laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II

Subcapsular hematoma (10–50% of surface area)

Or

Laceration, 1–3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Subcapsular hematoma >50% of surface area or expanding

  • ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding

Or
Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
Or
A hilar vascular injury with complete devascularization.

 

The management approach depends on the grade of injury:

Grade I and Grade II injuries: Usually, they are hemodynamically stable so they can be managed non-operatively.  It includes adequate bed rest, serial abdominal CECT's monitoring of vitals has to be done. If any shift to a high-grade injury, angioembolization can be done.

If the angioembolization fails, a spleen-sparing technique called splenorraphy can be done.

Grade IV and V injuries: Usually, they are hemodynamically unstable so splenectomy is done.

Grade III injury: If they are hemodynamically stable, they are managed as grades I and II while those are hemodynamically unstable, they are managed as grades IV and V.

Other options:

Option A- Courvoisier's sign is palpable gall bladder in the presence of jaundice due to periampullary carcinoma.

Option B- Cullen's sign is dark bluish discoloration around the umbilicus due to hemoperitoneum.

Option C- Ballance sign is a sign of splenic injury. Persistent dullness on the left side of the abdomen due to early coagulation of blood from the spleen is a positive sign. Shifting dullness can be present on the right side.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A patient was brought in with a history of consumption of acid. His last meal was a few hours ago. After resuscitation, the team performs all necessary treatments but the patient, unfortunately, succumbs to death. If you were to perform the autopsy and resect the stomach, which of the following images would indicate the most likely area of injury to the gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
The most likely area of injury to the gastric mucosa is denoted by image B.

The pathway that fluids (acid, alkali, water) take in a food-filled stomach is known as Magenstrasse. It is present along the lesser curvature of the stomach, and this is where the greatest damage to gastric mucosa takes place in corrosive injury. 

In an empty stomach, the maximum injury occurs to the lower half to two-thirds of the body, with sparing of the fundus. 

Magenstrasse refers to the pathway acidic agents follow in the stomach, a groove in the stomach along the lesser curvature that is the route food and liquids tend to take in moving toward the pylorus and that is a frequent site of peptic ulcer formation.

questions.text: An MRI of a female patient with new-onset seizures revealed a large, ring-enhancing mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema, crossing the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. Subsequently, she underwent surgical resection of the mass. Grossly, it was a grayish-white solid tumor with yellowish areas of necrosis, with interspersed areas of hemorrhages. Microscopy findings are shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with MRI findings is strongly suggestive of glioblastoma or grade IV astrocytoma.

It affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene are implicated in the pathogenesis.

They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere. 

Clinically, patients present with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits, depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages. Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

Radiologically, glioblastomas appear as a large ring-enhancing heterogeneous mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. The surrounding edema may be interspersed with infiltrating tumor cells. The tumor may show partial or complete enhancement on contrast study. 

Standard treatment includes surgery followed by a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy with temozolomide following surgical resection. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody, may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma. 

Option B: Craniopharyngioma - These are slow-growing, hypothalamic suprasellar tumors arising from vestigial remnants of the Rathke pouch. They often encroach on the optic chiasm or cranial nerves, and not infrequently they bulge into the floor of the third ventricle and base of the brain.

Two distinct histologic variants are recognized are adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma (most common in children) and papillary craniopharyngioma (most common in adults).

Option C: Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid and are usually attached to the dura. They are found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus. The most common histological pattern seen is meningothelial pattern, where clusters of epithelioid cells with indiscernible cell membranes are present.

The image below shows meningothelial or syncytial pattern:

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal care clinic at 30 weeks of gestation. You are asked to perform a detailed physical examination on her and document the findings in the case sheet. Which of the following cardiovascular findings would be specific to a pathological cardiac condition, if documented?
questions.solution:
Grade 4 early diastolic murmur documented is specific to a pathologic cardiac condition in a pregnant female. Any diastolic murmur is never a part of the physiological change in pregnancy. 

Physiological changes in pregnancy

Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)

Clinical examination

  • Pulse rate: Increases
  • Pedal edema: although it can be a sign of cardiac disease, it is also a normal physiological change in pregnancy. (Option A)
  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • Diastolic BP: Decreases
  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • The heart is displaced upwards and to the left
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • S1 M increased and widely split
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • Occasional but prominent S3 at mitral area (Option D)
  • Murmurs
    • Ejection systolic murmur at the left sternal border. (Option B)
    • Continuous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle)

ECG changes

  • Left axis deviation (due to elevation of the diaphragm)
  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement.
  • Mild ST changes in the inferior leads.
  • Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is a left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension 
  • Increased left ventricular mass

X-ray:

X-ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex).

Clinical indicators of heart disease during the pregnancy

Symptoms:

  • Progressive dyspnea or orthopnea
  • Nocturnal cough
  • Hemoptysis
  • Syncope
  • Chest pain 

Clinical signs:

  • Cyanosis
  • Clubbing of fingers
  • Persistent neck vein distention
  • Systolic murmur grade 3/6 or greater
  • Diastolic murmur
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Persistent tachycardia and/or arrhythmia
  • Persistently split S2
  • Fourth heart sound (S4)
  • Features of pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a bluish bulge is noted on parting the labia. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of cryptomenorrhea due to an imperforate hymen, which is managed by a cruciate incision of the hymen.

Cryptomenorrhea is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract. The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

Clinically, the patient presents with primary amenorrhea, a history of cyclic abdominal colicky pain, retention of urine, and the presence of a palpable abdominal lump.

Most common causes of cryptomenorrhea:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis. A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood and restores the reproductive capacity in most cases.

Other options

Option A: Hysterectomy is a very rare treatment modality used in cases with atresia of the upper vagina and cervix that undergoes restenosis after vaginoplasty.

Options B and D: Extensive septal dissection and vaginoplasty are required for the transverse vaginal septum or vaginal atresia.

questions.text:
You are calculating RBC indices during a hematology practical in a pathology laboratory. Which are the parameters you will need to calculate mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)?

Abbreviations: 

MCV - Mean corpuscular volume

MCH - Mean corpuscular hemoglobin

PCV - Packed cell volume
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option A: Hemoglobin, PCV.

Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is given by the formula hemoglobin/PCV (g/dL). It indicates the amount of hemoglobin per unit volume.

Note:

  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is given by the formula PCV/RBC (fL). It denotes the size of the RBCs.
  • Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) is given by the formula hemoglobin/RBC (pg). It quantifies the hemoglobin in the RBCs.
  • Red cell distribution width (RDW) is a quantitative measure of this variation in cell size that is calculated from MCV.

questions.text: A 48-year-old tall statured, thin-built man presents to the emergency department with features of acute abdominal pain and non-passage of stools for the past 2 days.  His abdominal X-ray is shown below. He was recently diagnosed with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing dilated colon is suggestive of toxic megacolon. Toxic megacolon is commonly associated with Gorlin syndrome (multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B [MEN 2B]).

MEN2B is also referred to as MEN3 and is characterized by the following:

    • Medullary thyroid cancer
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Mucosal neuromas
    • Marfanoid habitus
    • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
    • Megacolon

Option B - Sipple syndrome aka MEN2A syndrome. Associated conditions are as follows:

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (90%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
  • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

Option C - Wermer syndrome aka MEN1 syndrome. Associated conditions are as follows:

  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pancreatic endocrine tumor.

Option D -  Werner syndrome is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the WRN gene. DNA helicase is involved in DNA replication and repair. A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of damaged chromosomes that may mimic the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging; affected persons show various manifestations of premature aging including the following:  

  • Atherosclerosis
  • Senile cataract
  • Skin atrophy
  • Alopecia
  • Osteoporosis

Note: Megacolon is a feature seen in both MEN2A and MEN2B, the former being associated with Hirschsprung disease while the latter is associated with Toxic megacolon. Additionally, the Marfanoid habitus specified in the question is more in favor of MEN2B. Hence, option A Gorlin syndrome is the answer in this case.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A 21-year-old college student is brought to the doctor by his family because they found him working in a "drag-queen" bar, dressed as a woman. He says that he feels beautiful when he dresses as a woman and wears make-up. He likes the idea of feeling like a woman but has no wish to undergo any sex change surgery. He does not wish to live with his family as they are not supportive of his choices. This is punishable under which IPC section?
questions.solution:
The condition described in the given scenario is dual-role transvestism, in which the person temporarily likes to identify with the opposite gender by dressing like them. This is not punishable by law.

It is not associated with any genital or hormonal abnormality. This condition is not a sexual paraphilia as it is not accompanied by sexual excitement derived from cross-dressing. They do not want to undergo sex change surgery as they are otherwise comfortable with leading a life as their assigned gender.

Terms related to gender incongruence:

  • Transsexualism is a condition where the person wants to live life as a member of the opposite sex. They often prefer to undergo sex change surgery.
  • Dual-role transvestism
  • Gender incongruence of childhood- persistent excessive preoccupation with the dressing and activities of the opposite sex and desire to be one among the members of the opposite sex. This is accompanied by distress with one's assigned gender.

Note: The terms "transsexualism" and "gender identity disorder of children," which were present in ICD-10, are now considered outdated, and the ICD-11 has renamed them as "gender incongruence of adolescence and adulthood" and "gender incongruence of childhood," respectively. This change reflects the current understanding that trans-related and gender-diverse identities are not mental illnesses and that labeling them as such can result in significant stigma.

Disorders of sexual preference:

  • Fetishism - Using nonliving objects, usually those belonging to the opposite sex, as stimuli for sexual gratification
  • Fetishistic transvestism - Dressing as the opposite sex to derive sexual pleasure
  • Voyeurism - Recurrent urge to observe a person while undressing or engaging in sexual activity
  • Pedophilia - Sexual preference for pre-pubertal or early pubertal children
  • Sadomasochism - Preference for inflicting pain on a sexual partner or being subjected to pain by the sexual partner.

Other options:

Option A: Section 294 IPC is related to exhibitionism. It involves behaviors over a period of 6 months or more involving the exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. This is a punishable offense with imprisonment of up to 3 months or a fine.

Option C: Section 377 IPC: Definition and punishment of unnatural sexual offenses with imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine. In a landmark judgment, the Supreme Court of India scrapped the provisions of Section 377, except the provisions of bestiality, which is cruelty against animals.

Option D: Section 290 IPC is related to frotteurism, which describes behavior in which a person obtains sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, thighs, etc. in crowds). This is a punishable offense, with a fine of up to 200 Rs.

questions.text: A tire mark on the body of a road traffic accident victim is an example of _____.
questions.solution:
Tire marks on the body are suggestive of tertiary impact injury.

Injuries to pedestrians:

  • Primary impact injuries are caused by the first impact of the vehicle on the victim, e.g. injuries produced are patterned
    injuries, and are due to the bumper, radiator grill, headlights, etc.
  • Secondary impact injuries are further injuries caused by the vehicle, e.g. particles of the broken windshield, parts of
    the bonnet, etc. can produce contusions, lacerations, etc
  • Tertiary impact injuries (synonyms: secondary injuries) are caused when the victim strikes other objects or falls on the ground after being hit by the vehicle. Head injuries are the most common injuries of this group; other examples include crush injuries and tire marks seen on the body.

questions.text: Which of the following structures form the secretomotor pathway for the gland marked as 'X'?

choices.text: Superior salivary nucleus and 7th cranial nerve
Inferior salivary nucleus and 9th cranial nerve
Superior salivary nucleus and 9th cranial nerve
Inferior salivary nucleus and 7th cranial nerve

questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the submandibular gland, and the secretomotor pathway for the gland is from the superior salivary nucleus and 7th cranial nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with the clinical features of hematuria and proteinuria of 500 mg/dL. Urine microscopy shows a cast, as shown in the image given below. What is your inference from this slide?

choices.text: It is specific to advanced chronic kidney disease.
This structure is composed of albumin mainly.

questions.solution:
The urine microscopy shows orange-red to brown colored casts, which are suggestive of RBC casts. This finding is specific to glomerulonephritis and vasculitis. 

This is a case of glomerular hematuria because the presence of even a single RBC cast suggests a glomerular origin of hematuria.

RBC casts form as RBCs entering the tubule fluid become trapped in the cylindrical mold of Tamm-Horsfall protein. For the diagnosis of glomerular diseases from urine, the 40/5/1 rule is followed:

  • 40% dysmorphic RBCs
  • 5% acanthocytes (a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs)
  • Even a single (1) RBC cast

In advanced chronic kidney disease, broad casts are seen. Hematuria can be either due to systemic or renal causes. Renal causes can be further subdivided into glomerular and non-glomerular causes as given below:

Glomerular Non-glomerular

Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abnormal shape and size)

Isomorphic RBCs seen (normal shape and size)

RBC casts may be present

RBC casts always absent

MCV  is low (<72 fl)

MCV is normal

Protein leakage is more (>1 g/day)

Protein leakage is less (<1 g/day)

The cause is usually medical.

The cause is usually surgical.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act at which of the sites marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act on the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), which is labeled as site 1.

Carbonic anhydrase is predominantly present in the epithelial cells of the PCT. By inhibiting carbonic anhydrase, HCO3- reabsorption is blocked and diuresis occurs. Examples of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are acetazolamide, methazolamide, dichlorphenamide, and dorzolamide.

They are used in the treatment of glaucoma, urinary alkalinization in cystinuria, management of metabolic alkalosis, and acute mountain sickness. 

These drugs may lower the urinary excretion of NH4+, which can contribute to the development of hyperammonemia and hepatic encephalopathy in patients with cirrhosis.

Other options:

Option A: Site 2 is the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). Thiazides act on the DCT. They are used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic edema.

Option C: Site 3 is the descending limb of the loop of Henle. There is no diuretic with any major action here. Loop diuretics act on the thick ascending limb of Henle’s loop (TAL).

Option D: Site 4 is the collecting duct. Potassium-sparing diuretics act on the cortical collecting tubules, and vasopressin receptor antagonists act on the medullary collecting duct.

questions.text: A patient complains of hair loss over the back of her head. On examination, a 2 cm area of complete, smooth, circular hair loss with distinct margins and exclamation mark hairs is seen without scaling or inflammation. On further examination, the nail finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following is false about the condition responsible for this finding?

choices.text: Non- pigmemted hair is primarily affected
Condition can be associated with thyroiditis

questions.solution:
The image shows fine stippled pitting of nails, and the non-scarring type of hair loss associated with it is alopecia areata. The false statement about it is that non-pigmented hair is primarily affected.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis). The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen, which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares non-pigmented or white hair.

A perifollicular and intrafollicular inflammatory cell infiltrate that is focused in and around the hair bulb can be seen in anagen follicles near the edges of growing regions of alopecia areata. The predominant component of the inflammatory infiltration is activated T lymphocytes, with predominant CD4 cells, macrophages, Langerhans cells, and cells that exhibit NK cell markers.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients with hair loss that is patchy and is of shorter duration. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. 

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

The image below shows a clinical picture of alopecia areata with a patch of alopecia with a smooth surface of the scalp-

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his wife. The patient accuses his wife of cheating on him despite the wife denying it. The patient constantly keeps checking his wife's phone and has hacked into her social media account on multiple occasions previously. The wife says that the patient has become very jealous and insecure. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is suffering from Othello syndrome. It is a rare psychiatric condition where a person has morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy and suspects a faithful partner of infidelity.

Delusional Misidentification Syndromes:

Capgras syndrome: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Fregoli syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: This is a very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppelganger syndrome: This is a delusion of subjective doubles, where the person feels that he/she has his/her own impostor (doppelganger). 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A young girl presents to you with delayed puberty. On examination, you notice a characteristic finding, as shown in the picture below. Apart from this, she has a shield-shaped chest. Investigations revealed the presence of normal gonads and pulmonary valvular stenosis. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis based on features of short, webbed neck; shield chest; normal gonads; and pulmonary valvular stenosis is Noonan syndrome.

Noonan syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It involves mutations of the components of the RAS mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway (RAS-MAPK) pathway. The most common of these mutations is that of PTPN11, which encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase on chromosome 12. Although it shares many clinical features with Turner syndrome, Noonan syndrome affects both sexes with normal karyotype.

Clinical features:

  • Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant)
  • Pectus carinatum
  • Hypertelorism
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Low levels of clotting factors 11 and 12
  • Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia)
  • Moderate mental retardation in 25%
  • Cardiac abnormality: Most common is pulmonary valve stenosis.
    • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
    • Atrial septal defect
    • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus (similarities with Turner syndrome)
  • Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty.

 

Difference between Noonan syndrome and Turner syndrome:

Noonan syndrome

Turner syndrome

Normal karyotype (46XX/46XY)

45, X0 (60%)

Most common heart disease: Valvular pulmonary stenosis

Most common heart disease: Bicuspid aortic valve

25% have mental retardation

Mental retardation rare

Genitourinary:

Female: Fertile, delayed puberty

Male: Infertile due to cryptorchidism

Genitourinary:

Female: Infertile, streak ovaries

No males

Related Pearl: Gene Defects Associated with Congenital Heart Disease

Syndrome

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Pulmonary artery stenosis or tetralogy of Fallot

CHARGE syndrome

Atrial septal defect (ASD), ventricular septal defect (VSD), PDA, or hypoplastic right side of the heart

Noonan syndrome

Pulmonary valve stenosis, VSD, or Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Related Pearl: Abnormalities Associated with Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML) and Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS) in Children

Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) is associated with all of the above.

JMML:

  • Formerly called juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia
  • Resembles Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) more than chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
  • 70% of the patients are children less than 3 years old, with patients ranging from 1-month-old infants to teenagers
  • In 10% of the cases, neurofibromatosis 1 and deletion of the NF1 gene is observed.
  • The hallmark of JMML is hypersensitivity of marrow progenitors to granulocyte-monocyte colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF) in vitro. 
  • The varied clinical presentation may include failure to thrive, malaise, fever, bleeding, pallor, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly; less frequently skin, lung and GI involvement; and rarely CNS involvement.
  • Peripheral blood: leukocytosis with neutrophilia, monocytosis, nucleated red blood cells
  • Bone marrow: Hypercellular with granulocytic hyperplasia; monocytes, 5–30%; megakaryocytes, decreased; blasts + promonocytes, <20%; dysplasia, not prominent; reticulin fibrosis, rare.

questions.text: A 30-year-old salesman is brought to the ER with the following findings after he fell whilst trying to get up from the bed. There is a history of ATT intake 2 years back and low mood and lethargy for the past 2 months. Vitals were as follows: PR: 100 bpm; BP: 110/70 mmHg in the supine position and 90/60 mmHg on standing. RBS is 120 mg/dL. ABG results: Na - 120 mEq/L, K - 6 mEq/L. How would you manage this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of acute adrenal crisis in Addison's disease. It is treated with an IV infusion of saline and hydrocortisone bolus, followed by a maintenance dose of hydrocortisone.

The features favoring the diagnosis are low mood and lethargy, hyperpigmentation on gums, dorsum of hands and other exposed areas, postural hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.

Most common causes of Addison’s disease:

  • Tuberculosis in developing countries 
  • Autoimmune (idiopathic atrophy) in developed countries

An acute adrenal crisis occurs after a prolonged period of nonspecific complaints and is more frequently observed in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency. The clinical features occur due to the loss of both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid secretion. It may be precipitated by any illness, stress, infection, or hyperthyroidism contributing to increased utilization of glucocorticoids.

It can be confirmed by the ACTH stimulation test.

It is treated with an IV infusion of saline and hydrocortisone bolus. Followed by a maintenance dose of hydrocortisone. Mineralocorticoid replacement and adrenal androgen replacement are required in definite management.

Other options:


Option B:  IV propylthiouracil and propranolol are used in the management of thyrotoxicosis/ thyroid storm. The scenario will not have low BP or postural hypotension as in this case. It will have symptoms of increased metabolism, increased appetite, increased pulse, and high BP.

Option C: IV antibiotics and chlorpromazine are used in the treatment of acute labyrinthitis in which the patients might present with a history of falls and will complain of vertigo. It will not have features of hyponatremia or hypotension.

Option D: IV steroids and anti-tubercular drugs are used in the treatment of particular forms of tuberculosis such as extrapulmonary, and pediatric TB. It is often used in cases with features of meningitis, hydrocephalus, or pericarditis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: A 34-year-old man was brought to the emergency department with violent shaking of arms and legs for the past 15 minutes. He was administered IV lorazepam and phenytoin in intervals, followed by an additional dose of lorazepam. Even beyond 30 minutes, the seizures did not stop. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of violent shaking of arms and legs for 15 minutes is suggestive of status epilepticus. Intravenous midazolam infusion is the next step of management in this patient as he is refractory to treatment with two doses of lorazepam and an anti-seizure drug (phenytoin). 

Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness in the inter-ictal period. For practical purposes, status epilepticus is defined as any one of the following:

  • Continuing seizures >5 minutes or
  • No regaining of consciousness between 2 seizures.

The initial choice of therapy is a benzodiazepine, which includes either of the following:

  • Intravenous lorazepam
  • Intravenous diazepam 
  • Intramuscular midazolam- If IV access is not available

If the seizure still continues, we can repeat the above dose once again. If there is no response even after repeat doses, then a single dose of either of the antiepileptics can be given,

  • Intravenous fosphenytoin 
  • Intravenous valproic acid 
  • Intravenous levetiracetam 

If the seizure activity continues for 30 minutes even after administration of two doses of a benzodiazepine and an antiseizure drug, it is known as refractory status epilepticus. This patient requires endotracheal intubation for ventilatory support. General anesthesia is induced using continuous infusion of midazolam, propofol, or phenobarbital.

Management of status epilepticus:

questions.text: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an allosteric regulator. Which of the following is true about fructose-2,6-bisphosphate?

choices.text: Formed by phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by phosphofructokinase-1
Fall in fructose-2,6-bisphosphate levels favors gluconeogenesis

questions.solution:
Option C is the correct statement. A fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels favors gluconeogenesis.

This is a bifunctional enzyme and has the activity of both phosphofructokinase-II (PFK II) and fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase. 

  • PFK-II converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-2,6-bisphosphate. 
  • Fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase converts fructose-2,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate. 

Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate allosterically activates PFK-I, which is involved in converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate in glycolysis. In the well-fed state, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate acts as an intracellular signal that indicates that glucose is abundant, thereby causing an increase in the rate of glycolysis. 

In contrast, during fasting, there is the phosphorylation of this tandem enzyme by glucagon. This phosphorylation causes the inactivation of the PFK-II part and activation of the fructose-2,6-bis-phosphatase component. This results in a fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels, which favors gluconeogenesis.  

Other options:

Option A: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is formed by the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by phosphofructokinase-2.

Option B: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is the most potent positive allosteric activator of phosphofructokinase-1.

Option D: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an inhibitor of fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with amenorrhea for the past 4 months. On performing USG, you notice the presence of twin gestation, with a characteristic appearance as shown in the image below. When will the division of the inner cell mass occur in this type of twin gestation?
questions.solution:
The given USG image depicts the T sign, which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation, for which division of the inner cell mass occurs at 4–8 days. 

Time of division Type of twin gestation
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4–8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

 

"T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or at the beginning of the second trimester. In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is an absence of a dividing membrane.

In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
A patient who is a painter by profession presents with abdominal colic and constipation. On examination, pallor and blue stippled lines on the gums are observed. Which of the following is/are likely route(s) of exposure of the poisoning suspected?
  1. Inhalation
  2. Ingestion
  3. Absorption through skin
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with constipation, pallor, and Burton's lines (blue stippled lines on gums), most likely has lead poisoning. The correct answer is option B-1, 2, 3.

Lead poisoning occurs by lead exposure via the following modes:

  • Inhalation- Seen mostly in cases of industrial lead poisoning, due to inhalation of fumes and dust of lead and its compounds
  • Ingestion- Ingesting food with lead paint–contaminated hands or drinking water from lead pipes
  • Absorption through the skin– seen only with organic lead compounds like tetraethyl lead

The most toxic forms of lead are lead oxide, lead carbonate, and lead arsenate. The least toxic form is lead sulfide.

An increase in blood levels of lead up to 70 mcg/100 mL leads to clinical symptoms. Clinical features of inorganic lead toxicity include abdominal colic, constipation, loss of appetite, blue-line on the gums, stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist drop, and foot drop. Clinical features of organic lead poisoning include insomnia, headache, confusion, and delirium.

Diagnosis involves screening tests such as measurement of:

  • Coproporphyrin levels in urine. It is less than 150 mcg/L in non-exposed individuals.
  • Aminolevulinic acid levels in urine: A reading greater than 5 mg/L indicates lead absorption
  • Blood and urine levels of lead: A reading greater than 70 mcg/ 100 mL in blood indicates lead exposure. A reading greater than 0.8 mg/L in urine indicates lead exposure. 

Basophilic stippling can be demonstrated in erythrocytes.

Prevention of lead poisoning includes incorporating personal protective measures, regular screening of workers, good housekeeping practices, and health education.

Lead poisoning is a notifiable and compensatable disease in India.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: An infant presents with tachypnea and feeding problems. The urine has a peculiar tomcat urine odor. This condition is caused by defective utilization of____.
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odor is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiencies. Multiple carboxylase deficiencies occur due to defects in the utilization of biotin.

In the neonatal form of the disease, clinically, the affected infants seem normal at birth, but develop breathing difficulties shortly after birth, with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. If untreated, generalized erythematous rash, exfoliation, alopecia, failure to thrive, seizures, and even coma may occur. 

This problem may be an autosomal recessive form due to holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency or may be acquired due to dietary biotin deficiency because of short bowel syndrome, chronic diarrhea, or use of anticonvulsant drugs like phenytoin and carbamazepine. Raw egg ingestion may also lead to this because of avidin in the egg white binding to biotin and decreasing its absorption.

Affected infants should be treated with biotin.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy who presented with the following finding was diagnosed with Burkitt's lymphoma. Which of the following translocations is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The translocation seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14) causing translocation of the MYC gene. It is the most common translocation and is seen in 70% of the cases.

Other translocations that may be present include t(2;8) and t(8;22).

Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children < 15 years.

 Parameter  Features
Genetic factors

Translocations - t(8;14), t(2;8), t(8,22)
Clinical types

Endemic - affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla and is EBV-associated

Sporadic - in adults in western countries

Expression of CD21 (the EBV/C3d receptor) depends on EBV status of the tumors:

  • Non-endemic type (EBV-) - lack CD21
 Treatment

Started immediately after diagnosis

Intensive chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide
 Prognosis  Good - 70-80% cure rate

A variant of this condition with bone marrow involvement is called Burkitt's leukemia (ALL-L3). It is associated with c-myc dysregulation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic pancreatitis was referred to a surgeon who plans to perform the following procedure on him. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows a distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy indicative of the Duval procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis. It was developed on the basis of a presumption that a single stricture of the duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition. It consists of distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy. But it almost invariably failed due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring.

Chronic pancreatitis is associated with multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. This leads to the alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct leading to the chain of lakes appearance.

The etiology of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency can be classified based on the TIGAR-O classification system:

  • Toxic-metabolic -alcohol, smoking, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia
  • Idiopathic
  • Genetic- PRSS1, CFTR, and SPINK1 genes
  • Autoimmune- autoimmune chronic pancreatitis, IgG4-related disease
  • Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis
  • Obstructive- pancreas divisum, duct obstruction, malignancy

The diagnosis can be made using Rosemont criteria. It is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings. It is explained in the pearl attached below. 

Treatment:

Resection or hybrid surgical procedures as attached in the pearl below. 

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

Note:

Surgical treatments for chronic pancreatitis

Resection

  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch–Whipple procedure)
  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

Decompression/Drainage

  • Duval procedure
  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)
  • Izbicki procedure

Hybrid (resection+decompression)

  • Frey procedure
  • Hamburg modification
  • Berne modification

Related Pearl: Rosemont’s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis

  Parenchymal features Ductal features
Major criteria Major A criteria:
  • Hyperechoic foci with post-acoustic shadowing
Major B criteria:
  • Honeycombing lobularity
 Major A criteria:
  • Main pancreatic duct calculi
Minor criteria
  • Hyperechoic, non-shadowing foci ≥3 mm in length and width
  • Lobularity including three or more noncontiguous lobules in the body or tail
  • Pancreatic cysts ≥2 mm in short axis
  • At least three strands*

   *Strands are defined as hyperechoic lines ≥3 mm in length seen in at least two different directions in the body or tail of the pancreas.
  • Irregular main pancreatic duct (MPD) contour
  • Dilated side branches+
  • Main pancreatic duct dilation (≥3.5 mm in the body or ≥1.5 mm in the tail)
  • Hyperechoic MPD margin >50% of the main pancreatic duct in the body and tail.

 +≥3 tubular anechoic structures, each one ≥1 mm in width, budding from MPD
  Diagnosis of Chronic Pancreatitis:
  • Consistent with chronic pancreatitis
    • 1 major A criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • 1 major A criterion + major B criterion
    • 2 major A criteria
  • Suggestive of chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 1 major A criterion + <3 minor criteria
    • 1 major B criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • ≥5 minor criteria
  • Indeterminate for chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 3-4 minor criteria in the absence of major criteria
    • Major B criterion + <3 minor criteria
  •  Normal
    • <3 minor criteria

questions.text: A man presented with severe pain over his foot after an RTA. Examination revealed tenderness and swelling over the dorsum of his mid-foot. The fracture line is as shown in the picture. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing a fracture of the neck of the talus point to a diagnosis of aviator's fracture.

These fractures most commonly occur following a high-energy injury causing forced dorsiflexion with axial load. They typically occur in aircraft injuries, where the rudder bar is driven forcibly against the foot causing dorsiflexion, and the neck being very weak gives away, leading to fracture.

They can be further classified using Hawkins classification:

  • Type I - Undisplaced
  • Type II - Subtalar dislocation
  • Type III - Subtalar and tibiotalar dislocation
  • Type IV - Subtalar, tibiotalar, and talonavicular dislocation

Undisplaced fractures are managed conservatively in a short leg cast for 8–12 weeks and a non-weight-bearing cast for 6 weeks. Fractures of Hawkins types II-IV are managed by open reduction with internal fixation (ORIF).

Complications include avascular necrosis of the body of talus due to aberrant blood supply and, ultimately, osteoarthritis.

The below image shows the Hawkins classification of talar neck fractures.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Fracture Location
Hoffa fracture Coronal fracture of femoral condyles
Bumper fracture Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture Avulsion fracture of the tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture Fracture of the distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture Fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints 
Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation Fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation
March fracture Fracture of the neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal
Jone's fracture

Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal
Dancer’s fracture Fracture of distal shaft of the fifth metatarsal

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of painful and swollen right breast for the past 2 weeks. On examination, a few matted axillary nodes and warmth of the right breast are noted. What is the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy + modified radical mastectomy + radiotherapy

questions.solution:
The clinical photo shows erythema, edema, and dimpling (peau d'orange appearance) on the right breast, which together with the history and examination findings suggest a diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma. It is treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy.

Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage T4d) is the most aggressive subtype and is associated with the worst prognosis. It accounts for <3% of breast cancers. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from edema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

Diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer: 

  • Rapid onset of breast erythema, edema and/or peau d’orange, and/or warm breast (with or without an underlying palpable mass)

  • Duration of history of no more than six months

  • Erythema covering at least one-third of the breast

  • Pathologic confirmation of invasive carcinoma

A cut-off of 6 months for the duration of history differentiates between inflammatory breast carcinoma (≤6 months) and locally advanced breast cancer with secondary erythema (>6 months).

The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics in skin biopsy specimens, but it is not a prerequisite for diagnosis.

Mammography may show normal findings or skin thickening. A PET-CT scan should be considered at the time of diagnosis to rule out concurrent metastatic disease.

Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Combined-modality treatment is used, which includes the following:

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Modified radical mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy (for ER-positive tumors)
  • Trastuzumab (for HER-2-positive tumors)

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Tumor (T)

Description
Tx

Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1mic ≤ 0.1 cm

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – Inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
