Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of cylindrical lenses can be used to treat with-the-rule astigmatism?
questions.solution:
- 3.00 DC x 180, + 1.00 DC x 90 can be used to correct with-the-rule astigmatism.

In with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is steeper than the horizontal meridian. Hence, to make up for this, we need a combination of cylindrical lenses with relatively greater power in the horizontal meridian than in the vertical meridian.

Before considering the options, also remember that a cylinder aligned along the horizontal meridian (180 axis) has action in the vertical meridian and vice versa.

In option A, the cylinder acting along the horizontal meridian (- 3.00 DC x 90) has lesser power than the one acting along the vertical meridian (+ 5.00 DC x 180). This is also the case with options B and C.  

Only option D has a cylinder with greater power along the horizontal meridian ( +1.00 DC x 90) compared to the vertical meridian (- 3.00 DC x 180). Hence, option D is the answer.

 

Alternative method:

This method involves the use of the optical cross technique

STEP 1:

  • Frame the optical cross with the given powers in their respective meridians.
  • While framing the optical cross, the power which is given in 180 needs to marked in 90 and vice versa.

For example, option A has + 5.00 DC x 180, - 3.00 DC x 90, which means the eye gets a correction of + 5.00 in vertical meridian (i.e in 90 degree) and correction of - 3.00 in horizontal meridian (i.e in 180 degree). Keeping this in mind, if one frames the optical crosses for the given options, the end image would be as given below  

 

 

STEP 2:

Now, we need to interpret the optical crosses to find which meridian is steeper with certain hints.

If the power in one axis is ‘+’ and the power in the other axis is ‘-’, then the axis with ‘-’ power is steeper.

If powers in both the axes are ‘-’, then the higher number of the two will be steeper.

If powers in both the axes are ‘+’, then the lower number of the two will be steeper.

 

STEP 3:

Applying these hints to the options will give option D as with-the-rule astigmatism.

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining a 38-year-old female patient with a retroverted uterus. What is the lowest part of the cervix palpated by the examining finger in this case?
questions.solution:
In a retroverted uterus, the external os of the cervix is directed downward and forward; therefore, the lowest part of the cervix is either the external os or the posterior lip.

In anteversion, the external os is directed downward and backwards; therefore, on vaginal examination, the lowest part of the cervix felt by the fingers is the anterior lip.

Anteflexion of the uterus is at the level of Internal os. 

Angle of Anteversion Angle of Anteflexion
The angle between the cervix and vagina The angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o
(Remember: V for version, V for vagina)

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with an enlarged thyroid gland. She is asymptomatic otherwise. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Assessing the biochemical function of the thyroid, i.e. thyroid function test (TFT), is the first investigation done on any thyroid condition.

Assessment of TSH, T3, and T4 levels is done. However, TSH level is most helpful in determining the management plan, especially in patients with thyroid nodules who clinically appear to be euthyroid.

Modalities for evaluation of thyroid swelling:

    • Laboratory evaluation
      • TSH
      • T3
      • T4 
    • Thyroid imaging

Ultrasonography is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of the nodule into benign or malignant tissue.

Benign nodules are easily compressible and deform when pressure is applied with the probe while performing USG. Malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm. 

Ultrasound findings of a nodule that are considered suspicious of malignancy:

  1. Microcalcifications
  2. Hypervascularity
  3. Infiltrative margins
  4. Hypoechoic compared with surrounding parenchyma
  • Radioisotope scanning
  • CT/MRI
  • Biopsy techniques
  • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB)
  • Tru-cut/core-needle biopsy

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not classified as a seronegative spondyloarthropathy?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis is not classified as a seronegative type of arthritis because it is associated with the presence of autoantibodies (e.g. rheumatoid factor) in the blood.

Seronegative spondyloarthorpathies share some common properties:

  • There is an absence of autoantibodies (hence, the term seronegative).
  • They affect the spine.
  • They usually affect young individuals (age less than 40 years).
  • It is associated with HLA B-27.

They include:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Reiter’s syndrome: Triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Enteropathic arthritis: They are associated with inflammatory bowel disease

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient visits the OPD with progressive deformity in the left lower limb. The x-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the x-ray showing Shepherd's crook deformity are both suggestive of fibrous dysplasia of the proximal femur. 

Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterized by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. It is commonly monostotic (involves a single bone), but in 20% of cases, it can be polyostotic.

Clinical features:

The patient presents with a progressive limb deformity or a fracture through a previously asymptomatic lesion. Presentation is often in the second decade. Other symptoms include nonspecific bone pain, tenderness, and swelling in the affected area. The commonly involved sites are the proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot.

McCune-Albright syndrome: It is characterized by polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, precocious puberty, and cafe-au-lait spots with irregular borders.

Radiological findings:

  • Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions
  • Hazy, ground-glass appearance is seen in the majority of cases
  • Shepherd's crook deformity - Expansion with marked varus in the proximal femur

Treatment:

Bisphosphonates are used to manage bone pain. Surgical stabilization and realignment are done when there is a progressive deformity or pathological fracture. 

Other options: 

Option A: Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. It is most commonly seen in the diaphysis of the proximal femur. They most often present with pain that is classically worse at night and relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Plain X-ray demonstrates an area of dense sclerosis with a small rounded area of osteolysis. The preferred treatment is CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.

Option C: Chondrosarcoma is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor after osteosarcoma. It can present between the 3rd and 8th decades of life. They are slow-growing tumors that produce deep pain with an enlarging mass and arise in any bone derived from enchondral ossification. Radiographically, they appear as large, intraosseous, osteolytic tumors with irregular, granular calcifications, giving a honeycomb or popcorn appearance. CT and MRI are useful in the diagnosis. Chondrosarcoma is resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation. Surgical excision is the only treatment.

Option D: Ewing sarcoma is related to neuroectodermal tumors and arises from the mesenchymal stem cells from the bone marrow. The characteristic translocation involved is t(11:22). The tumor usually develops between 10 and 20 years of age and is usually located in the diaphysis of the long bones (femur-most common). Pain is followed by swelling and a low-grade fever. On radiography, a periosteal reaction with an 'onion peel' appearance is seen. Treatment includes preoperative chemotherapy, wide excision, and radiotherapy, if required.

Related Pearl: Classical Radiological Appearance of Bone Tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance / Codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion)

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis)

Soap bubble appearance

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient sustained a head injury in a road traffic accident. During the examination, the patient was unable to recall his name, the name of the place he lives in, or his date of birth. However, he was still able to remember the events such as his marriage. His non-declarative memory is intact. Which of the following areas of the brain is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient had a loss of memory associated with the facts (semantic memory), suggestive of injury to the prefrontal cortex or anterior/lateral temporal cortex.

Forms of memory are classified into two types, explicit and implicit.

Explicit/declarative memory is the memory of factual knowledge about people, places, things, and events. It is associated with consciousness/awareness. They are of two types:

  • Semantic memory (facts) e.g., knowing the capital of India, date of birth, names of people, etc. The parts of the brain involved are the lateral & anterior temporal cortex and prefrontal cortex.
  • Episodic memory (events) e.g., recalling the events that occurred on the first day in college. The parts of the brain involved are the hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and neocortex. 

Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory does not involve consciousness or awareness. They are of 4 types:

  • Procedural memory refers to skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic, such as riding a bicycle or driving a car. It is processed in the striatum.
  • Priming refers to the facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them. It is dependent on the neocortex.
  • Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitization. It is dependent on various reflex pathways.
  • Associative learning includes classical and operant conditioning in which one learns about the relationship between one stimulus and another. It is dependent on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: As the medical officer of a factory, you advise installing a water purification system to treat polluted water produced by the manufacturing process. Slow sand filters are chosen for the same purpose. Which is incorrect regarding 'schmutzdecke' associated with it?

choices.text: It is formed at the bottom of sand bed.
It is the heart of slow sand filter.
It removes organic matter and prevents bacteria from flowing through.
It is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton.

questions.solution:
Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer is formed above/at the top of the slow sand filter.

Slow sand filters:

These are also called biological filters. They are accepted as the standard method of large-scale water purification.

The elements of a slow sand filter include the following (from above downward):

  • Supernatant (raw) water - provides a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation, and particle agglomeration
  • Sand bed - Filters the water as it percolates the sand particles, through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation, and adsorption
  • Under-drainage system - System of porous and perforated pipes
  • System of filter control valves - Includes outlet-pipe system with valves and a venturi meter, which measures the bed resistance or the loss of head

In a new filter, the sand bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But, over time the sand bed becomes covered with schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms, and plankton (Option D). The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter, and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter (Option B). It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through (Option C), and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free. Until the vital layer is fully formed (takes several days), the filtrate of the first few days is usually run to waste.

Rapid sand filters:

They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large-scale purification of water. Two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).

Comparison between rapid and slow sand filters: 

Property Rapid sand filter Slow sand filter
Space Less space Large area
Rate of filtration 200 m.g.a.d 2–3 m.g.a.d
Effective size of sand 0.4–0.7 mm 0.2–0.3 mm
Preliminary treatment Chemical coagulation and sedimentation Plain sedimentation 
Washing Backwashing Scraping the sand bed
Operation Highly skilled Less skilled
Loss of head 2–2.5 m/6–8 feet 1.5 m/4 feet
Removal of turbidity Good Good
Removal of color Good Fair 
Removal of bacteria 98–99% 99.9–99.99% 


The blueprint given below depicts rapid sand filtration:

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

Related Pearl: Rapid Sand Filters

  • They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large scale purification of water.
  • The two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).
  • Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:
    • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum.
    • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
    • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminium hydroxide.
    • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculent along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place.
    • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
      • Filter beds: The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 metre and has graded gravel below it.
      • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer which adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.
      • Backwashing is done by reversing the flow of water through the sand bed. It dislodges the impurities and cleans the bed. Skilled labor is needed for this purpose.
    • Advantages of rapid sand filter:
      • Rapid sand filter does not need storage of water before it is treated.
      • It occupies less space when compared to slow sand filters.
      • Filtration is much more rapid than slow sand filters.
      • It is easy to wash and clean.
      • There is more flexibility in its operation.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: An ENT resident administers a submucosal injection of Teflon paste to one of his patients. Which of the following nasal conditions is he treating?
questions.solution:
Injection of submucosal Teflon paste is a treatment approach for atrophic rhinitis.

The nasal chambers are very wide in atrophic rhinitis, so the air currents dry up the secretions, leading to crusting. Thus, the narrowing of the nasal airway helps relieve the symptoms.

Young’s operation - Both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. The nostrils are re-opened after at least 6 months. With this procedure, the mucosa may revert to normal, and crusting may reduce.

Modified Young’s operation - This procedure aims at partially closing the nostrils. The result is the same as Young’s operation.

Other options:

Option A - Vasomotor rhinitis: Treated with vidian neurectomy, i.e. sectioning of parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the nose

Option C - Rhinitis medicamentosa is also known as rebound congestion. It occurs due to overuse of topical nasal decongestants which leads to inflammation. It is treated by discontinuing the decongestant. This may lead to an initial worsening of symptoms which can be relieved using intranasal corticosteroids.

Option D - Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by the gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It usually affects young adults in the third to fourth decade of life and risk factors include malnutrition, poor hygiene, and overcrowding. Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2 consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency room with complaints of continuous watery diarrhea that started 20 hours ago. On examination, he is drowsy and unresponsive. Findings of the microscopic examination of a stool sample are shown in the image below. All the following can be used as a transport medium for this causative organism, except _____.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette consisting of watery stools and the image showing the characteristic fish in stream appearance are suggestive of Vibrio cholerae, for which Stuart media cannot be used as a transport medium. Stuart medium is used as a transport medium for the Neisseria group of organisms.

Transport media for Vibrio cholerae: 

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary Blair medium
  • Autoclaved seawater.  

Enrichment media for Vibrio cholerae:

  • Alkaline peptone water at a pH of 8.6
  • Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water at a pH of 9.2.

 

Note: Both enrichment media are good transport media as well.

Related Pearl: Culture media used for Vibrio cholerae

The following are various culture media used for Vibrio cholerae: 

Transport Media

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man was brought to the casualty with the following findings. On examination, about 25% of the body surface showed sloughing. What is the most probable diagnosis?

SJS-Stevens-Johnson syndrome 

TEN-Toxic epidermal necrolysis
questions.solution:
The given image showing hemorrhagic crust and bloody peeling of the lips along with sloughing of 25% of the body surface area is suggestive of overlap SJS-TEN.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, where SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

Based on the type of cutaneous lesion and extent of maximal epidermal detachment, the disease is classified as follows:

Disease  Epidermal detachment  Purpuric macules and atypical target lesions 
SJS  <10% Present
Overlap SJS-TEN  10–30% Present
TEN with spots >30% Present 
TEN without spots  >30% (large sheets of epidermal loss) Absent 

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN:

  • Allopurinol
  • NSAIDs - oxicam group
  • Antiepileptics - phenobarbital, phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics - penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine, nevirapine

In 15% of the cases, where the drug cannot be identified, especially in children, lesions appear to be triggered by infections, most notably Mycoplasma pneumonia infection.

The image below shows SJS in the early stages with mucosal involvement.

Other options:

Option B: Erythema multiforme (EM) major is a severe illness associated with extensive target lesions and involvement of the mucous membrane. It usually has a sudden onset. Compared to SJS/TEN, EM major occurs in younger men, has lower grade of fever, and gives rise to milder mucosal lesions. There is no association with collagen vascular diseases, HIV, or cancer.

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

 

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell syndrome)
% Body Surface-area

<10%

 <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality

 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child abruptly developed symptoms suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder and Tourette syndrome. PANDAS, a pediatric neuropsychiatric disorder, is suspected. Which of the following organisms is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
PANDAS is associated with Streptococcus pyogenes infection.

PANDAS stands for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections.

The symptoms usually occur abruptly and can include the following:

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
  • Tic disorder
  • Gilles de la Tourette syndrome (coprolalia and tics)

Additionally, children may become moody or irritable, experience anxiety attacks, and/or show separation anxiety. These symptoms are the result of an autoimmune process that leads to inflammation of the basal ganglia and the resultant disruption of cortical-striatal-thalamic axis functioning.

Features:

  • Prepubertal onset
  • Abrupt and episodic course
  • Neurological symptoms
  • Disorders associated: Tics, OCD
  • Associated with a recent history of sore throat

Note: Non-infectious manifestations of streptococcal infection:

  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • PANDAS
  • Guttate psoriasis

questions.text: Which among the following is the narrowest constriction of the ureter where a ureteric stone is most likely to be lodged?
questions.solution:
The stone is most likely to be lodged in the vesicoureteric junction marked as D in the image as it is the narrowest part of the ureter.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. At the pelvi-ureteric junction
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery)
  3. At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

questions.text: A 60-year-old male complains of recurrent cough and difficulty in breathing for 2 months. A chest X-ray is provided below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest x-ray shown here demonstrates the Luftsichel sign, which translates from German as 'air crescent'. It is typically seen in the left upper lobe collapse, resulting in para-mediastinal translucency.  

It occurs due to hyperinflation of the superior segment of the left lower lobe, creating a crescent of air between the aortic arch and the medial border of the collapsed left upper lobe.

The CT below shows the collapse of the left upper lobe.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented with an altered mental status, flank pain, and polyuria. Laboratory investigations reveal hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria. He has a history of lung cancer, for which he underwent chemotherapy a few months back.  What is the next line of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy, a paraneoplastic syndrome occurring probably due to underlying lung cancer. The next line of management in this patient is the administration of intravenous saline.

Hypercalcemia of malignancy results from the ectopic production of PTH-related peptide (PTHrP). PTHrP is structurally similar to PTH and binds to the same receptors and has the same downstream actions. This is seen in squamous cell carcinomas of head and neck, lungs, and skin. Another mechanism that may be involved is the excess production of 1,25-hihydroxycholecalciferol, otherwise known as calcitriol. 
 
Patients are usually found to have hypercalcemia on routine laboratory tests. Calcium levels are markedly elevated, often >14 mg/dL. Patients may present with altered mental status, polyuria, dehydration, and renal stones. ECG shows shortened ST segment and QT interval. 

Laboratory investigations reveal high serum calcium levels, hypercalciuria, hypophosphatemia, and metabolic alkalosis. PTH measurement is useful in excluding hyperparathyroidism. PTH is suppressed in cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy, while it is elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Initial management is by rehydration with intravenous normal saline to dilute serum calcium levels. Along with this, subcutaneous calcitonin is also administered, to promote renal excretion of calcium and prevent further bone resorption. Intravenous bisphosphonates such as zoledronate and pamidronate (option C) reduce serum calcium levels over the next 1–2 days and provide a more sustained effect.

Forced diuresis with loop diuretics (option A) can be used in life-threatening hypercalcemia only after complete rehydration and with careful monitoring of fluid balance. Hemodialysis (option D) is considered in patients with renal insufficiency or heart failure, in whom hydration cannot be given without the risk of worsening of fluid status. Denosumab is used in patients with refractory hypercalcemia despite bisphosphonate therapy or if there is any contraindication to bisphosphonates.

questions.text: You notice this specialized vaporizer being used in the OT. Which of the following is true regarding the gas filled in this vaporizer?
questions.solution:
The image shows a specialized vaporizer, Tec 6. Because of its high vapor pressure (669 mmHg at 20°C) and low boiling point (22.8°C ~ room temperature), desflurane requires this specialized vaporizer for its delivery.

The new Tec 6 desflurane vaporizer is an electrically heated, pressurized, electromechanically coupled dual-circuit blender.

Important characteristics of desflurane: 

  • Anesthetic gas with the highest vapor pressure: High saturated vapor pressure, which is 3–4 times that of other agents
  • Low boiling point (22.8°C ~ room temperature)
  • Low blood-gas solubility (0.42), resulting in rapid uptake and recovery
  • High MAC value of 6, indicating low potency
  • Requires specialized vaporizer, such as Tec 6
  • Color coding - Blue
  • Undergoes minimal metabolism
  • Degraded into CO by the desiccated CO2 absorbent

Related Pearl: Color coding of Vaporisers

Volatile Agent  Color
Halothane Red
Isoflurane Purple
Sevoflurane Yellow
Desflurane Blue
Enflurane Orange

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice: 

Indication Anesthetic gas
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

 

Feature Drug
Most potent       Methoxyflurane > Halothane 
Least potent      Nitrous oxide > Desflurane

Most nephrotoxic Methoxyflurane 
Most hepatotoxic Halothane

questions.text: A student plots the following graph while studying the concentration of cyclins in various stages of the cell cycle. Which cyclin does the pink curve represent?
questions.solution:
The pink curve represents cyclin D, the first cyclin to appear in the cell cycle. The correct sequence of cyclins in the cell cycle is Cyclin D → Cyclin E → Cyclin A → Cyclin B.

The sequence of events that results in cell proliferation is called the cell cycle. It consists of G1 (gap 1), S (DNA synthesis), G2 (gap 2), and M (mitotic) phases. Quiescent cells that are not actively cycling are in the G0 (gap 0) state

Cell cycle progression is chaperoned by proteins called cyclins and cyclin-associated enzymes called cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). More than 15 cyclins have been identified; cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

Below is a graph showing the varying concentrations of cyclins during the cell cycle:


The image below shows the different checkpoints and cell cycle regulators:

questions.text: During the examination of an alcohol-intoxicated person, the pupils are constricted, but pinching the skin of the neck leads to transient dilatation of pupils, with a slow return to the original constricted state. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign is called McEwan's sign. In an alcohol-intoxicated patient, the pupils are constricted. But on the application of painful stimuli like pinching or slapping, the pupils slowly dilate. Once the painful stimulus is stopped, the pupils return back to their constricted state.

This is a characteristic finding of ethanol toxicity, seen at blood alcohol concentration levels >300 mg%. It is helpful in differentiating alcoholic coma from other comatose conditions.

The effects of alcohol intoxication at various blood alcohol concentrations are listed below.

Blood alcohol concentration (mg/dL) Effects 
30–50 Impairment of driving and similar skills
50–100 Reduced inhibitions, talkativeness, laughter
100–150 Incoordination, unsteadiness, slurred speech
150–200 Obvious drunkenness, nausea, and ataxia
200–300 Vomiting, stupor
300–350 Stupor , coma, risk of aspirating vomitus
350–450 and above Danger of death from respiratory paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following is assessed using the test shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Rorschach inkblot test, which is a projective personality test.

10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblots are shown to the participants. The test is administered in two phases:

  • Free association phase: Participant's response to the cards is recorded
  • Inquiry phase: Participants explain why they formed the impression.

Projective tests:

These tests are based on the principle that when presented with an ambiguous stimulus, such as an inkblot, the patient's responses will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality. The ambiguous stimulus is a sort of screen on which the individual projects his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Projective tests generally do not measure a particular personality type like 'type-A personality' (narrow-band measurement), but rather measure these as a 'whole' (broad-band measurement).

Commonly used projective tests are as follows:

  • Thematic apperception test
  • Rorschach's inkblot test
  • Sentence completion test
  • Draw a person test

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.

 

Sentence Completion Test

Uses Characteristics
Used to identify worries and problems using verbal associations

Projective test

Patients complete sentences started by the examiner

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman is rushed to the hospital with labor pains at 34 weeks of gestation. She did not attend any prior antenatal visits. On further evaluation, she is found to be positive for HbsAg. Which of the following should be administered to the newborn after delivery?

choices.text: Immunoglobulin, followed by vaccine 1 month later

questions.solution:
The simultaneous administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine is more efficacious than HBIG alone for the prevention of the carrier state in newborn babies of HBV-positive mothers.

HBIG does not interfere with the antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine. This combined procedure is ideal both for postexposure prophylaxis of persons accidentally exposed to blood known to contain hepatitis B virus and for the prevention of the carrier state in the newborn babies of carrier mothers.

HBIG (0.05–0.07 mL/kg) IM 

  • As early as possible, preferably within 24 hours of exposure

Hepatitis B vaccine (20 mcg/1.0 mL), IM

  • 1st dose: within 7 days of exposure
  • 2nd and 3rd dose: at one and six months, respectively

questions.text: A patient complains of epigastric pain for over 6 months, not relieved by over-the-counter medications. An endoscopic gastric biopsy tissue showed curved, gram-negative rods that were oxidase-positive. It grows at 37 degrees celsius in microaerophilic conditions. What is the organism most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of peptic ulcer disease caused by Helicobacter pylori.

H. pylori is a gram-negative motile rod with lophotrichous flagella. It has a unique feature of the production of urease, which is helpful in diagnosis. The sole source of H. pylori is the human gastric mucus. Gastric antrum is the commonest site of colonization. Infection is confined to the gastric mucosa in the stomach or in areas of gastric metaplasia and heteroplasia in the duodenum. 

In some patients, H. pylori causes mild acute gastritis lasting for about two weeks. In others, it can cause peptic ulcer disease, which in later stages may lead to chronic atrophic gastritis. This is a risk factor for gastric malignancies like adenocarcinoma and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

Diagnosis can be made by performing a biopsy. A piece of biopsy material is added to a urease indicator medium which will show a positive result within minutes inside the endoscopy room. Part of the biopsy material is sent for microscopy and culture. On microscopy, Warthin-Starry silver staining can be done where spiral bacilli are seen, as shown below.

Culture requires an enriched medium. It grows at 37°C in microaerophilic conditions and takes 3–7 days. The organisms obtained from the colonies are curved and oxidase positive. Non-invasive diagnostic tests like the urease breath test can also be performed. In this, the patient drinks a carbon-labeled urea solution which is later detected in the breath. 

The standard treatment is a combination of bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, and metronidazole for 2 weeks. Alternatively, proton pump inhibitors like omeprazole are also used along with clarithromycin. Treatment is not given for asymptomatic patients.

Other options:

Option A: Haemophilus influenzae is a fastidious organism that grows well on blood agar at 37°C. It mainly causes diseases like meningitis, croup, and pneumonia. 

Option B: Vibrio parahaemolyticus grows only in media that contain sodium chloride. It can tolerate salt concentrations of up to 8% in the media. The most commonly used media for this is thiosulphate citrate bile salts sucrose agar (TCBS). This organism is known to cause food poisoning associated with seafood. 

Option D: Campylobacter jejuni is best grown under microaerophilic conditions at 5% oxygen concentration. It is also thermophilic and grows at 42°C. C. jejuni is the most common cause of bacterial diarrhea in many developed countries.
