questions.text: An elderly patient presented with easy fatiguability and backache. He has had recurrent infections in the past 3 months. Reports showed hypercalcemia. His skull x-ray is  below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple myeloma is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. The given radiograph represents the multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance, which is seen in multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is the malignant production of plasma cells that results in bone pain or fractures, renal failure, increased susceptibility to infections, anemia, hypercalcemia, and manifestations of hyperviscosity. The incidence of multiple myeloma increases with age, and it is more commonly seen in males than in females.

Bone pain is the most common symptom and is due to the proliferation of tumor cells, stimulation of osteoclasts that destroy the bone, and inhibition of osteoblast cells that form new bone resulting in osteolytic lesions. Recurrent infections in multiple myeloma are due to hypogammaglobulinemia. Hypercalcemia results from the chronic mobilization of calcium from bones.

Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

Plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder: (specifically CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance of <40 mL/min or serum creatinine level of >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level >20 g/L (2 mg/dL) below the lowest limit of normal or hemoglobin level of <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron-emission tomography (PET)/CT
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
    • >1 focal lesion on MRI that is at least 5 mm or greater in size

Option A - Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by multiple tiny, well-defined lucencies in the skull due to the resorption of trabecular bone, resulting in the salt and pepper appearance or pepper pot skull. The clinical features are mainly due to hypercalcemia and typically include anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, depression, fatigue, and muscle weakness. Renal stones/nephrocalcinosis can occur due to hypercalciuria. Joint symptoms occur due to chondrocalcinosis.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal resorption of middle phalanges - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Loss of lamina dura 
  • An atypical cyst-like lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor 

Option C - Paget's disease is characterized by excessive bone remodeling. Most cases are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally on a radiograph or a raised alkaline phosphatase level. The symptoms include pain and deformities of the bones and cranial nerve palsy due to compression. The characteristic skull radiographic finding is the presence of mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull, which is referred to as the cotton wool appearance. 

Other radiographic findings in Paget's disease:

  • Picture frame vertebra
  • Squaring of vertebra on lateral radiographs
  • Blade of grass appearance in long bones

Option D- Eosinophilic granuloma is a mild form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis and is characterized by abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells, with an abundance of eosinophils, neutrophils, and lymphocytes. It results in medullary bone resorption. It usually presents with pain and swelling in the affected area. Otitis media and mastoiditis occur if the calvarium is involved. Compression fractures and neurological symptoms occur in spinal involvement. The characteristic skull finding is the geographic skull and solitary or multiple lytic lesions, with a beveled-edge appearance.

Other radiographic findings in eosinophilic granuloma:

  • Vertebra plana
  • Floating tooth in the mandible

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: For the engineering team project, Mr. X and Mr. Y were paired up. Mr. X, who is generally a lonely person,  requested a change of partner. When the tutor asked for an explanation for requesting this change, Mr. X replied, 'Mr. Y wants to be left alone.' Which of the following defense mechanisms best explains Mr. X's response?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Mr. X's response can be best explained by the defense mechanism of projection. Projection is when you attribute your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings to someone else.

Mr. X is projecting his wishes by stating that Mr. Y wants to be left alone when in reality it is he who wants to be left alone. Mr. X could have probably done this because of severe prejudice against Mr. Y, or because he senses danger or a bad outcome when paired with Mr. Y. 

Other options-

Option (A): Rationalization is making excuses for your behavior. Had that been the answer, he would have made excuses, such as he’s uncomfortable with Mr. Y. 

Option (C): Displacement would have been the correct answer if Mr. X had shouted at Mr. Y for the tutor having paired them together. Displacement is the shifting of emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

Option (D): Repression refers to subconsciously forgetting something. The scenario does not convey this mechanism.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

questions.text: A lady is brought to the casualty department with a 2-day history of diffuse abdominal pain. She has had several episodes of bloody diarrhea for the past 8 hours and appears dehydrated. On examination, her pulse is feeble and BP is 80/55 mmHg. An abdominal x-ray shows the "thumbprinting sign.” What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The thumbprinting sign is seen in both ischemic colitis and pseudomembranous colitis.

Bowel wall "thumbprinting" (the appearance of thumbprint-shaped projections) is a radiological sign of submucosal thickening of the colonic wall. It can result from any process that leads to edema of the bowel wall, including pseudomembranous colitis, ischemic colitis, non-infective inflammatory bowel disease, other infective bowel diseases, as well as submucosal/intramural hemorrhage.

The plain abdomen x-ray given below shows submucosal thickening with crescentic margins of the colon described as "thumbprinting" sign.

questions.text: An elderly woman was brought with worsening memory for the past 4 years. Recently, she has not been able to carry out her daily chores and lost her way at the supermarket. There is no evidence of personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances. Which of the following are the main neurotransmitters involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease, and the neurotransmitters that are most often implicated in its pathogenesis are acetylcholine and norepinephrine.

Main neurotransmitters involved:

  • Degeneration of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert - Reduced acetylcholine
  • Degeneration of the locus ceruleus - Reduced norepinephrine
  • Degeneration of dorsal raphe -Reduced serotonin

Two other neurotransmitters implicated in the pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease are somatostatin and corticotropin, which show decreased levels.

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. It begins with memory impairment, which later progresses to language and visuospatial deficits. Later, the patient has difficulty in keeping track of finances, following instructions, driving, shopping, and housekeeping. In severe impairment, the patient easily gets lost and confused.

Language deficits appear as impairment in naming, comprehension, and finally fluency. Visuospatial defects include difficulty dressing, eating, copying geometric figures, and reading the clock. Risk factors for the development of Alzheimer's disease include:

  • Age >70 years.
  • Positive family history.
  • Female gender.
  • Apo ε4 allele.
  • Diabetes (increase the risk threefold).
  • Hypertension.
  • Elevated homocysteine and cholesterol levels.
  • Diminished intake of folic acid, fruits, vegetables, and red wine.
  • Low levels of exercise.
  • Down syndrome.
  • Mutation in presenilin 1 and presenilin 2 genes.

Protective factors are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and Apo ε2. 

Treatment: Cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and NMDA receptor antagonist like memantine.

Related Pearl: Synucleinopathies and tauopathies

Synucleinopathies:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
  • REM behavioral disorder
  • Pure autonomic failure 
Tauopathies:
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Down syndrome
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Corticobasal degeneration
  • Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia
  • Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica
  • Postencephalitic parkinsonism
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration
  • Niemann Pick disease type C
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

questions.text: A population of 1000 children under 10 years living in town X is studied. 200 children have been diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia and are treated. 5 years later, 180 children are alive and doing well. What is the survival rate?
questions.solution:
Survival rate in this case is 90%. Survival rate is defined as the proportion of survivors in a group, (e.g. of patients) studied and followed over a period (e.g. a 5-year period).

The formula of survival rate is given as follows: Total number of patients alive after 5 years/Total number of patients diagnosed or treated x 100

Here, 180 patients were alive at the end of 5 years, making the survival rate: 180/200 x 100 = 90%.

The survival rate is a method of describing prognosis in certain disease conditions. It can be used as a yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy. Survival rates have received special attention in cancer studies.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: A young man presents with vomiting, nausea, and epigastric pain. He has been on proton-pump inhibitors for the past year. An endoscopy revealed multiple well-circumscribed polyps with a smooth surface, located on the gastric body and fundus. Shown below is a histopathological image of the polyp. Which of the following is this condition most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and site of the polyps are highly suggestive of fundic gland polyps. This condition is most likely associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Fundic gland polyps usually occur at a mean age of 50 years. They are commonly found in the gastric body and fundus. These polyps may occur sporadically with proton-pump inhibitor use or due to mutation of the APC gene. APC gene mutation is also associated with familial adenomatous polyposis and hence is a possible risk factor for the development of fundic gland polyps.

They may be asymptomatic or associated with nausea, vomiting, or epigastric pain. Dysplasia, and even cancer, may occur in FAP-associated fundic gland polyps. But sporadic polyps due to proton pump inhibitors use do not progress to neoplastic conditions. Another gastric polyp associated with FAP is gastric adenoma.

Histological image of fundic gland polyp showing cystically dilated, irregular glands lined by flattened parietal and chief cells. Inflammation is typically absent or minimal.

Other options: 

Option A: Chronic gastritis - Multiple, smooth, hyperplastic, or inflammatory polyps that are <1 cm in size occur in chronic gastritis. On histology, they show irregular, cystically dilated, and elongated foveolar glands with edematous lamina propria. Variable degrees of inflammation are present.

Option B: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome - It is due to the presence of gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors in the small intestine or pancreas. The oxyntic mucosa of the stomach is thickened due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Option C: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome - This is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. Histology shows a characteristic branching or arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by a normal-appearing intestinal epithelium. The following image shows the histology of a polyp in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: As a medical officer at a primary health center, you are training the staff to arrange different vaccines in ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs). What will be your advice for oral polio vaccine (OPV)?

choices.text: Keep it in the upper zone as it is heat sensitive.
Keep it in the upper zone as it is freeze sensitive.
Keep it in the lower zone as it is heat sensitive.
Keep it in the lower zone as it is freeze sensitive.

questions.solution:
OPV is heat sensitive; hence, it is kept in the lower zone of ILR.

ILRs are the main method of vaccine storage in district and sub-district vaccine stores (PHCs). They are an important part of the cold chain, and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 °C for the storage of vaccines.

They have different temperature zones for different vaccines. The upper zone in the ILR is for freeze-sensitive vaccines like cholera vaccine, hepatitis B vaccine, and rotavirus vaccine (liquid), while the lower zone is for heat-sensitive vaccines like OPV and measles vaccine.

All vaccines are kept in the basket provided with ILR. Vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE can be kept at the bottom of the basket while, DPT, TT, Hep B, IPV, and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in the upper part of the basket. 

Note: In the sub-district stores, OPV is kept in ILR, whereas in higher-level vaccine stores, it is kept in deep freezer (DF).

Related Pearl: Cold Chain Equipment

Cold chain equipment : 

Storage : 

  • Walk in cooler (WIC)
  • Walk in freezer (WIF)
  • Ice lined refrigerator (ILR)
  • Deep freezer 
  • Domestic refrigerator 

Solar :

  • Solar Refrigerator Battery drive
  • Solar Refrigerator Direct drive

Non electrical :

  • Cold box
  • Vaccine carrier

Transportation : 

  • Refrigerator vaccine van
  • Insulated vaccine van
  • Cold box 
  • Vaccine carrier

 

Electrical Cold Chain Equipment: 

Component

Temperature (degree Celsius)

Level

Other Comments

Walk in Freezers (WIF)

-15 to -25 

National, State and Regional vaccine stores

Used for bulk storage of OPV

Walk in Coolers (WIC)

+2 to +8

Government Medical Store Depot (GMSD), State and Regional vaccines stores

Used for bulk storage of most vaccines in UIP

Deep Freezer (DF)

-15 to -25 

District and Sub-district vaccines stores

Used for bulk storage of OPV and ice packs

Ice Line Refrigerator (ILR)

+2 to +8

District and Sub-district vaccines stores, PHCs

Has different temperature zones for different vaccines

Front Load Refrigerator (Domestic)

+2 to +8

Sub-district levels, hospitals. dispensaries and nursing homes

Used for all vaccines

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the process of reconversion of alanine formed in the muscles, back to glucose inside the liver. Which of the following is false regarding this cycle?
questions.solution:
The above cycle described is the glucose-alanine cycle or Cahill cycle and it is not active in fed state.

In the fasting state, muscle glycogen undergoes glycolysis. Pyruvate released during this glycolysis is transaminated to produce alanine. Alanine is then exported to the liver, where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate by alanine transaminase and enters gluconeogenesis to produce glucose. 

Also, this alanine serves as a transporter of ammonia. After reaching the liver the alanine is converted into pyruvate and glutamate by transaminase. The glutamate enters the urea cycle carrying the ammonia.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: After a diet rich in cholesterol, it is seen that the de novo synthesis of cholesterol in the liver decreases. Which of the following enzymes is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the enzyme HMG CoA reductase is involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis in the body.

HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Long-term regulation of cholesterol synthesis involves regulating the transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When there is sufficient cholesterol in the cell, transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase is suppressed, and there is decreased synthesis of cholesterol. 

When cholesterol is less, proteases in the Golgi bodies cleave a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP). The protein which is then formed binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This activates transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene which increases cholesterol synthesis.

Hormones that influence HMG reductase are:

  • Insulin and thyroxine increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Cortisol and glucagon decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Statins inhibit the activity of HMG CoA reductase

Other options:

Option A: Acetoacetyl CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction that combines two molecules of acetyl-CoA condense forming acetoacetyl-CoA. This acetoacetyl-CoA enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

Option B: HMG CoA lyase is involved in ketone body synthesis which converts HMG coA to acetoacetate. 

Option C: HMG CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction where the third molecule of acetyl CoA condenses with acetoacetyl CoA forming beta-hydroxy beta-methyl glutaryl CoA (HMG CoA).

questions.text: An egg is considered a "reference protein" because it has  ______

choices.text: No other macronutrient apart from protein.

questions.solution:
An egg has the highest NPU value, which is why it is considered a reference protein. 

Few important food substances whose NPU is to be remembered:

(Different books give different values; these values are quoted from Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition)

  • Egg - 100
  • Cow milk - 75
  • Meat - 80
  • Rice - 65
  • Groundnut/pulses - 50

The term net protein utilization is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body concerning nitrogen intake.

Note: The NPU of the Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Eggs contain all nutrients except carbohydrates and vitamin C.

A 60 gm egg contains

  • 6 g Fat
  • 6 g Protein
  • 30 mg Calcium
  • 1.5 mg Iron
  • 70 Kcal Energy

The cholesterol content is 250 mg/ egg. Eggs protein has all 9 amino acids needed for the body in the right proportions, and hence, it is considered as a "reference Protein". A boiled egg is nutritionally superior to raw egg; further, boiling destroys avidin, a substance that prevents the body from absorbing biotin.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: A 27-year-old IT professional has presented to you with intense watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. He took out his contact lens and applied eye lubricants to help alleviate his ailment, but it didn't provide any relief. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis. It is most commonly associated with contact lens wear. It can also be associated with ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles.

Patients usually present with redness, foreign body sensation, increased mucus production, itching, blurring, and loss of contact lens tolerance. On examination, giant papillae are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae.

Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva. These are caused by the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system, with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.

The image below shows papillae in the tarsal conjunctiva.

Treatment includes the removal of the offending cause. Mast cell stabilizers, such as sodium cromoglycate, and drugs like azelastine and olopatadine, which have combined antihistamine and mast cell–stabilizing effects, are effective. Steroids can be used for resistant cases.

Other options:

Option A: In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

Option B: In follicular conjunctivitis, follicles are seen. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer.

The image shows follicles.

Option D: In spring catarrh (vernal catarrh), cobblestone appearance is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen. It is more common during summer.

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A patient who has been on theophylline for several weeks has complaints of gastric discomfort and increased urinary frequency.  He has recently been prescribed a drug for the management of chronic gout. The symptoms were attributed to theophylline toxicity caused by an interaction with the newly prescribed drug. Identify the prescribed drug.
questions.solution:
The drug that was prescribed for gout in this case is most likely to be allopurinol. 

Allopurinol decreases the clearance of theophylline. It inhibits CYP1A2 in the liver, and theophylline is mainly metabolized by CYP1A2 in the liver. This leads to plasma concentration–dependent side effects of theophylline. 

The toxicity and side effects of theophylline are mostly dose-related and generally tend to occur at plasma concentrations greater than 15 mg/L. The adverse effects and their mechanism are summarized below:

       Side effect         Mechanism
Nausea, vomiting, gastric discomfort    PDE4 inhibition
Headaches    PDE4 inhibition
Diuresis / increased urinary frequency     A1 receptor antagonism
Cardiac arrhythmias     PDE3 and A1 receptor antagonism
Epileptic seizures     A1 receptor antagonism

Theophylline belongs to a class of drugs called methylxanthines. It can be given intravenously or orally as tablets or elixirs. Its therapeutic range is 5–15 mg/L and has antiasthma effects (besides bronchodilatation) below 10 mg/L.

Once administered, it is rapidly and completely absorbed, but there are large interindividual variations in clearance due to differences in hepatic metabolism. Theophylline is metabolized in the liver, mainly by CYP1A2 and many factors influence hepatic metabolism and clearance of theophylline.

Factors that decrease the clearance of theophylline:

  • Drugs that cause CYP inhibition - erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, allopurinol, fluvoxamine, zileuton, zafirlukast
  • Congestive heart failure, liver disease, pneumonia
  • Viral infection and vaccination
  • High-carbohydrate diet
  • Old age

Factors increasing its clearance:

  • Drugs like rifampin and ethanol, which are inducers of enzymes such as CYP1A2
  • Tobacco and marijuana smoking, by CYP1A2 induction
  • High-protein, low-carbohydrate diet
  • Barbequed meat

It has been used as a controller in the management of mild persistent asthma and is also used as a bronchodilator in COPD.

An illustration of its efficacy and toxicity at different doses is given in the diagram below.

questions.text: An infant born 48 hours back by vaginal delivery with birth asphyxia develops seizures. What stage of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the child likely to be in?
questions.solution:
Seizures are common in stage 2 of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE).

Stages Seizures 
Stage 1 Nil 
Stage 2 Common 
Stage 3 Decerebration 

HIE is an important cause of permanent damage to CNS tissues, resulting in the following:

  • Neonatal Death
  • Cerebral Palsy
  • Developmental Delay

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L1 woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with pruritus on the palms and soles for 2 weeks. She also had yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL. Alkaline phosphatase levels were elevated, and serum transaminase levels were normal. She also reports that she had similar complaints during the previous pregnancy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease occurring in the 2nd or 3rd trimester. It is characterized by pruritus (worse on palms and soles and at the night) and icterus. It is also known as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum.

Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment, but total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 4 to 5 mg/dL. Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated, but seldom exceed 250 U/L. Total and fasting serum bile acid concentrations are elevated. Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated. Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Management comprises antihistamines, topical emollients, cholestyramine, and ursodeoxycholic acid.

Other options:

Option B: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy manifests mostly in the last trimester of pregnancy with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, epigastric pain, and progressive jaundice. There may be hypertension, protein­uria, and edema. There is moderate to severe liver dysfunction with hypofi­brinogenemia, hypoalbuminemia, hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting times. Serum bilirubin level is usually <10 mg/dL, and serum transaminases are ele­vated but <1000 U/L.

Option C: Acute viral hepatitis is usually asymptomatic. When symptomatic, it presents with nausea, vomiting, and malaise, followed by jaundice. Low-grade fever may be present. Serum bilirubin rises, and transaminase levels vary.

Option D: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is commonly associated with obesity, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia­ syndrome. It is usually asymptomatic with elevated transaminases.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with complaints of continuous urinary dribbling from the vagina. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done and the middle swab is stained with blue. Intravenous pyelogram is normal. In India, which among the following could be the most likely cause of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Neglected labor is the most common cause of vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) in developing countries like India. In developed countries, surgical injury to the bladder is the most common cause of VVF.

Causes of vesico-vaginal fistula:

  • Obstetric: Prolonged or neglected labor
  • Gynecological: As a complication of total hysterectomy or anterior colporrhaphy
  • Radiotherapy
  • Direct neoplastic infiltration:  Seen in carcinoma cervix

Patients usually present with unexplained, continuous urinary leakage from the vagina after a recent procedure. Other non-specific symptoms include fever, pain, ileus and bladder irritability.

Clinical assessment by the introduction of a speculum helps to determine the size, number, and location of the fistulae. A methylene blue test helps confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of repair operation.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. Most established fistulas need to be repaired vaginally usually after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside.

The repair operation includes the Latzko procedure. The procedure involves denuding the vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximating the raw surfaces. Another is the Chassar-Moir technique of widely separating the bladder and vagina and suturing them separately in two layers.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months. Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: The jugular venous pressure of a cardiac patient is being monitored, and the following curve is plotted. Which of the following statements is false regarding the curve shown below?

choices.text: a and x waves are due to atrial events of cardiac cycle.
v and y waves are due to ventricular events of cardiac cycle.
a and c waves are due to systolic events of cardiac cycle.
x and y waves are due to diastolic events of cardiac cycle.

questions.solution:
The answer is option B: v and y waves are due to atrial events of the cardiac cycle.

Waveforms seen in a normal JVP:

  • The a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (systole) and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • The c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • The x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • The v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • The y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole. 

The Wiggers diagram given below correlates JVP with other aspects of the cardiac cycle. 

 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 29-year-old female patient was referred to you from the gynecology department for an incidental finding of a liver lesion on her abdominal and pelvic ultrasound scan. She has no history of abdominal pain or discomfort. She has not been on any medication, except for oral contraceptive pills. A CT scan was ordered, and the image is given below. What is your most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows a hepatic adenoma.

Hepatic adenomas, also referred to as hepatocellular adenomas, are benign liver tumors. They are well-defined, vascular lesions, which are generally solitary. They are almost always seen in women between the age of 25 and 50 years and are associated with the use of the oral contraceptive pill.

Most are found incidentally on imaging, although some may present with upper abdominal pain caused by local compression, rupture, or bleeding. Up to 10% of these tumors can develop into hepatocellular carcinoma.

On CT, uncomplicated adenomas are usually homogeneous, with a well-defined margin. They enhance markedly and uniformly during the arterial phase and then merge with the surrounding liver during the portal phase.

Treatment is surgical excision if the tumor is >5 cm in size. Asymptomatic tumors may regress after discontinuing oral contraceptive pills.

Other options:

Option A - Hemangioma: On contrast-enhanced CT scan, hemangiomas show asymmetrical, nodular peripheral enhancement that is isodense, with large vessels and progressive centripetal enhancement.

Option B - Metastatic deposits: Most metastases appear as areas of low attenuation on unenhanced CT and portal-phase CT. Hypervascular tumors are often visible as low-attenuation lesions on unenhanced images and may enhance transiently in the arterial phase, some becoming invisible in the portal phase.

Option C: Focal nodular hyperplasia - CT scan shows well-circumscribed lesions with a typical central scar. They show intense homogeneous enhancement on arterial-phase contrast-enhanced images and are often isodense or invisible when compared with the background liver in the venous phase.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1L1 woman at term is admitted to the labor room for normal vaginal delivery. A per vaginal examination was performed once her membranes ruptured, and a pulsatile cord-like structure was felt. An immediate ultrasound revealed that the baby was still alive, and cardiotocography revealed prolonged and variable decelerations. What is the definitive management in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of cord prolapse and the definitive management in this condition is delivery of the baby by cesarean section.

The management algorithm of cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

  • Living or dead baby
  • Maturity of the baby
  • Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is the delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

  • If the baby is dead - 
    • Reconfirmation with ultrasound
    • Spontaneous delivery when death is confirmed
    • Destructive operations are rarely needed
  • If immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible - 
    • When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances as it takes a longer time 
    • Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction
    • Transverse lie - the internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction
  • When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible - 
    • Relieve pressure on the cord
    • Oxytocin infusion is stopped
    • Oxygen supplementation and intravenous fluids are given

The contraindications of immediate delivery are fetal death, lethal fetal anomalies, and a pre-viable gestation.

Forceps-assisted (Option A) delivery can be done if deemed quicker and the head is engaged. But, this is not the definitive management. Manual repositioning (Option D) of the cord is done to minimize exposure to the external environment that may induce vasospasm due to colder temperatures. It is rarely used nowadays and Vago's method is preferred.

In Vago's method (Option B) a Foleys catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with >500 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression of the cord and helps decrease uterine contractions. It is generally used to stabilize the mother and baby until definitive management is done. 

Other methods that may be used:

  • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina
  • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, an exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position as shown below
  • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery, but is associated with a risk of uterine atony after delivery

Sims postion:

Trendelenburg position:

Knee-chest position:

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is given below:

questions.text: The given instrument was used to treat a patient with uterine prolapse. Which of the following statements is false about this instrument?

choices.text: It should be changed every 3 months.
It can be used in pregnant patients.
It may rarely cause carcinoma of vagina.

questions.solution:
The given image shows a ring pessary, which is only a palliative treatment for genital prolapse. 

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients and very elderly women. In these patients, it is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy.

Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. After being placed, they should be changed every 3 months. They may cause vaginitis; dyspareunia; and, rarely, carcinoma if retained for a long time.

The image below shows the types of pessaries:

questions.text: In which of the following layers of skin are desmosomes abundant?
questions.solution:
Desmosomes are abundant in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis. Stratum spinosum in the above image is represented by ‘3’.

The stratum spinosum/spinous layer/prickle cell layer is situated immediately above the basal cell layer. The epibasal keratinocytes enlarge to form this layer.

The desmosomes appear like spines on microscopy, and hence, this layer is also called the prickle layer. Desmosomes are the major adhesion complex in the epidermis. They anchor keratin intermediate filaments to the cell membrane and form bridges between adjacent keratinocytes. 

One of the main components of desmosomes is a transmembrane cadherin called desmoglein (Dsg). There are 4 types of epidermis‐specific desmogleins— Dsg1 to Dsg4. Disruption of Dsg1 occurs in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome and bullous impetigo. Dsg-2 damage is associated with arrythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy and Dsg-3 damage is associated with pemphigus vulagris. Antibodies to desmosomal proteins may develop in conditions like paraneoplastic pemphigus.

From superficial to deep, the layers of the epidermis are marked in the below image-

  1. Stratum corneum
  2. Stratum granulosum
  3. Stratum spinosum
  4. Stratum basale

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification was noted radiologically. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an infant with primary adrenal insufficiency with hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent vomiting, and bilateral adrenal calcification is suggestive of Wolman's disease. This disease is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme acid lipase.

Wolman's disease:

  • Rare lipid storage disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in the most visceral organs
  • Presents in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

Other options:

Option A: 11β-hydroxylase deficiency causes congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). It is the most common enzyme deficiency leading to childhood hypertension.

Option B: Deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase/α-1,4-glucosidase causes Pompe's disease, a type II glycogen storage disorder. It is a rapidly progressive disorder that results in hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and macroglossia; chest x-ray image shows cardiomegaly.

Option D: Deficiency of P450 oxidoreductase (POR) results in congenital anomalies collectively referred to as Antley-Bixler syndrome. These include deficiencies of 17-hydroxylase and 21-hydroxylase, which leads to congenital adrenal hyperplasia, along with other congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A patient presented with cough, hemoptysis, and an evening rise in temperature. He was suspected to have pulmonary tuberculosis, and the sputum sample was sent for microbiological examination with Ziehl-Neelsen stain. All of the following stains are used in this procedure, except ________.
questions.solution:
All the stains mentioned above are used in the Ziehl-Neelsen staining method, except safranin.

Mycobacteria are acid-fast due to the presence of mycolic acid in their cell walls. 

The image given below shows the cell wall structure of mycobacteria.

On being stained with carbol fuchsin or fluorescent dyes such as auramine-O or rhodamine, mycobacteria resist decolorization by 20% sulphuric acid and absolute alcohol for 10 minutes. This property is referred to as acid and alcohol fastness and is routinely used to identify mycobacteria.

Acid-fast bacteria (AFB) in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background. The AFB can be appreciated by Ziehl-Neelsen staining or cold staining (Kinyoun stain). 

The image given below shows a sputum smear stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain showing Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Steps involved in Ziehl-Neelsen stain:

  1. Place sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  2. Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  3. Apply carbol fuchsin stain and heat to fix it.
  4. Wash with water to remove excess stain.
  5. Decolorize with alcohol. 
  6. Apply methylene blue/malachite green stain. 
  7. Wash with water to remove excess stain.
  8. View under microscope.

The image given below shows the steps involved in Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

Kinyoun modified the classical Ziehl-Neelsen staining method such that heat fixing is not required, which is why it is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. It is then washed with water and decolorized with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope.

Related Pearl: Acid fast Organisms

Acid-fast organisms Sulfuric acid (%) required for decolorization 
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis 
 25%
  • Mycobacterium leprae
 5%

 

  • Eggs of Taenia saginata
  • Eggs of Schistosoma mansoni
  • Oocyst of Cryptosporidium
  • Oocyst of Cyclospora
  • Oocyst of Cystoisospora
 1%
  • Sperm head
  • Legionella micdadei
  • Nocardia

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image and the structure it articulates with.

choices.text: Superior costal facet, Head of rib
Superior articular facet, Head of rib
Inferior articular facet, Tubercle of rib
Transverse process of vertebra, Tubercle of rib

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the transverse process. It articulates with the tubercle of the rib to form the costotransverse joint.

The various types of joints in the thoracic wall:

Type of Joint  Examples 
Synovial joint

Costovertebral joint

Costotranverse joint

Interchondral joints
Primary cartilaginous joint or Synchondrosis Costochondral joint
Secondary cartilaginous or Symphyses joint Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints

 Note :  

  • Sternocostal joints: These are the joints between the costal cartilages of the first seven ribs and the sternum.
    • The joint between the 1st costal cartilage and manubrium is a fibrocartilaginous joint (synarthrosis).
    • The joints between the 2nd to 7th costal cartilages and the sternum are synovial joints.
  • The interchondral joint between the costal cartilages of the 9th and 10th ribs is never synovial and is usually absent.

The following image shows the marked parts of vertebrae.

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

 Joints
  • Costovertebral: Rib to the vertebral body  
  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

Articulations with the vertebrae

Ribs 2 to 9: 3 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the inferior costal facet of the vertebral body above
  • Head of the rib to the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Rib 1: 2 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 10, 11 and 12: 1 articulation

  • 10th rib - upper border of the tenth thoracic vertebra near its pedicle
  • 11th, 12th ribs - Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body

Articulations with the sternum

Ribs 1- 7: True ribs - Articulate directly with a single costal cartilages 

Ribs 8 - 10: False ribs - Articulate with a common costal cartilage.

Ribs 11 and 12: Floating ribs - Do not articulate with the sternum

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with a history of recurrent urinary tract infection presents with fever, tachypnea, tachycardia, mental obtundation, and reduced blood pressure. Which of the following coagulation factors is activated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of septic shock as a result of gram-negative sepsis originating from a urinary tract infection and the coagulation factor activated in this condition is factor XII.

Factors involved in the pathophysiology of septic shock:

Inflammatory and counter-inflammatory responses - 

Microbial products such as pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) lead to increased expression of genes encoding inflammatory mediators. These include cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF), interleukin 1 (IL-1), IL-12, IL-18, and interferon-γ (IFN-γ). C-reactive protein and procalcitonin are also elevated. Reactive oxygen species, prostaglandins, and platelet-activating factors are also increased. Activation of the complement pathway also occurs. The coagulation cascade is activated directly through factor XII and indirectly through altered endothelial function. Both hyperinflammatory and immunosuppressed states are triggered simultaneously.

Endothelial activation and injury:

There is widespread vascular leakage and tissue edema as a result of the pro-inflammatory state and endothelial cell activation leading to the accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid throughout the body. Systemic hypotension is a direct consequence of vascular smooth muscle relaxation due to upregulation of NO, C3a, C5a, and PAF production. These changes cause a mismatch in oxygen needs and oxygen delivery.

Induction of a procoagulant state:

Pro-inflammatory cytokines decrease the production of endothelial anticoagulant factors and decreases fibrinolysis. There is stasis of blood in small vessels and capillaries due to vascular leaks and tissue edema. This leads to systemic activation of thrombin and the deposition of fibrin-rich thrombi in small vessels, further compromising tissue perfusion, and causing DIC.

Metabolic abnormalities:

Insulin resistance and hyperglycemia are seen in patients with sepsis as cytokines such as TNF and IL-1, stress-induced hormones such as glucagon, growth hormone, and glucocorticoids and catecholamines increase the process of gluconeogenesis. Neutrophil function is markedly decreased which leads to a reduction in bactericidal activity.

Organ dysfunction:

All these factors compromise the delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the tissues causing cellular hypoxia and end-organ damage.

questions.text: An epidemiologist describes the epidemiologic data received from field investigations and surveillance by using the chart given below. Which of the following examples best represents the chart shown in the image?

choices.text: Gonorrhea outbreak from a sex worker

questions.solution:
The chart in the image shows an epidemic curve that rises and falls rapidly with no secondary waves. This is indicative of a point-source epidemic. Among the given options, an epidemic of food poisoning is the best example of a point-source epidemic.

Point-source epidemics are also called single-exposure epidemics and belong to the common source type of epidemics. The exposure to the disease agent is brief, and all cases develop within one incubation period. Single-exposure outbreaks are explosive, with clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. Infectious agents, environmental pollution, and food contamination are common causes of point-source epidemics.

Common-source, single-exposure epidemics are differentiated from common-source, multiple-exposure epidemics as follows:

  Common-source, single-exposure epidemic Common-source, multiple-exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

 

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

Other options:

Options B and C - Outbreak of Legionnaire's disease and a gonorrhea outbreak from a sex worker are examples of a common-source, multiple-exposure epidemic. The exposure from the same source may be prolonged—continuous, repeated, or intermittent—and not at the same time or place. There is no single explosive increase in the number of cases.

Option D - Epidemic of yellow fever (arthropod vector) is an example of propagated epidemics that result from the transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. Cases occur over more than one incubation period.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man who has prostate cancer is being treated with a long-acting GnRH agonist. After prolonged injection of GnRH, which of the following will most likely be seen in this patient?

↓-Low levels, ↑-High levels

Options FSH LH Testosterone
A ↓ ↓ ↑
B ↓ ↓ ↓
C ↑ ↑ ↑
D ↑ ↑ ↓
questions.solution:
Prolonged injection of GnRH(gonadotropin-releasing hormone) will lead to decreased LH, FSH, and testosterone levels.

A constant administration of GnRH produces an initial agonistic action known as "flare", followed by downregulation of GnRH receptors ( decrease in GnRH receptor concentration). This desensitizes the pituitary to the action of GnRH and a hypogonadotropic-hypogonadal state is induced. This is characterized by low LH (luteinizing hormone) and FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) levels, thereby reducing testosterone production (i.e., chemical castration).

The regulation of gonadotropin secretion by the hypothalamus involves the pulsatile release of GnRH. GnRH is secreted in pulses lasting between 5 to 25 minutes at 1 to 2 hours intervals. This intermittent release is crucial for stimulating the anterior pituitary gland to secrete LH and FSH. Continuous infusion of GnRH, in contrast, leads to the downregulation of GnRH receptors in the pituitary, resulting in reduced secretion of LH and FSH.

In the treatment of prostate cancer, which is driven by the carcinogenic effects of testosterone, continuous infusion of GnRH agonists is used. This treatment effectively suppresses testosterone levels by downregulating GnRH receptors, thereby reducing the stimulation of LH and FSH. In the case of a 70-year-old man undergoing long-term GnRH agonist therapy for prostate cancer, the expected outcome would be decreased levels of FSH, LH, and testosterone due to the prolonged suppression of GnRH signaling.

questions.text: A new genetic syndrome has been defined, and its etiology is being debated by many scholars all around the world. A study is being performed, where you will describe the disease according to its distribution in terms of time, place and person, to formulate the hypothesis. In this study, you will do____.
questions.solution:
A descriptive study is the study of choice for formulating an etiological hypothesis of a disease, where only observation is done.

Types of epidemiological study:

  1. Observational study
    • Descriptive studies (hypothesis formulation)
    • Analytical studies (hypothesis testing)

     2. Experimental studies/Intervention study (hypothesis confirmation)

A descriptive study is undertaken to formulate an etiological hypothesis for a given disease. On the other hand, an analytical study is performed to test the hypothesis (i.e. to accept or reject the hypothesis).

Descriptive study:

  • Descriptive studies are limited to the description of a disease, including its etiology, pathogenesis, and occurrence, in a population.
  • Diseases of unknown etiology or new diseases can be studied with descriptive epidemiology.
  • There is no intervention in this type of study—it is merely observational.
  • The diseases are described on the basis of their distribution in terms of time, place, and person, and a hypothesis is formed.
  • This hypothesis is then tested using other types of studies.
  • Studies like longitudinal and cross-sectional studies are used for the measurement of the disease being investigated.

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of low-grade fever, irritability, headache, and neck rigidity for the past 1 week. Examination reveals papilledema and abducens nerve palsy. MRI shows dilated ventricles and significant basal exudates. Which of the following would most likely be seen in the CSF?
questions.solution:
The features and imaging findings are suggestive of tuberculous meningitis. CSF analysis would most likely show lymphocytosis, low glucose level, and high protein level. 

Tuberculous meningitis presents as a subacute infection and has a longer course than bacterial meningitis. Ocular nerve palsy is a common association as there is marked meningeal involvement at the base of the brain. The patient can also develop hydrocephalus.

The clinical triad of fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity is common to all types of meningitis. Nuchal rigidity is the resistance of the neck to passive flexion and is pathognomonic of meningeal irritation. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs are other features of meningeal irritation. Raised intracranial pressure (ICP) is a complication that presents as papilledema, disorientation, or dilated poorly reactive pupils.

If the CSF is allowed to stand, a 'spider’s web clot' or 'cobweb' coagulum may form due to the high level of protein. There is usually lymphocytic leukocytosis, low glucose concentration, and elevated levels of proteins. Acid-fast bacilli are not frequently seen on the direct smear of the CSF sediment. CSF culture remains the gold standard for diagnosis. However, CB-NAAT (a type of nucleic acid amplification method) is the initial diagnostic test of choice because of its high sensitivity and quicker results compared to culture.

Imaging studies (CT and MRI) may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.
