questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with no comorbidities develops palpitations during an exercise routine. She visits a physician who then diagnoses her with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Which of the following medications can be used in the prophylactic management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Verapamil can be used to manage this patient's condition prophylactically.

Drugs used to treat PSVT include oral beta blockers, verapamil, or diltiazem. They are given at the beginning of the episode. If prophylactic therapy is needed, chronic treatment with the same drugs or flecainide can be given.  

Verapamil and diltiazem are calcium channel blockers that belong to class IV antiarrhythmics.  

CCBs are classified based on their chemical structures into dihydropyridines and non-dihydropyridines. Verapamil and diltiazem are non-dihydropyridines that act on cardiac myocytes.

These drugs act by blocking L-type Ca2+ channels and delaying their recovery. This in turn prolongs the AV node effective refractory period (ERP).

Class IV arrhythmic such work particularly well in the management of supraventricular and nodal arrhythmias. These agents can be used in the termination and prevention of such arrhythmias.

Other options:

Option A: Disopyramide is a class Ia antiarrhythmic that is primarily used as a second-line agent to prevent the recurrence of ventricular arrhythmias.

Option B: Quinidine is a class Ia antiarrhythmic. It is rarely used in clinical practice due to the availability of better-tolerated antiarrhythmic drugs. Cardiac adverse effects of quinidine include prolonged QT interval and torsades de pointes. 

Option D: Adenosine is the preferred agent in the acute termination of an episode of supraventricular tachyarrhythmias since it is fast acting and has a short half life. Adenosine cannot be used to prevent recurrences of supraventricular arrhythmias and the preferred agents in such a situation are verapamil and diltiazem.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a known history of sickle cell disease presented with sustained painful penile erection for the last 5 hours. Blood gas analysis from the penis shows hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. Aspiration of the sludge of blood is done, but it fails to improve the condition. Which of the following drugs should now be injected into the structure marked as 'X' in the image?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests priapism. Intracavernosal (Part 'X' in the image) injection of phenylephrine (an alpha-adrenoceptor agonist) is administered if the aspiration of the sludge blood fails. 

Priapism refers to a persistent erection lasting for >4 hours unrelated to sexual stimulation. There are two types of priapism:

  • Ischemic (more common)
  • Non-ischemic

Ischemic priapism occurs due to venous congestion and consequent thrombosis. On examination, the penis is tender. Blood gas analysis of penile blood shows hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. Risk factors for priapism are sickle cell disease or trait, malignancy, medications, cocaine abuse, and total parenteral nutrition.

Detumescence should be ensured in 6-12 hours to avoid progressive, irreversible damage to the corpus cavernosal tissue with subsequent fibrosis and erectile dysfunction. Initial management can be done with oral agents like pseudoephedrine or baclofen.

  • First-line treatment- Aspiration of the sludged blood in the corpora cavernosa
    • By insertion of a large 18-gauge needle into the lateral aspect of one corporal body 
  • Intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine (an alpha-adrenoceptor agonist) is the next line of therapy.
  • Surgical shunts
    • Distal shunts like Winter shunt (in the emergency room), Al-Ghorab shunt (operative shunt)
    • Proximal shunts like Quackel shunt (cavernosal-spongiosal shunt), Grayhack shunt (corporal-saphenous shunt)

For patients with sickle cell disease, hydration and oxygen administration should be performed first. 

Non-ischemic priapism usually occurs after blunt perineal trauma. A fistula develops between the central penile artery and the sinusoidal space, leading to a persistent, painless erection. Blood gas analysis shows characteristics of arterial blood. Treatment is not an emergency and is done by selective arterial embolization.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the given structure.

choices.text: H1 is most tightly bound to chromatin
1.75 turns of DNA are wrapped around the octamer
The linker DNA between such units consists of 30 base pairs
Acetylation is one of the post-translational modifications

questions.solution:
The given structure is the nucleosome and the octamer, which forms the core component of the nucleosome is the core histones, namely H2A, H2B, H3, and H4. The incorrect statement is H1 is most tightly bound to chromatin.

H1 is least tightly bound to chromatin and can be removed by adding salt solution.

Nucleosomes are composed of DNA wound around an octameric complex of histone molecules. Histones are a small family of closely related basic proteins composed of arginine and lysine. H3 and H4 form a tetramer, while H2A and H2B form dimers; these histone oligomers associate to form the histone octamer. 1.75 turns of DNA are wrapped around octamer, protecting 145–150 base pairs of DNA.

The histone H1 is seen in the linker region and is bound loosely to the nucleosome. The linker region is formed of 30 base pairs of DNA.

These four core histones are subject to at least six types of covalent modification or post-translational modifications:

  • Acetylation
  • Methylation
  • Phosphorylation
  • ADP-ribosylation
  • Monoubiquitylation
  • Sumoylation

questions.text: A patient with a lower urinary tract infection has been prescribed an antimicrobial agent that is a combination of two drugs in the ratio of 20:1. Identify the two drugs that are combined to form this agent.
questions.solution:
The antimicrobial agent prescribed is cotrimoxazole—a combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim in a ratio of 20:1.

The optimal plasma ratio of sulfamethoxazole:trimethoprim for cotrimoxazole is 20:1. 

The optimal ratio of the concentrations of the two drugs is the ratio of the minimum inhibitory concentrations of the independent drugs. The most effective ratio for most of the microorganisms is 20:1 for sulfamethoxazole:trimethoprim. Thus, the combination of these drugs contains sulfamethoxazole at a concentration that is 20 times greater than that of trimethoprim.

It is used in the treatment of urinary tract, respiratory, and GI infections, as well as Pneumocystis jirovecii and MRSA infections. The antimicrobial activity of the combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole is due to their actions on sequential steps of the pathway for tetrahydrofolic acid synthesis.

questions.text: A patient with an ulcer shown in the image below is admitted to the general surgery ward. A history of which of the following would you be likely to elicit in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows an ulcer with an undermined edge, which is seen in tuberculosis and could be associated with a preceding history of chronic cough and weight loss. 

Other options:

Option A: Unprotected sexual intercourse may be a significant history pointing towards syphilis which causes an ulcer with punched-out edges and wash-leather slough.

Option B: Exposure to UV radiation suggests the development of skin cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma has everted edges and basal cell carcinoma has rolled-out edges.

Option D: Diabetes mellitus causes neuropathic/trophic ulcer with punched-out edges.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of hematopoietic stem cells?
questions.solution:
CD34 is the marker of hematopoietic stem cells.

Option A: PAX5 is a transcription factor required for B cell development.
Option B: Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (Tdt) is a specialized DNA polymerase that is expressed only in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.
Option D: CD1a - It is common to all T Cells. CD1a is also seen in the Langerhans type of dendritic cell.

Related Pearl: Classification of Stem Cells

Types of stem cells

Capacity to differentiate

Examples

Totipotent cells

They can form embryonic and extraembryonic cells

Zygote, early blastomeres

Pluripotent cells

They can form all cell types of an embryonic body but cannot form that of the placenta and umbilical cord

Inner cell mass

Multipotent cells

They form more than one category of cells

Hematopoietic stem cells

Oligopotent cells

They form only one category of cells

Vascular stem cells

Unipotent

They can form only one type of cell

Liver cell

questions.text: A patient with breast cancer underwent the dissection of lymph nodes which are shown in the image below. Lymphatic drainage of which body part will not be affected?
questions.solution:
The infra umbilical anterolateral body wall does not drain into the axillary lymph nodes. All the remaining options listed drain into them.

Axillary lymph nodes collectively drain the entire upper limb, breast, and trunk above the umbilicus.

Axillary nodes can be divided into 5 groups:

  • Lateral/humeral
  • Anterior/pectoral
  • Posterior/subscapular
  • Central
  • Apical

Given below is a diagrammatic representation and details about the individual axillary groups of lymph nodes.

  Location Afferents Efferents
Humeral/ Lateral Group Posteromedial to the axillary vein Whole limb except vessels accompanying cephalic veins • Central nodes
• Apical nodes 
• Inferior deep cervical nodes 
Pectoral/ Anterior group Along lateral thoracic vessels Skin and muscles of supra-umbilical anterolateral body wall and breast • Central nodes
• Apical nodes
Subscapular/ Posterior group Along the subscapular vessels Skin and muscles of the inferior posterior region of the neck, dorsal aspect of the trunk up to the iliac crest • Central nodes
• Apical nodes
Central Group Embedded in the axillary pad of fat All preceding groups • Apical group
Apical group Deep to clavipectoral fascia, along the axillary vessels Those accompanying cephalic vein Unite as the subclavian trunk; the right subclavian trunk drains into the jugular-subclavian venous junction, and the left subclavian trunk ends in the thoracic duct

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with complaints of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. She was hospitalized for pneumonia and was on antibiotic therapy with clindamycin. Sigmoidoscopy revealed multiple yellowish plaques from the rectum to the sigmoid colon; her CECT image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the CT image showing the accordion sign, is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis.

The accordion sign or concertina sign is seen in the CT abdomen of patients with pseudomembranous colitis. It refers to the thickened edematous bowel appearing similar to the folds of an accordion. This appearance is caused by the stretching of the hyperemic, enhancing mucosa over the thickened submucosal folds. This is also seen when the contrast agent is trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudomembranes of the colon.

The accordion sign is typical for pseudomembranous colitis but can be also seen in the following conditions:

  • Ischemic colitis
  • AIDS-related colitis
  • Severe edema from cirrhosis

Pseudomembranous colitis: It is usually caused by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile. It is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes C. difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of this condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). 

PMC is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers. can persist on surfaces for months. Risk factors include poor hand hygiene, old age, and gastrointestinal surgery.

The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially, which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and the detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 

Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

Other options:

Option B: In Ogilvie syndrome, also known as colonic pseudo-obstruction, a massively dilated colon without any mechanical obstruction is seen. It is a functional disorder, usually associated with narcotics, bed rest, and comorbidities.

Option C: Toxic megacolon appears as a massively dilated colon with additional loss of haustral markings with pseudopolyps on CT.

Option D: Sigmoid volvulus appears as a coffee-bean or bent inner tube sign on plain x-ray and shows the pathognomonic bird's beak sign on gastrografin enema.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A nursing mother in her third week postpartum presents with pain in her breast and difficulty breastfeeding. Examination reveals a warm, swollen, and tender breast, and is shown in the image below. Her temperature is 38.3 degrees and the WBC count is 13000/ cumm. Which of the following are not included in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of breast pain, fever, and leucocytosis with the image showing a red and swollen breast suggests a diagnosis of mastitis. Breastfeeding should not be stopped, and continued breastfeeding is advised.

Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus,  present in the infant's nose and throat. Predisposing factors to develop mastitis include fissures, abrasions, or cracks in the nipple.

Symptoms usually appear in the 3rd-4th week postpartum. The infection is usually unilateral with marked engorgement of the breast which may even progress into an abscess. There may be fever, chills, rigors, and tachycardia. Severe pain occurs and the breast becomes hard and red.

Management:

  • Breastfeeding should be continued. Often, vigorous expression of breast milk is a sufficient treatment. Pumping of the breasts relieves the engorgement and edema of the inflamed breast. The baby is encouraged to feed from the uninvolved breast first as it allows the let-down reflex to begin before moving to the tender breast.
  • Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers. Other beta-lactamase-resistant penicillins that are recommended include cloxacillin and flucloxacillin.
  • Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.
  • If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing staphylococci or if resistant organisms are suspected while awaiting the culture results, then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given.
  • If an abscess is formed, surgical drainage is done under general anesthesia.

questions.text: According to the Erlanger and Gasser classification, which type of nerve fiber carries proprioceptive signals?
questions.solution:
According to the Erlanger and Gasser classification, proprioception is carried by Aα fiber.

Erlanger and Gasser classified nerve fibers into types A, B, and C, with type A fibers further subdivided into α, β, γ, and δ fibers.

  • Type A fibers are the typical large- and medium-­sized myelinated fibers of spinal nerves.
  • Type B fibers are smaller fibers with minimal myelination. They transmit impulses of the ANS, including the bladder. (B for Bladder)
  • Type C fibers are small unmyelinated nerve fibers that conduct impulses at low velocities.

questions.text:
Match the following subgroups of undernutrition with the respective parameters.
Subgroup Parameters

1. Underweight

 a. Low weight for height
2. Stunting b. Low height for age
3. Wasting c. Low weight for age
questions.solution:
Undernutrition can be divided into three subgroups, as follows:

Subgroup Parameters

1. Underweight

 c. Low weight for age
2. Stunting b. Low height for age
3. Wasting a. Low weight for height

To define each subgroup, the respective parameter should be below minus two standard deviations (<-2SD) on the WHO Child Growth Standard for the child's age.

Stunting indicates chronic undernutrition, whereas wasting indicates acute undernutrition due to a recent food deficit or an acute illness such as diarrhea.

questions.text: The test shown in the image is used to detect the abnormality of_____________.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the Cottle test. It is used to detect abnormalities of the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. The nasal airway improves as the nasal valve opens upon performing this maneuver. This helps us in finding the site of obstruction.

The nasal valve area is the narrowest portion of the nasal passage. It is bounded medially by the nasal septum, superiorly and laterally by the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage, and inferiorly by the floor of the piriform aperture; the nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum.

Conditions with a positive Cottle test:

  • Deviated nasal septum
  • Collapsed nasal valve - causes snoring and sleep apnea
  • Valve stenosis

The following illustration shows the nasal valve and the nasal valve area:

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with vomiting and abdominal pain for 5 days. He has had similar episodes in the past. IgA-tissue transglutaminase titer is found to be elevated. Which of the following is not an extraintestinal manifestation associated with the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The boy is suffering from coeliac disease. Muscular hypertrophy is not an extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease.

On the contrary, the extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease in the paediatric age group is muscular atrophy.

Coeliac disease is an immune-mediated systemic disorder triggered by the ingestion of wheat gluten and related prolamins from rye and barley.

The intestinal symptoms are caused by the atrophy of the small bowel mucosa and malabsorption. The symptoms include diarrhea, vomiting, anorexia, weight loss, failure to thrive, rectal prolapse, and intussusception.

The extraintestinal manifestations are caused due to malnutrition and autoimmunity and they include the following:

questions.text:
What is the device shown in the image given below used for?

HDR - High dose rate
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a remote afterloader. Remote afterloading is related to brachytherapy.

Brachytherapy is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

The following isotopes are used in brachytherapy:

  • Iodine-125 and Iridium-192 are used in low-dose rate (LDR) brachytherapy. 
  • Cobalt-60 is used for high-dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy.

Afterloading is the process of placing the radioactive material into the target region. This is either done manually by the oncologist or by using remote afterloading devices.

Remote afterloading devices enable us to eliminate direct contact with radioactive sources during administration. It protects healthcare professionals from radiation exposure by securing the radiation source in a shielded, safe manner.

questions.text: What was the theme for World Health Day 2023?
questions.solution:
The theme for World Health Day 2023 was Health for all. 

World Health Day is celebrated on 7th April and each year a different theme is adopted such as:

  • 2024- My health, my right
  • 2022- Our planet, our health
  • 2021- Build a fairer, healthier world for everyone, everywhere
  • 2020 - Support nurses and midwives
  • 2018 & 2019 - Universal health coverage: everyone, everywhere
  • 2017 - Depression: Let’s talk
  • 2016 - Beat diabetes
  • 2015 - Food safety

World Health Day on April 7th raises awareness about global health issues. The 2024 theme, "My health, my right" highlights access to quality healthcare as a fundamental human right. This year's focus is on ensuring universal access to healthcare for all.

questions.text: Which of the following immunodiffusion tests represents single diffusion in one dimension?
questions.solution:
Single diffusion in one dimension is called the Oudin procedure. Immunodiffusion employs antigen-antibody precipitation in gel medium rather than liquid and has several advantages. 

  • Distint line of precipitation which is stable and can be stained seperately
  • Able to detect the number of different antigens, as individual antigens produce a distinct line of precipitation
  • Analyse the identity and non-identity between different antigens

Different types of immunodiffusion:

  • Single diffusion in one dimension - Oudin procedure
  • Double diffusion in one dimension - Oakley-Fulthorpe procedure
  • Single diffusion in two dimensions - Radial immunodiffusion/Mancini procedure : This method has been used for the estimation of the immunoglobulin classes in sera and for screening sera for antibodies to influenza viruses
  • Double diffusion in two dimensions - Ouchterlony procedure : A special variety of double diffusion in two dimensions is the Elek test for toxigenicity in diphtheria bacilli. When diphtheria bacilli are streaked at right angles to a filter paper strip carrying the antitoxin implanted on a plate of suitable medium, arrowhead-shaped lines of precipitation appear on incubation, if the bacillus is toxigenic.

The images given below show the different types of immunodiffusion.

questions.text: A female patient on oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) was prescribed phenytoin after she developed seizures. What is the main concern here?

choices.text: Phenytoin is an enzyme inducer and causes failure of OCPs.
Phenytoin is an enzyme inhibitor and causes failure of OCPs.
Phenytoin is an enzyme inducer and causes OCP toxicity.
Phenytoin is an enzyme inhibitor and causes OCP toxicity.

questions.solution:
Phenytoin is an enzyme inducer and can cause the failure of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs).

Phenytoin can induce various hepatic CYPs. OCPs are metabolized by CYP3A4. Hence, the administration of phenytoin in a patient who is on OCPs results in enhanced metabolism of OCPs. This may lead to an unplanned pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient presenting with breathing difficulties is a known case of tuberous sclerosis. Later on, the patient is diagnosed with lymphangioleiomyomatosis. This pulmonary condition has a predilection for which epidemiological parameters?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) has a predilection for non-smoker, female patients.

It is usually seen in young females with tuberous sclerosis. LAM can lead to pneumothorax or chylous effusions. 

Pulmonary function testing usually reveals an obstructive or mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern. HRCT shows thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma. 

Smoking-related ILDs:

  • DIP - Desquamative interstitial pneumonia.
  • RB-ILD - Respiratory bronchiolitis–associated ILD
  • LCH - Langerhans cell histiocytosis

Sex predilection in ILDs

Women Men
Pulmonary LAM (associated with tuberous sclerosis) Pneumoconiosis (due to occupational exposure to asbestos, beryllium, and silica)
ILDs associated with connective tissue disorder (CTD) (except ILD associated with rheumatoid arthritis) ILD associated with rheumatoid arthritis 
  Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)
  Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH)

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer is bitten by an insect whose life cycle is as portrayed below. He develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash 2 weeks later. A positive serological diagnosis for this condition is made using agglutination with antigens from which of the following species?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing characteristic eschar with lymphadenopathy and rash, along with the life cycle of a trombiculid mite (which acts as the vector), is suggestive of scrub typhus. It gives a positive Weil-Felix reaction with OX K agglutinins, which are derived from Proteus mirabilis.

Scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus, is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris strains OX19 and OX2 and Proteus mirabilis strain OXK. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some rickettsiae and some strains of Proteus.

OXK is agglutinated only in scrub typhus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia was brought to the hospital with an acute-onset neck spasm. On examination, his upper body and neck are rigid. On review of his medications, it is seen that he had been started on haloperidol 5 days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the history of recent haloperidol usage, the most probable diagnosis is acute dystonia. 

Acute dystonia usually presents within hours or days of starting treatment with antipsychotic drugs. There is a higher risk among patients between the ages of 10–19. It occurs due to acute dopamine receptor antagonism.  It presents with spasms of the head and neck muscles and the tongue. The severest form includes an oculogyric crisis with extraocular muscle involvement.

Treatment is with anticholinergics, such as benztropine, diphenhydramine, or trihexyphenidyl.

Other options:

Option A: Akathisia is an extrapyramidal syndrome characterized by a feeling of restlessness, frequent repetitive stereotyped movements, and an inability to sit still for more than a short period of time. It usually occurs during the first few months of drug use.

Option C: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: It usually occurs weeks to months after starting neuroleptic therapy. Clinical manifestations include fever, extreme muscle rigidity, stupor, dystonia, tachycardia, and unstable blood pressure. Treatment is with dantrolene or with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine. The antipsychotic drug responsible should be immediately stopped.

Option D: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by choreiform movements which are quick, repetitive, involuntary movements, along with slower twisting athetotic movements. It occurs months or years after initiation of the treatment and is more frequent in the elderly.

questions.text: What is the name of the finding in the image of a patient with dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
The name of the finding in the image of a patient with dermatomyositis is the V sign. 

Dermatomyositis is characterized by symmetrical involvement of the muscles, commonly affecting the proximal muscles more than the distal muscles. Multiple dermatological manifestations also accompany it:

  • Shawl sign (Option B)- rashes in a sun-exposed area. This is present on the back of the neck and shoulders. 
  • V sign - rashes that occur in sun-exposed areas. They are present on the anterior neck and chest 
  • Heliotrope rash (Option D) is erythema and discolouration of the eyelids with periorbital oedema.
  • Gottron's sign (Option A) is an erythematous rash on the elbows, knees, ankles, and knuckles on the extensor surfaces.
  • Gottron's papules are raised with erythematous rashes over the knuckles. 
  • Edema of face and limbs
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Vasculopathic ulcers
  • Mechanic's hands in antisynthetase syndrome
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

Other manifestations of dermatomyositis include dysphagia, interstitial lung disease, bronchopneumonia, alveolitis, and myocarditis. 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy, and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids as the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with a risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required. 

The image given below is a heliotrope rash:

The image below shows the Shawl sign. 

The image below shows Gottron's papules and Gottron's sign, respectively.

Association with other autoimmune diseases Infrequent Frequent  Infrequent
Association with malignancy Yes (breast, ovarian, lung) and ILD  Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis)  No
Immunotherapy  Responsive  Responsive  Resistant

questions.text:
What is incorrect regarding aminoglycoside-mediated nephrotoxicity?

AKI - Acute Kidney Injury

choices.text: AKI can present even after the drug is discontinued

questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides cause non-oliguric (urine volume >400 mL/day) acute kidney injury (AKI).

Aminoglycoside-mediated nephrotoxicity:

  • It causes tubular necrosis.
  • It causes non-oliguric AKI.
  • It is freely filtered across the glomerulus and accumulates within the renal cortex.
  • AKI occurs after 5–7 days of therapy, and it can present even after the drug has been discontinued. 
  • Hypomagnesemia is a common finding.

Nephrotoxic drugs include the following:

  • NSAIDs: Prerenal AKI > acute tubulointerstitial nephritis
  • Antifungals (amphotericin B): Acute tubular necrosis
  • Antibiotics
    • Aminoglycosides: Acute tubular necrosis
    • Vancomycin: AKI
    • Cephalosporins: Acute interstitial nephritis
    • Sulfonamides: Acute interstitial nephritis 
  • Antivirals
    • Acyclovir: Precipitates in tubules and causes obstruction, hence oliguric AKI
    • Foscarnet: Tubular toxicity
  • Chemotherapy drugs
    • Ifosfamide: Hemorrhagic cystitis and tubular toxicity. 
    • Platins: Necrosis and apoptosis of proximal tubular cells.
  • Immunosuppressants (cyclosporine)

questions.text: A young man has recently undergone a vasectomy. How long should this patient use additional contraceptive methods?
questions.solution:
The patient should use additional contraceptive measures for 3 months after undergoing vasectomy.

Vasectomy is a permanent sterilization procedure done in males, where a segment of the vas deferens is resected and ligated bilaterally.

This procedure is done under local anesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens is divided on both sides, disrupting the passage of sperms. The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps, and a skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15%.

It is a relatively simple procedure with low rates of complications. A patient who had a vasectomy is not sterile immediately after the procedure because semen is stored in distal channels of the vas deferens for varying periods.

It is estimated that at least 20 ejaculations or 3 months are required to empty the stored semen. 

 

Related Pearl: Failure rate of contraceptives

Type of contraception Failure rate (%)
Lactation for 6 months 0.5-1.5
Coitus interruptus 25
Diaphragm 4-6
Intrauterine devices 0-3
Progesterone only minipill 2-3
Condom 10-14
Combined Pill 0.1
Vasectomy 0.15
Tubal ligation 0.4

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman was diagnosed with melanoma. Sentinel lymph node biopsy showed malignant cells.  Which among the following is a recombinant interleukin-2 preparation approved for use in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of metastatic melanoma. The recombinant interleukin-2 (IL-2) preparation that is approved for use in metastatic melanoma is aldesleukin. It acts as an IL-2 agonist and is also approved for use in metastatic renal cell cancer.

Denileukin diftitox is an immunotoxin made from the recombinant combination of IL-2 and the catalytically active fragment of diphtheria toxin. It is approved for use in cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

Imatinib and nilotinib are a BCR/ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of burning micturition, hematuria, and flank pain. After a detailed workup, he was diagnosed with hemorrhagic cystitis caused by adenovirus. What are the serotypes of adenovirus implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus serotypes 11 and 21 cause acute hemorrhagic cystitis in children.

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis is a viral urinary tract infection. It is benign and self-limited. It more commonly affects boys than girls. It presents with cystitis and gross hematuria. Microscopic hematuria and dysuria may persist for several more days, but renal function tests show normal results. 

Adenovirus types 11 and 21 are the common serotypes associated with this disease and can be recovered from the blood and urine of patients with hemorrhagic cystitis. 

Urinary tract infections in children are most commonly caused by the following:

  • Escherichia coli (most common)
  • Klebsiella species
  • Proteus species
  • Staphylococcus saprophyticus
  • Enterococcus
  • Adenovirus and other viruses (cause cystitis and gross hematuria)

The following table shows various syndromes caused by adenoviruses and associated serotypes:

Syndrome Principle serotypes
Respiratory disease in children 1, 2, 5, 6
Sore throat, febrile cold, pneumonia 3, 4, 7, 14, 21
ARD in military recruits 4, 7, 21
Follicular (swimming pool) conjunctivitis/ Pharyngoconjunctival fever 3, 7
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (shipyard eye) 8, 19, 37
Diarrhea 40, 41

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text: A woman experiences hot flushes and sweating often and has stopped to menstruate for the last one year. She suspects that she has attained menopause. It would be considered to be a premature menopause if her age is less than_____.
questions.solution:
It would be considered to be a premature menopause if her age is less than 40 years.

Menopause is the permanent cessation of ovarian function, thereby leading to permanent amenorrhea. It usually occurs between 45–50 years, but the average age of menopause is 47 years old and is confirmed after 12 months of amenorrhea.

Clinical features of menopause:

  • Hot flushes, which are transient heat sensations occurring in the face and neck and lasting for 2–5 minutes, followed by sweating
  • Insomnia, headache
  • Dyspareunia
  • Irritability, depression, tiredness
  • Lack of concentration and lack of memory 

Menopause sets in when the follicle number falls below 1000. If this occurs before 40 years of age, it is termed premature menopause, while attaining it after 55 years is delayed menopause. 

The age at which menopause is attained is not related to age at menarche, race, the number of pregnancies, socioeconomic status, or oral contraceptive pills usage. However, it is directly influenced by smoking and genetic disposition. Perimenopause is the period 3–4 years preceding menopause and is followed by 1 year of amenorrhea.

questions.text:
In a reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction test (RT-PCR), the target RNA strand that will undergo the process is 5' - AUGCUGCAGUCAAAAAA - 3'. Outputs obtained from the process are shown below. Choose the correct statement.
  1. "A" is the DNA strand obtained after replication of cDNA
  2. "B" is the cDNA strand obtained from RNA
  3. "C" is the cDNA strand obtained from RNA
  4. "D" is the DNA strand obtained after replication of cDNA
questions.solution:
For the given RNA strand, 5' - AUGCUGCAGUCAAAAAA - 3', the obtained complementary DNA strand will be as shown in image "C" following the rules of complementary base pairing (adenine binds with thymine/uracil and cytosine binds with guanine). The DNA strand obtained by replication of the cDNA strand will contain only thymine and not uracil and is therefore represented by "A" in the image above.

RT-PCR is a method that is used for the analysis of mRNA expression and its amplification.

Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is a variant of PCR and includes 2 steps:

  • Generation of complementary DNA (cDNA copies) from mRNA using reverse transcriptase - used to qualitatively detect gene expression
  • Amplification of newly synthesized cDNA by traditional PCR - This can be quantitatively measured by using fluorescent dyes (qRT-PCR).

Uses: 

  • Determination of viral load
  • Screening of genetic diseases and cancers

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and regional lymphadenopathy, following a scratch from his pet kitten. His lymph node biopsy specimen was examined with Warthin-Starry staining; the findings are shown in the given image. What is the causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever and lymphadenopathy after a cat scratch and the above image shows the black short rod-shaped bacilli arranged in chains or clumps, suggestive of cat scratch disease, This condition is caused by Bartonella henselae.

Cat scratch disease presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch. Patients present with a painless papule or pustule at the site of the scratch and lymph node enlargement and can be suppurative. The disease is usually self resolving. However, it can be treated with azithromycin only in patients who have severe complications.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist performs laparoscopy, during which he finds the following lesions in the pelvis. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given condition is endometriosis. The laparoscopic picture shows powder-burn spots pathognomic of endometriosis. Estrogen therapy is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as it is the major risk factor for the condition.

Treatment of endometriosis:

1. Medical management:

For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow.

For moderate to severe diseases, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium, causing endometrial atrophy. The drug of choice is GnRH agonist.

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analog
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

2. Surgical management:

Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormonal treatment would delay pregnancy.

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the uterus.

Risk factors for the development of endometriosis

  • Family history
  • Nulliparity
  • Prolonged exposure to endogenous estrogen (early menarche, late menopause)
  • Estrogen therapy
  • In utero exposure to diethylstilbesterol (DES)

Key clinical features

  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Infertility
  • Pain during urination or defecation
  • Constipation or diarrhea
  • Irregular bleeding

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis has been a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Laparoscopy helps detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis, locate the site of endometriosis and staging, take a biopsy, and perform surgical ablation as a part of treatment.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels: raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels: raised in the peritoneal fluid
  • MRI
  • Color Doppler
  • Anti-endometrial antibodies

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the embryological origin of the components of the eyeball?
questions.solution:
The crystalline lens is derived from the surface ectoderm.

Other options:

Option A - Sclera: Most of the part from the neural crest + superotemporal part from the mesoderm.

Option B - Cornea: Epithelium from the surface ectoderm + stroma, keratocytes, and endothelium from the neural crest.

Option D - Iris: Epithelium from the neuroectoderm + stroma from the neural crest.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of fever, cough, and nasal discharge. He was diagnosed with infection by the influenza virus, which is an enveloped virus. Which of the following is false regarding enveloped viruses?
questions.solution:
The lipid of enveloped viruses is largely of host-cell origin, whereas protein is virus coded.

Being enveloped contributes to their lipid solvent susceptibility. This is the reason alcohol-based hand sanitizers and soaps are used. The lipid membrane dissolution and protein denaturation by ethanol lead to membrane disruption and inhibition of metabolism.

Properties of enveloped virus:

  • The envelope confers chemical, antigenic, and biological properties on the virus.
  • It is made of lipid (phospholipid) and protein (glycoprotein).
  • Lipid is largely of host cell origin, whereas glycoprotein is virus coded.
  • The lipid is acquired when the viral nucleocapsid buds through a cellular membrane during maturation. Budding occurs only at sites where virus-specific proteins have been inserted into the host cell membrane.
  • Protein subunits may be seen projecting on the surface of envelope called peplomer, e.g, hemagglutinin and neuraminidase of influenza virus.

The following are the differences between enveloped and non-enveloped viruses.

Enveloped viruses Non-enveloped viruses
Ether sensitive Ether resistant
Heat labile Heat stable
Pleomorphic Non-pleomorphic
Susceptible to bile salts Resistant to bile salts

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with fever and weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Which of the following signifies a bad prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the bone marrow histology suggest a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), where peripheral blast counts of >100,000 is a poor prognostic factor.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphomas (ALL) are neoplasms composed of immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells referred to as lymphoblasts. About 85% are B-cell ALLs which present as childhood leukemias and T-ALLs are usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement.

Clinical Features:

  • Abrupt stormy onset within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.
  • Symptoms related to depression of marrow function include anemia and fever,
  • Secondary infections due to neutropenia and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
  • Mass effects caused by neoplastic infiltration.
  • Bone pain resulting from marrow expansion and infiltration of the subperiosteum
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly
  • Testicular enlargement
  • Central nervous system manifestations such as headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies

Genetic diseases like Bloom syndrome, Fanconi anemia, and ataxia-telangiectasia predisposes to ALL.

Histopathology of ALL:

  • The marrow is hypercellular and packed with lymphoblasts. These cells replace the normal marrow.
  • Lymphoblasts have scant cytoplasm with no granulations. They are myeloperoxidase negative and contain PAS-positive cytoplasmic material.
  • The tumor cells have a basophilic cytoplasm. The nuclei of these cells are larger than the small lymphocytes. The nucleoli are usually small. The nuclear chromatin is delicate and finely stippled, and nucleoli are small and demarcated by a rim of condensed chromatin. The nuclear membrane is deeply subdivided and gives a convoluted appearance.
  • The macrophages engulfing the apoptotic tumor cells might give it a starry sky appearance as in other rapidly growing tumors.

Cytogenetics and immunophenotype:

  • Majority of the cells express TdT (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase), a specialized DNA polymerase that is expressed only in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.
  • Immature B-ALLs do not express CD10. Late pre-B-ALLs express CD10, CD19, and CD20
  • T-ALLs are positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, and CD7.
  • The more immature tumors are usually negative for CD3, CD4, and CD8, but late pre–T-cell tumors are positive for these markers.

Factors associated with a worse prognosis:

  • Age younger than 2 years
  • Presentation in adolescence or adulthood
  • Peripheral blood blast counts greater than 100,000, which probably reflects a high tumor burden.

Factors associated with good prognosis:

  • Age between 2 and 10 years
  • A low white cell count
  • Hyperdiploidy
  • Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 7, and 10
  • Presence of t(12;21)

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

  Lymphoblasts  Myeloblasts 
Blast population Homogeneous Heterogeneous, with the exception of the undifferentiated form 
Size Variable, mainly small  Variable, mainly large 
Nucleus Central, mainly round; sometimes indented. 
 		 Eccentric, round, oval, or angulated; sometimes convoluted, particularly in the form with a monocytic component 
Chromatin Fine, with dispersed condensation. 
Very condensed in small lymphoblasts 		 Fine, granular, delicately dispersed 
Nucleoli Absent in small lymphoblasts. 
Sometimes indistinct 		 Present. Often large and prominent, double or triple 
Cytoplasm Scanty and basophilic.
Sometimes with a single long projection (hand-mirror cell) 		 Variable. 
Abundant in monoblasts, 
with protrusions in erythroblasts and megakaryoblasts 
Granules Rarely present. Negative for peroxidase, esterases, and toluidine blue  Present in forms with differentiation and positive with cytochemical stains
  • Peroxidase in the neutrophil and eosinophil lineages
  • Nonspecific esterase in the monocyte lineage 
Auer rods Absent  Can be present. 
Typically present in the hyper granular promyelocytic form 
Vacuoles Can be present Can be present. 
Almost always present in forms with a monocytic component 

The image given below shows lymphoblasts.

The image given below shows myeloblasts.

Age younger than 2 years 

Presentation in adolescence or adulthood

Female  Male 
Hyperdiploidy  Hypodiploidy

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presented with severely pruritic, large, tense, multiple blisters on the trunk and flexor surfaces. Histopathology shows subepidermal blisters with eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence reveals IgG deposits as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is wrong about this disease?

choices.text: The main target antigen is BP180.
There is an association with psoriasis.
Nikolsky's sign is positive in this disease.
Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the direct immunofluorescence image are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. Nikolsky's sign is negative in bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous pemphigoid is one of the most common subepidermal immunobullous disorders. It is mostly a disease of the elderly. It is characterized by a subepidermal split, with tissue-bound and serum IgG antibodies against BP180 and BP230 antigens.

Bullous pemphigoid is associated with psoriasis and treatments of psoriasis, like phototherapy and psoralen. It is also precipitated by triggers like trauma, burns, skin grafting, and drugs like furosemide.

Clinical features:

  • Prodromal phase:
    • Excoriated papules, eczematous or urticarial skin lesions, and hemorrhagic crusts may be seen.
  • Bullous phase:
    • Intense pruritus is almost constantly present.
    • Symmetrically distributed tense bullae and vesicles are seen over the flexural aspects and abdomen of the body.
    • Partly hemorrhagic crusts and erythematous plaques with an annular pattern are seen.
    • Lesions heal without scarring, provided there are no superinfections.
    • The bullae contain clear, sometimes hemorrhagic, exudates.
    • Nikolsky's sign is negative.
    • Oral or mucosal lesions and milia formation are rare.

The image given below shows the lesions seen in bullous pemphigoid.

 

Histopathology shows the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils. Immunofluorescent microscopy shows the presence of subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction.

The below image shows linear IgG deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction seen in bullous pemphigoid.

 

Untreated bullous pemphigoid has a chronic, self-limiting course, with remissions and relapses. Complete remissions are possible with treatment.

Bullous pemphigoid is mainly treated with topical and systemic corticosteroids. Other drugs like azathioprine, dapsone, doxycycline, and immunomodulators are also used.

Related Pearl: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

  Pemphigus vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid
Age 30-40 years 70-80 years
Antibody Anti-desmoglein Anti-hemidesmosome
Location of target antigens Intraepidermal Subepidermal
Immuno-fluorescence Fish-net pattern Linear, shoreline pattern
Bullae Thin and fragile Deep and tense
Mouth involved Yes No
Nikolsky’s sign Positive Negative
Symptom Painful Pruritic
Severity Life threatening Resolves

questions.text: A child presents with features of parkinsonism and spasticity. His MRI brain is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the MRI image showing the eye of the tiger sign, is suggestive of the Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome.

The eye of the tiger sign refers to an abnormal, low T2 signal intensity on MRI (due to abnormal accumulation of iron) in the globus pallidus, with a longitudinal stripe of high signal intensity (due to gliosis and spongiosis).

Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome, or pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN), is an autosomal recessive disorder. It causes involuntary spasticity and progressive dementia, along with parkinsonism and dystonia starting from childhood itself. It is a subset of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (NBIA). 

The image below shows an MRI depicting the eye of a tiger sign.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be continued on the day of surgery?
questions.solution:
Oral hypoglycemic agents are generally withheld on the day of surgery except for minor, short procedures.

SGLT-2 inhibitors are stopped 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high-risk surgeries.

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior 

Related Pearl: Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

  1. Antihypertensive medications (Exceptions are ACE Inhibitors and ARB) 
  2. Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  3. Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  4. Thyroid medications
  5. Eye drops
  6. Heartburn or reflux medications
  7. Narcotic medications
  8. Anticonvulsants
  9. Asthma medications
  10. Steroids (oral and inhaled)
  11. Statins
  12. Levodopa
  13. Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors are continued when:(1) Anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures (2) Possibility of exacerbation or precipitation of depressive syndrome.

questions.text: You are a resident assisting a vaginal delivery. Because the baby goes into distress, the second stage of labor is shortened with the use of the instrument shown below. Where will you place the cup of the instrument?

choices.text: On the mother's abdomen, within a 2-cm radius of the umbilicus
On a point 3 cm from the anterior fontanelle and 6 cm from posterior fontanelle of the fetal head
At the extension point on the fetal head
On the sagittal suture on the fetal head

questions.solution:
The given image shows a vacuum delivery system, and during vaccum-assisted delivery, the suction cup is placed on the fetal scalp on the sagittal suture.

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp.

The instrument consists of the following components:

  • Suction cup
  • Vacuum generator
  • Traction tubing device

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput, called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel.

Once the cup is placed over the flexion point, the ventouse extraction is started by creating a vacuum pressure of 0.2 kg/cm2. This takes about 2 minutes. The pressure is then gradually increased up to an effective vacuum pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 at the rate of 0.1 kg/cm2 per minute; traction is then applied.

Traction:

  • Traction is applied at a right angle to the cup and should be synchronous to the uterine contractions.
  • Between the uterine contractions, the traction is released.
  • Traction is made using one hand along the axis of the birth canal, while the fingers of the other hand are placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation, and advancement of the head.

Traction should be abandoned if

  • There is no decent of the presenting part with each pull
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed more than 30 minutes. Once the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve and the cup is then detached.

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with ischemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden, severe, generalized abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 92/58 mm Hg. The abdomen appears soft, and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia. For an acute arterial occlusive disease, the gold standard for diagnosis is angiography and that for management is laparotomy.

An embolus is the most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia. Risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are as follows:

  • Presence of an irregularly irregular pulse is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. 
  • Previous history of ischemic heart disease

The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated symptoms can include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. With the onset of bowel infarction, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools occur.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of an acute arterial occlusive disease is angiography and that for management is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

Note:

A pulsatile abdominal mass is seen in the case of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Acute pain and hypotension occur with rupture of the aneurysm, which requires an emergency operation.

Acute severe pancreatitis and peptic ulcer perforation have no association with atrial fibrillation. They usually present with pain over the upper abdomen, associated with guarding and rigidity on examination.

questions.text: Which female genital cancer is associated with metabolic disturbances like diabetes, obesity, and hypertension?
questions.solution:
Endometrial cancer has been found to be associated with metabolic disturbances like diabetes, obesity, and hypertension, also known as corpus cancer syndrome.

Endometrial carcinoma is the most common invasive cancer of the female genital tract. Type 1 endometrial carcinoma shows endometrioid morphology and is associated with the following:

  • Unopposed estrogen exposure (endometrial hyperplasia)
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension

The tumor-suppressor gene PTEN is mutated in approximately 20% of endometrial hyperplasias.

Genomic sequencing of endometrial carcinoma has revealed 4 major molecular subtypes of endometrioid and serous carcinomas:

  • Ultramutated/POLE tumors - mutations in DNA polymerase ε (POLE)
  • Hypermutated/MSI (microsatellite instability) tumors - mutations involving mismatch repair genes
  • Copy number low/MSS (microsatellite stable) tumors - mutations involving the PI3K/AKT pathway
  • Copy number high/serous-like tumors - TP53 mutations and numerous genomic copy number variants

Related Pearl: Types of endometrial carcinoma

Characteristics Type 1 Type 2
Age 55–65 yr 65–75 yr
Clinical setting Unopposed estrogen
Obesity
Hypertension
Diabetes		 Atrophy
Thin physique
Morphology Endometrioid Serous
Clear Cell
Mixed mullerian tumor
Precursor Atypical hyperplasia Serous endometrial
intraepithelial carcinoma

Mutated genes/genetic 

abnormalities

 PTEN
ARID1A (regulator of chromatin)
PIK3CA (PI3K)
KRAS
FGF2 (growth factor)
MSI

TP53		 TP53
