questions.text: In which of the following time periods during the course of a disease would it be beneficial to administer a screening test to a patient?
questions.solution:
The time difference between the first possible point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis is called screening time, which is represented by the time interval 1 to 2 in the given image. It is during this time period in course of the disease, it would be beneficial to administer a screening test to a patient.

Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

The usual time of diagnosis (point 3): The onset of symptoms is followed by a short interval (varies from disease to disease) after which the patient presents to a healthcare setup, where a diagnosis of the disease is made. Based on treatment and prognosis, the patient can progress to either recovery, disability, or death. 

In the image, the period between the first possible point of diagnosis and the usual time of diagnosis is called lead time and is represented by the time period between points 1 and 3 in the image. Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Natural history of disease: It refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment.

Exposure: The disease process begins with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host. For example in infectious disease, the exposure is a microorganism. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibers or components in tobacco smoke.

Pathological changes: After the disease process has been triggered, pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it. This stage of subclinical disease, extending from the time of exposure to the onset of symptoms, is usually called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases. During this stage, the disease remains asymptomatic.

The onset of clinical symptoms: It is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.

The below diagram shows the natural history of disease in an individual over time.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: You are a first-year student who has been asked to identify the hybrid muscle during dissection of the lower limb. When you point towards biceps femoris, you are asked a nerve supply of this muscle. Your answer would be ____

choices.text: Tibial part of sciatic nerve, Common fibular nerve
Anterior division of obturator nerve, Tibial part of sciatic nerve
Posterior division of obturator nerve, Femoral nerve

questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option A: Tibial part of sciatic nerve, Common fibular nerve. 

Muscles supplied by two different motor nerves with different root values are called hybrid or composite muscles.

Hybrid muscles:

  • Pectineus: Supplied by femoral nerve and anterior division of obturator nerve. 
  • Adductor Magnus: Supplied by the obturator nerve and tibial part of the sciatic nerve
  • Flexor digitorum profundus: Supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve and the ulnar nerve
  • Pectoralis major: Supplied by the medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Flexor pollicis brevis: Supplied by the recurrent motor branch of median nerve and the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Brachialis: Supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve and the radial nerve
  • Biceps femoris: The long head is supplied by the tibial part of the sciatic nerve, and the short head by the common fibular nerve
  • Digastric: The anterior belly is supplied by the mylohyoid branch of the inferior alveolar nerve and the posterior belly is supplied by the facial nerve

questions.text: A patient is posted for esophagectomy for the presence of esophageal carcinoma in the middle third of the esophagus. During the operation, the surgeon performs laparotomy and constructs a gastric tube. After this, he performs a right thoracotomy and removes the tumor. He then anastomoses the remaining part of the esophagus with the stomach in the upper part of the thorax. What is the type of esophagectomy done by the surgeon?
questions.solution:
The resection of a tumor in the middle third of the esophagus by laparotomy and right thoracotomy is called the Ivor Lewis approach. 

In the Ivor Lewis approach, partial esophagectomy and esophagogastric anastomosis are done in the thorax. 

Other approaches in esophagectomy:

  • Orringer approach (option B) is used for tumors in the lower part of the esophagus. The stomach is mobilized through a midline abdominal incision or by laparotomy, and the tumor is removed. The cervical esophagus is mobilized through an incision in the neck, and anastomosis of the remaining part of the esophagus and the stomach is performed. This is a palliative procedure. 
  • McKeown approach (option C) is used for the tumors in the upper part of the esophagus. In this technique, the surgeon performs laparotomy and thoracotomy to remove the tumor. A right-side neck approach is done for the anastomosis between the pharynx and stomach. 

McEvedy approach (option A) is used in the repair of the femoral hernia. The surgeon reaches the site of the hernia via a horizontal incision in the lower part of the abdomen, centered at the lateral edge of the rectus muscle.

Related Pearl: Replacement conduits after esophagectomy

  • Best conduit after esophagectomy – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after carcinoma esophagus resection – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after benign disorders – Colon
  • Best conduit of choice after short segment replacement – Jejunum
  • Gastric conduit is based on right gastric and gastroepiploic arteries
  • Left colon conduit is based on left colic artery
  • The posterior mediastinal route is preferred for placement of conduit as it is the shortest route.

questions.text: While undergoing a surgical procedure under halothane anesthesia, a patient suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Following prompt measures, the patient recovers. Considering this history, which of the following anesthetic agents should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing hyperthermia and muscle rigidity while undergoing a procedure under halothane anesthesia is suggestive of an episode of malignant hyperthermia. Desflurane should be avoided in malignant hyperthermia.

Inhaled anesthetics, such as halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, ether, and methoxyflurane, and depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as succinylcholine, are known to trigger malignant hyperthermia; hence, these drugs should be avoided in a patient with prior history of malignant hyperthermia.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in the skeletal muscle, resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2. Susceptible patients are those with a positive family history (inherited as an autosomal dominant trait) and those with congenital myopathies.

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for the management of malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive treatment with rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia should be given.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl child is scheduled for a tonsillectomy. Prior to endotracheal intubation, she is given IV propofol, followed by an agent, labeled "A" in the image shown below. The procedure is completed as planned, and the anesthetist now administers a new drug, labeled "B" in the image to reverse its effect. The effect of "B" is specific to "A". Identify A and B, respectively.

TOF - Train of four
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a non-depolarizing agent, rocuronium (labeled "A" in the image), is used for anesthesia induction prior to endotracheal intubation. Following the surgical procedure, a newer drug ("B" in the image), sugammadex, is used to reverse its action.

The graph shows the train-of-four (TOF) monitoring to assess the neuromuscular block in an anesthetized patient. The fade in the graph indicates a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent, which is reversed by sugammadex. 

TOF fade is a pattern of nerve stimulation used to monitor neuromuscular blockade and is related to the degree of neuromuscular block.

Sugammadex is a modified gamma-cyclodextrin that binds rocuronium and vecuronium tightly and decreases the concentration of free plasma levels. It has no effect on succinylcholine and benzylisoquinoline neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs), such as atracurium. 

It exerts its reversal effect by forming tight complexes in a 1:1 ratio with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium > vecuronium). Since rocuronium is a steroidal agent, it is specifically bound by sugammadex.

Rocuronium is commonly used to provide muscle relaxation during routine intubation in pediatric patients because it has a rapid onset and can be administered intramuscularly.

Neostigmine can be used to reverse the neuromuscular block caused by succinylcholine when there is a phase II block.

The illustration below shows variations of train-of-four fade patterns of various muscle relaxants.

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with a history of injury to the eye caused while climbing a tree 5 days ago; the injury has caused pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. Slit-lamp examination reveals a lesion as shown below. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image of an ulcer with irregular feathery margins are suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. Satellite lesions are a feature of fungal ulcers.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. Signs are more pronounced than symptoms. The corneal ulcer appears dry.

Causative organisms:

  • Aspergillus
  • Fusarium
  • Candida albicans

Signs of a fungal ulcer:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley ring) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, and immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs: These include topical natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops, which are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium. Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Severe ulcers with hypopyon, perforation, or suspected endophthalmitis might warrant the use of oral antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole.

Other options :

Option A: Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber. Here, emulsified silicone bubbles are coalesced and seen in the upper part of the anterior chamber (AC). 

Option B: Dendritic ulcer is seen in epithelial keratitis caused by the herpes simplex virus. An image of a dendritic ulcer with fluorescein dye is shown below.

Option C: Ring abscess is seen in helminthic keratitis, especially that caused by Acanthamoeba. Gradual enlargement and coalescence of infiltrates occur, leading to the formation of an abscess.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A patient with lepromatous leprosy presents with eye pain. The image of his eye is given below. Identify the finding marked by the arrow:
questions.solution:
The finding marked by the arrow in the image of the eye of a patient with lepromatous leprosy is the iris pearl, which is a pathognomonic finding of leprosy.

Leprosy or Hansen disease is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium leprae. Ocular features in leprosy occur due to bacterial invasion. They include the following:

  • Keratitis with thickened, beaded corneal nerves, punctate subepithelial lesions, pannus, and vascularization
  • Chronic low-grade anterior uveitis
  • Miosis
  • Iris atrophy
  • Iris pearls 
  • Retinal pearls
  • Other features are scleritis, episcleritis, cataracts, diminished corneal sensation, etc. 

Other options:

Option A: Brushfield spots refer to small white speckles on the peripheral iris that are arranged in a concentric ring. They are seen in Down’s syndrome and may sometimes be a normal finding in blue eyes. The image below shows Brushfield spots.

Option C: Lisch nodules are small well-defined nodules that are seen in neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface.

Option D: Busacca nodules are present on the iris stroma. They are seen in granulomatous uveitis.

The image below shows Koeppe nodules. These are present at the pupillary border and are seen in anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A patient presented with a heavy fall on his outstretched hands. He was diagnosed with Essex-Lopresti fracture. Which of the following is not a component of this type of lesion?

choices.text: Fracture of the head of radius

questions.solution:
Fracture of the radial head is sometimes accompanied by the disruption of the interosseous membrane and dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint called as the Essex-Lopresti lesion. Fracture of the radial styloid is not a component of this lesion.

Mechanism:

  • Occurs in those who have fallen from a height

X-ray:

  • Lateral view of the pronated wrist
  • To avoid missing this lesion, forearm and wrist X-ray should be taken in all cases of fracture of the head of radius.

Treatment :

  • A combination of radial head replacement and an ulnar shortening osteotomy improves symptoms.
  • Radioulnar fusion: only salvage procedure

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text:
Match the following columns regarding various hemolytic anemias.
Hemolytic anemia-Type Example
1. Inherited, intracorpuscular  a. Sickle cell anemia
2. Inherited, extracorpuscular b. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
3. Acquired, intracorpuscular c. Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome
4. Acquired, extracorpuscular d. Drug-induced hemolysis
questions.solution:
The correct anwer is Option B-1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d.

Hemolytic anemia-Type Example
1. Inherited, intracorpuscular   Sickle cell anemia
2. Inherited, extracorpuscular  Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome
3. Acquired, intracorpuscular  Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
4. Acquired, extracorpuscular  Drug-induced hemolysis

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A patient underwent a trabeculectomy, following which he developed a headache. Examination revealed that the anterior chamber was flat, the Seidel test result was negative, and the intraocular pressure was raised. He was given 1% atropine, which improved his condition. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on clinical features is malignant glaucoma.

Malignant glaucoma is seen after intraocular surgery such as trabeculectomy. The forward flow of aqueous is blocked as the tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against the lens/IOL/anterior hyaloid of the vitreous. Hence, aqueous humor collects in the vitreous cavity.

Clinical features:

  • Persistent shallow or flat anterior chamber
  • Negative Seidel’s test result
  • Raised intra-ocular pressure

Treatment

  • Atropine:
    • Malignant glaucoma is also called inverse glaucoma since atropine is used.
    • It dilates the ciliary ring and increases the distance between the ciliary processes and the equator of the lens, thereby tightening the zonule and pulling the lens posteriorly into its normal position.
  • Intravenous mannitol may be used if mydriatics are ineffective, in order to shrink the vitreous gel and allow the lens to move posteriorly.
  • Nd:YAG laser hyaloidotomy - making an opening in the anterior hyaloid membrane
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

Other options:

Option A: Posner–Schlossman syndrome is characterized by recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised intraocular pressure associated with mild anterior uveitis. It presents with mild discomfort, haloes, and blurring of vision.

Option B: Pseudoexfoliation glaucoma is rapidly progressive and can lead to significant visual loss. It is an ocular manifestation of a systemic condition in which pseudoexfoliative material is deposited on structures like the lens capsule, zonular fibers, iris, trabeculae, and conjunctiva.

Option C: Phacolytic glaucoma is a secondary open-angle glaucoma associated with a hypermature cataract. Patients present with pain and poor vision. Slit-lamp examination shows corneal edema, hypermature cataract, and deep anterior chamber. Large, floating, white particles consisting of lens protein and protein-containing macrophages may be seen in the anterior chamber.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 42 weeks 1 day of gestation is still not having labor pains. What color is the amniotic fluid likely to be in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a post-term pregnancy (>42 weeks). The amniotic fluid color in this patient is likely to be greenish-yellow.

ACOG defines post-term pregnancy as a pregnancy continuing beyond 42 completed weeks of gestation. For clinical purposes, a pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery (>294 days) is called a post-term pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Usually, the amniotic fluid appears colorless in early pregnancy

Option C: In Rh-negative pregnancy, amniotic fluid is golden yellow.

Option D: In intrauterine death (absent fetal movements and FHS absent on doppler), a tobacco juice amniotic fluid is seen.

 

Related Pearl: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought for evaluation of repeated lung infections. The bronchial fluid samples show gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria that produce a bluish-green pigment. He also has been experiencing foul-smelling diarrhea with pale, floating stools. What is the mode of inheritance of the condition that the child is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Repeated lung infections and steatorrhea (foul-smelling diarrhea with pale, floating stools) suggest a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria that produce a blue-green pigment indicate infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is commonly seen in this condition. 

Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7 (7q31.2). It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, and reproductive tract. 

  • Lungs - Abnormal CFTR leads to sticky viscous mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance leading to obstruction and recurrent respiratory infections. 
  • Pancreas - The viscous secretions block the pancreatic ducts impairing the flow of digestive enzymes. This leads to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, causing fat malabsorption and the resultant steatorrhea. 
  • Reproductive tract - More than 95% of men are infertile, with absent vas deferens. Women have tenacious cervical mucus but are not always infertile. 

The sweat chloride test is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Sweat ducts with normal CFTR reabsorb the chloride from the primary sweat secretion. Mutated CFTR reduces this uptake, increasing chloride levels in sweat. A sweat chloride level of >60 mmol/L is diagnostic.

Other pathogens commonly causing infections in cystic fibrosis include Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Burkholderia cepacia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has had a history of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain since 3 years of age. She has pallor, and her weight and height are below the 3rd percentile. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to make a specific diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A small intestinal biopsy can help diagnose documented steatorrhea or chronic diarrhea (>3 weeks). Failure to thrive in the setting of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain suggests a diagnosis of chronic malabsorption.

Endoscopy is the preferred method of obtaining histologic material from the proximal small-intestinal mucosa.

The other options are not specific tests used to confirm malabsorption syndromes.

Lesions seen on small-bowel biopsy can be classified into three categories according to their distribution and specificity of findings; diseases in which these lessons are seen and the associated pathologic findings are given below:

Lesions Pathologic Findings
Diffuse, Specific 
Whipple disease Lamina propria includes macrophages containing material positive on periodic acid–Schiff staining
Patchy, Specific

Diffuse, Nonspecific 
Celiac disease Short or absent vill, mononuclear infiltrate, epithelial cell damage,  hypertrophy of crypts
Folate deficiency Short villi, decreased mitosis in crypts, megalocytosis
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome   Mucosal ulceration and erosion from acid

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with breathlessness, chest pain, and syncopal attacks on and off for 3 months. Echocardiography showed an abnormality of the cardiac valve. Identify the valvular lesion and the associated murmur from the below image that depicts the heart sounds and murmur of the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a systolic murmur (occurring in the interval between S1 and S2) are suggestive of aortic stenosis and the associated systolic murmur. 

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It is caused by rheumatic heart disease or by the calcification of the normal aortic valve or a congenital bicuspid valve. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decrease in stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (pulsus parvus), which slowly rises and has a delayed peak (pulsus tardus)—a pattern best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

The clinical features of aortic stenosis are exertional dyspnea due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction, angina pectoris due to the combination of the increased oxygen demand and reduced supply, syncope due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation, which lead to a reduction in cerebral perfusion.

An ejection mid-systolic murmur can be auscultated in aortic stenosis. It begins after the first heart sound (S1), increases in intensity toward the middle of the ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is low-pitched, rough, and rasping in character. It is best heard at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.

A systolic ejection click can be heard in young patients with a bicuspid aortic valve, but disappears as the valves become calcified. A2 and P2 may be heard at the same time, or A2 may follow P2, resulting in the paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound (S2). The fourth heart sound (S4) is often heard at the apex, indicating the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

Other options:

In mitral stenosis, a diastolic murmur can be heard during auscultation.

Other murmurs: 

  • Pansystolic murmur of functional tricuspid regurgitation:
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Louder during inspiration and reduces during forced expiration (Carvallo sign)
  • Graham Steell murmur of pulmonary regurgitation:
    • High-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo-blowing murmur
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension

A pansystolic murmur of at least grade III/VI intensity can be auscultated in chronic severe mitral regurgitation. It is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Ruptured chordae tendineae may produce a murmur with a cooing or “seagull” quality, whereas a flail leaflet may produce a murmur with a musical quality. 

S1 is generally absent or soft. Wide splitting of S2 may occur due to the premature closure of the aortic valve. A low-pitched, third heart sound (S3) may occur following A2. S4 can also be audible in patients with acute severe MR.

An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic aortic regurgitation. It is high-pitched and blowing in character. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. It may be accompanied by a mid-systolic ejection murmur in isolated AR or the Austin Flint murmur in severe AR. The latter is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling, mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream.

A2 is usually absent, and occasionally, S4 also may be heard.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

 

Related Pearl: The causes of holosystolic murmur are:

  1. Mitral regurgitation

  • Best heard at the apex
  • Radiates to axilla or base
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • A2 is not heard at the apex

  2. Tricuspid regurgitation

  • Best heard at lower left sternal border
  • Radiates to the epigastrium and right sternal border
  • Increases in intensity during inspiration
  • Prominent c-v waves seen in JVP

  3. Ventricular septal defect

  • Beat heard over left 3rd and 4th intercostal space
  • Radiates widely
  • Palpable thrill present
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • Wide splitting of S2 seen

questions.text: You notice the following equipment in the principal biomedical waste handling facility. This equipment is used for the treatment of all the following, except ____

choices.text: Waste sharps such as needles and syringes

questions.solution:
The given image shows an incinerator. Incineration is used for the treatment of all the listed wastes, except waste sharps such as needles and syringes.

In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. 

Waste sharps such as needles and syringes are sterilized by autoclaving, followed by shredding, mutilation, or encapsulation in a metal container or cement concrete. They are then sent for final disposal to iron foundries.

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants. The image given below shows an autoclave:

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student came to OPD with intermittent episodes of the feeling of impending doom, accompanied by intense perspiration. Usually, the episodes occur prior to her exams. Which of the following agents has the most rapid onset of action against her condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is panic disorder. Benzodiazepines have the most rapid onset of action in panic, with the onset happening often within the first week.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort. Recurrent panic attacks for more than one month are classified as panic disorder. Panic attacks can occur in mental disorders other than panic disorder, particu­larly in specific phobia, social phobia, and post-traumatic stress disorder.

Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam and lorazepam have been widely used for panic disorder. They are often used as a first agent while the serotonergic drug is up-titrated to therapeutic levels. Benzodiazepines are preferred for short-term therapy as long-term use can often lead to dependence and abuse.

Clinically, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and clomipramine are preferred over benzodiazepines, monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), and tricyclic and tetracyclic drugs in terms of effectiveness, long-term therapy, and tolerance of adverse effects. 

Related Pearl: Panic disorder

DSM-5 criteria for panic disorder:

1.Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:

  • Palpitation
  • Sweating
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Shortness of breath of smothering sensation
  • Choking sensation
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Nausea or abdominal distress
  • Dizziness, light-headedness
  • Chills or heat sensation
  • Paraesthesia’s
  • Derealisation or depersonalisation
  • Fear of losing control or “going crazy”
  • Fear of dying  

 2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

  • Immediate: benzodiazepines 
  • Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy

 

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient who is a chronic smoker with uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes mellitus, not on medication, was planned to undergo elective appendicectomy. He was brought for a pre-anesthetic checkup. In which ASA-PS class would you place this patient?

ASA-PS: American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status
questions.solution:
A patient who is a chronic smoker with uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes mellitus is placed under ASA-PS class III.

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification system was developed to assess and communicate a patient's pre-anesthesia medical comorbidities.

Perioperative risks cannot be predicted with this classification system alone, but when used with other factors (eg: type of surgery, level of deconditioning), it can help to predict perioperative risks.

This system assigns patients into 6 classes—class I to class VI. An additional class E denotes an emergency surgical procedure.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman visits a PHC where she is prescribed a contraceptive known as Chhaya. What is the mechanism of action of this contraceptive?

PHC- Primary health center

choices.text: Prevents ovulation by preventing LH surge
Spermicidal action on the uterine cavity
Prevents fertilization by decreasing sperm motility

questions.solution:
The contraceptive pill that the woman has is Chhaya, which contains 30 mg of centchroman. Centchroman is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive that does not prevent ovulation, but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.

It is started on the first day of menses and is taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter.

To begin the use of Chhaya, the woman is advised to take the first pill on the first day of the period and the second pill three days later. This pattern of days is repeated throughout the first 3 months. From the fourth month, the pill is to be taken once a week on the first pill day and should be continued on the weekly schedule, regardless of her menstrual cycle.

Effects:

  • It does not prevent ovulation but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.
  • It exhibits a strong antiestrogenic and a weak estrogenic action peripherally at the receptor level.
  • The return of fertility occurs soon after the stoppage of the drug (within 6 months).

Centchroman is not teratogenic or carcinogenic and exerts no pharmacological effect on other organs. The drug can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in 60 mg dose within 24 h of coitus (two tablets repeated 12 h later, with a failure rate of 1%). 

Side effects include weight gain and delay in the return of fertility for up to 6 months. Long-term use can cause hyperplasia and atypical endometrium. It does not protect against HIV and sexually transmitted diseases.

Contraindications include PCOD, hepatic dysfunction, cervical dysplasia, and allergy to the drug.

Saheli has been renamed as Chhaya and is now available in two packages: ASHA supply (for home distribution) and free supply (for distribution at health facilities).

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. What is the correlation between the drug isoniazid and the enzyme coded by the KatG gene?

choices.text: Isoniazid is activated by the enzyme
Isoniazid is inhibited by the enzyme

questions.solution:
Isoniazid is activated by the enzyme coded by the KatG gene.

Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid.

Isoniazid is a first-line bactericidal drug that is used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This drug enters bacilli by passive diffusion. It is then activated to its toxic form by the enzyme catalase-peroxidase (the enzyme encoded by the KatG gene).

Normally, InhA and KasA are involved in the synthesis of mycolic acid. Upon activation, the reactive metabolite of isoniazid forms complexes with NAD that inhibit InhA and KasA. Hence, isoniazid inhibits the production of mycolic acid.

The reactive isoniazid metabolite also forms complexes with NADP. This complex inhibits mycobacterial dihydrofolate reductase which results in the interruption of DNA synthesis.

Side effects of isoniazid:

  • Peripheral neuritis due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.
  • Hepatitis: Isoniazid must be stopped at the first sign of hepatotoxicity.
  • Rashes
  • Anemia
  • Arthralgia

Toxicity of isoniazid results in metabolic acidosis and seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following findings suggests that the baby was live-born in a case of infanticide?

choices.text: Gelatinous tissue in the middle ear
Weight of lung 1/35th of body weight

questions.solution:
The baby will be considered live-born if the weight of the lung is 1/35th of the body weight.

Autopsy findings to differentiate before and after respiration:

Autopsy findings Before respiration After respiration
1. Shape of chest Flat; chest circumference is 1–2 cm less than the abdominal circumference Dome or arch-shaped
2. Position of the diaphragm At or above the 4th/5th rib At or below the 6th/7th rib
3. Lung margins Sharp Rounded
4. Lung consistency Dense, firm, non-crepitant Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant
5. Lung weight 1/70th of body weight 1/35th of body weight
6. Lung color Uniformly reddish-brown or bluish-red Mottled or marbled appearance
7. Hydrostatic test Specific gravity is 1040–1050 Specific gravity is 940
8. Stomach Contains only mucin and sinks in water Contains mucin and air and floats in water
9. Middle ear Contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue Air replaces the embryonic tissue

 

Other tests for live birth:

  • Breslau’s first life test (also known as Hydrostatic test/Raygat’s test) - The organ tested is the lung. It is based on the ability of the lung to sink or float in water.
  • Breslau's second life test: It is based on the air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water to check if they float or sink.
  • Wreden’s test – This test is based on changes in the middle ear after birth
  • Fodere’s test – This test is based on the increase in the weight of the lungs due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of the unrespired lung is 30–40 g, whereas the weight of respired lung is 60–66 g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – This is based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs - 1/70
    • Respired lungs - 1/35

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: The dose-response curves of four different drugs are shown here. Which of the following drugs is the most potent?
questions.solution:
Drug 2 is the most potent among the other given drugs.

The potency and efficacy of a drug are represented by the dose-response curve.

The potency of the drug is defined as the concentration of the drug which produces half of the maximal effect. The drug which produces half of the maximum effect in the least concentration is said to be more potent. The more the curve is towards the left, the more the potency.

Efficacy is the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. If the response is more, the drug is said to be more efficacious. Drug 4 is most efficacious.

questions.text: The partner of a patient with herpetic genital ulcers comes to the clinic for a consultation. She is asymptomatic. As per the syndromic approach to sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and reproductive tract infections (RTIs), how will you treat this case?
questions.solution:
As per the syndromic approach to STIs/ RTIs, routine treatment is not given to asymptomatic partners of patients with herpetic genital ulcers.

Asymptomatic partners of patients with genital herpes should be asked about a history of genital symptoms and offered serologic testing for HSV-2. There is no evidence that treatment with antiviral drugs would be of any benefit. Hence, no treatment is routinely given.

Symptomatic partners should be evaluated and treated for genital herpes.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers
