Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient approached a radiologist for a screening breast examination during breast cancer awareness month. Which of the following best represents the difference in the  X-ray tube used in this procedure from that of a conventional X-ray machine?

choices.text: Beryllium exit window and molybdenum filter
Glass exit window and aluminium filter
Beryllium exit window and aluminium filter
Glass exit window and molybdenum filter

questions.solution:
The screening procedure for breast cancer is mammography. The x-ray tube used in mammography differs from that of a conventional x-ray machine in that it has a beryllium exit window and molybdenum filter.

Differences between mammography and conventional radiography:

  • Mammography involves the use of low-energy and high-amperage waves.
  • The target anode is made of a tungsten disc in conventional x-ray tubes and molybdenum in mammography x-ray tubes.
  • Most mammography tubes use beryllium exit windows between the evacuated tube and the atmosphere.
  • The conventional X-ray tube has an aluminum filter, but in mammography, a molybdenum filter is used.

Some indications for mammography:

  • Evaluation of breast signs and symptoms like masses, skin changes, deformities, nipple retraction, discharge, and eczema
  • Breast cancer screening
  • Follow-up for patients treated for breast cancer
  • Localization of lesions not visible on ultrasound

The two standard mammographic projections are the mediolateral oblique view and the craniocaudal view.

Note: Breast cancer awareness month is an annual international health campaign organized by major breast cancer charities every year in the month of October.

Related Pearl: Difference between Normal Radiography and Mammography

  Radiography Mammography
Type of X rays Bremsstrahlung reaction Characteristic radiation
Target Tungsten Molybdenum
Exit Window Glass Beryllium
Filter Aluminum Molybdenum

questions.text: Fincham’s test was done for a patient presenting with blurred vision and colored halos that did not disappear on irrigation. The halos were broken up when the stenopaeic slit was moved. What is the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
In Fincham's test, the breaking up of halos when the stenopaeic slit is moved indicates that the halos are due to a lenticular cause such as a cataract. 

Colored halos can be seen as rainbow-colored rings around lights at night. They occur as a result of the prismatic dispersion of light caused by various conditions such as: 

  • Cataract
  • Acute angle-closure glaucoma
  • Mucopurulent conjunctivitis
  • Corneal edema

Fincham's test distinguishes between the colored halos caused by cataracts and glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaeic slit before the eyes across the line of vision and noting the changes observed in the halos. A lenticular halo, such as one due to a cataract, breaks up into fragments, similar to the wings of a fan, and moves together. A glaucomatous halo, however, remains intact but diminishes in intensity.

Other options:
Option B - Angle-closure glaucoma/glaucomatous halos involve the history of colored halos along with periodic blurring of vision. Fincham's test shows intact halos that are diminished in intensity.

Option C - Halos due to conjunctivitis is because of the associated mucopurulent discharge over the cornea. These halos can be eliminated by irrigating the eye and removing the discharge.

Option D - Fuchs' dystrophy is the most common endothelial corneal dystrophy, more common in elderly females. This condition is caused by endothelial changes and the formation of hyaline excrescences on Descemet's membrane (cornea gutta). Patients present with morning halos that later disappear. A slit-lamp examination shows hexagonal endothelial cells and central guttate spots.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with dizziness and palpitations since 3 days. On examination, she has an irregularly irregular pulse, with ECG findings as shown below. If she were to undergo surgical ablation to treat this condition, which part of the myocardium should be targeted?

choices.text: Across the bicuspid annulus, from the left atrium to  free wall of the ventricle
From the AV node towards the tricuspid annulus
Left atrial regions around the pulmonary veins

questions.solution:
The given history and the ECG findings of an irregularly irregular rhythm, absent p waves, and narrow QRS complexes are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. If she were to undergo surgical ablation to treat this condition, the left atrial regions around the pulmonary veins should be targeted.

The triggering foci for atrial fibrillation most commonly originate from the left atrial tissue, near the openings of the pulmonary veins. When medical management is unsuccessful or if quicker results are desired, cardiac ablation can be carried out. Targeting this region will produce the best results.

Atrial fibrillation refers to an irregular atrial activation, with the absence of atrial contraction. Ventricular contraction is irregular, depending on the atrioventricular nodal conduction rate. Atrial fibrillation is the most common cardiac arrhythmia, and most patients are above the age of 60 years. Patients present with palpitations, dizziness, syncopal episodes, etc. On examination, they are found to have irregularly irregular pulses and, in severe cases, even cardiovascular collapse and heart failure.

ECG shows an increased rate and irregular rhythm with the absence of p waves. The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to determine a patient's risk of developing stroke, and if the score is >2, the patient is recommended to start oral anticoagulation therapy. Beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers are most commonly used to treat atrial fibrillation, and they help to control the ventricular rate and improve symptoms. 

Obesity, hypertension, alcohol abuse, and sleep apnea are known risk factors and should be controlled in order to reduce the incidence of these episodes.

Other options:

Option A: In Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, the most common accessory pathway is found across the bicuspid annulus, from the left atrium to the free wall of the left ventricle; the other common accessory pathways are the posteroseptal and anteroseptal accessory pathways.

Option B: AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia circuits are most commonly found along the path from the AV node to the tricuspid valve annulus.

Option C: Atrial flutter most commonly originates around the cavotricuspid isthmus, and ablation of this area can resolve the condition in most cases.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about wet gangrene, except _____.

choices.text: The affected part appears shriveled and mummified.
It requires a higher level of amputation.
Sudden loss of blood supply occurs.

questions.solution:
The false statement about wet gangrene is that the affected part appears shriveled and mummified.

Gangrene refers to the tissue death, which results in the black discoloration of the affected part because of the breakdown of hemoglobin and the formation of iron sulfide. It usually affects the most distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis, embolus, or arteritis).

Wet gangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Crepitus may be felt on palpation as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms, commonly in diabetic foot problems, and should be considered a surgical emergency, with urgent need for tissue debridement or amputation.

Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by the gradual slowing of the blood supply to the part. It is typically the result of atheromatous occlusion of arteries.

Dry gangrene

Wet gangrene 

Clear line of demarcation is seen.

Line of demarcation is vague.

Affected part is dry, shriveled, mummified

Affected part is edematous, putrified, discolored (due to H2S production)

Slow, gradual loss of blood supply

Sudden loss of blood supply

Separation is by aseptic ulceration

Septic ulceration causes separation

Is confined within the demarcation

Can extend proximally rapidly

Causes are atherosclerosis,

thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO)

Causes are emboli, trauma 

Limited amputation is sufficient.

Major higher amputation is often needed.

questions.text: From a crime scene, you recover a fingerprint that is of a loop pattern. Which of the following patterns most likely represents the same?
questions.solution:
Image A shows the Loop type of fingerprint. It is the most common type of fingerprint. 

A - Looped Pattern - 60–70%

B - Whorl - 29%

C - Arched - 3%

D - Tented Arch - 3%

Fingerprint first develops in 12–16 weeks of intrauterine life and is complete by 24 weeks. They are the impressions of patterns produced by the papillary or epidermal ridges present on the fingertips. The arrangement and distribution of the ridges not only remain unchanged throughout life but are unique for each individual. The study of this ridge pattern in the skin is called dermatoglyphics or dactylography and helps in the identification of an individual.

Edgeoscopy is the study of edges of friction ridges, which normally show seven characteristic features. Ridgeology is the study of friction ridges, which are composed of the edges of ridge units that vary in size, shape, and alignment.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the hospital with the following lesions on the body. The lesion started 2 days ago and has increased in number. Similar lesions are also present on the lower limbs. Examination of the oral cavity shows similar lesions. Which of the following infections most commonly presents with this skin condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows target lesions, which are seen in erythema multiforme. Herpes simplex commonly presents with this skin condition.

Erythema multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis, which results from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity, most commonly to infection or drugs.

Common triggers of erythema multiforme include: 

  • Herpes simplex infection.
  • Mycoplasma infection.
  • Bacterial infections.
  • Fungal infections.
  • Vaccinations.
  • Malignancy: Carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia.
  • Drug reactions: Sulfonamides, cotrimoxazole, penicillins.
  • Miscellaneous: Lupus erythematosus (Rowell syndrome), sarcoidosis, polyarteritis nodosa.

It presents clinically with macular, popular, or urticarial lesions, along with the classic acral iris or target lesions. The lesions are distributed on the distal extremities, palms or trunk, and oral and genital mucous membranes.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

  • Central area of dusky erythema or purpura.
  • Middle paler zone of edema.
  • Outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Atypical lesions will have only 2 zones. They fade in 1–2 weeks, leaving dusky discoloration.

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

 

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell syndrome)
% Body Surface-area

<10%

 <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality

 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of abnormal gait. On examination, the child had a waddling gait and exaggerated lumbar lordosis. The mother gives a history of breech delivery and remembers that the pediatrician diagnosed a hip condition at that time, but it was ignored by the family. What should be the management at this stage?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of developmental or congenital dysplasia of the hip (DDH). In a child of age 18-36 months (2 years old), open reduction with osteotomy is done.

This osteotomy can be either femoral or pelvic or both. 

Pelvic osteotomies are of varieties as follows:

  • Salter's
  • Pemberton
  • Chiari
  • Steel
  • Shelf operations

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth.

Risk factors for DDH include:

  • Sex of the baby- females are more susceptible to DDH due to the action of maternal relaxin on the fetal joints in-utero predisposing it to dislocation. It is 3-5 times more common in females.
  • Intrauterine positioning- breech position is associated with a higher incidence of DDH
  • Genetic predisposition- DDH is more common in children of parents who had DDH themselves.
  • First born child.

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check instability of the hip:

  • Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.
  • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk".
  • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

2) At 3-6 months of age:

  • Galeazzi's test 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

  • Trendelenburg gait
  • Positive Trendelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of DDH

AGE OF THE PATIENT                 MANAGEMENT
Less than 6 months Closed reduction with Pavlik harness or von Rosen splint
6-18 months Closed or open reduction followed by hip spica after reduction
18-36 months Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy (Salter's osteotomy, Pemberton osteotomy, Steel osteotomy)
3-8 year Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy 
8-18 year

Open procedure with femoral shortening with pelvic osteotomy or total hip replacement

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with a skin rash for 3 days. He gives a history of antiepileptic drug use for 2 months and is ataxic on examination. He is diagnosed to have Stevens-Johnson syndrome. Which of the following drugs are implicated in these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Lamotrigine is known to cause such adverse effects in patients.

Adverse effects of lamotrigine:

  • Skin rash
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • Dizziness
  • Diplopia
  • Sedation
  • Ataxia
  • Headache

questions.text: A chronic diabetic patient was brought to the ER following a sudden collapse; ECG was done, and the findings are shown below. After the patient recovered with the initial treatment, the resident taking the history noted that the patient did not have any complaints of chest pain prior to this episode. What could be the possible reason for this?
questions.solution:
Silent/ painless myocardial infarction (MI) (from the given ECG, lateral wall MI) in a diabetic patient is due to autonomic neuropathy.

ST-elevation is present in the high lateral leads (I and aVL) and in V5 and V6. Reciprocal ST depression is seen in the inferior leads (III and aVF), with associated ST depression in V1, V2, and V3 (which could represent posterior wall MI).

Autonomic neuropathy is a common complication of diabetes and results in the following features:

  • Postural hypotension
  • Silent myocardial infarction
  • Hypoglycemia unawareness
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Overflow incontinence
  • Gastroparesis
  • Enteropathy with constipation or diarrhea

Other options:

The most common form of diabetic neuropathy is distal symmetric polyneuropathy. It presents with distal sensory loss and pain in a stocking-and-glove distribution and is a risk factor for foot ulceration.

Mononeuropathy of peripheral (median, ulnar, radial) and cranial (oculomotor) nerves, as well as mononeuritis multiplex, is also seen in diabetic patients.

Diabetic polyradiculopathy is characterized by severe pain along the distribution of one or more nerve roots.

questions.text: A middle-aged man noticed that his shoes no longer fit him, his finger ring is getting tighter, and his jaw seems protruded. The image below compares the size of his hand (right side) with that of the physician (left side). MRI of the brain shows a mass in the pituitary gland. Which of the following is not useful in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image are suggestive of acromegaly which can be managed by stereotactic ablation, pegvisomant and transsphenoidal tumor resection.

It is commonly caused due to growth hormone-secreting somatotroph adenoma. Increased secretion of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor- 1 (IGF-1) results in acral bone overgrowth. Patients present with frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and widened space between the lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, increased shoe size, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Other manifestations seen in GH excess are cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes mellitus, etc.

Serum IGF-1 levels and GH suppression test with oral glucose are useful in the diagnosis. The levels of GH do not reduce in response to the oral glucose load. 

GH-secreting adenomas are managed with surgery. Transsphenoidal surgical treatment is the preferred surgery. Stereotactic ablation of GH-secreting adenomas by gamma-knife radiotherapy has also been beneficial. Preoperatively, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used to shrink the size of the tumor. Another drug that is useful in acromegaly is pegvisomant. It is a growth hormone receptor antagonist and, therefore, antagonizes the actions of GH.

Other options:

Option C: Oglcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist. It is used for the treatment of migraine.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

The various types of pituitary tumors are listed in decreasing order of frequency:

Adenoma cell origin

Hormone

Clinical features

Lactotroph

Prolactin

Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (in females)

Sexual dysfunction, infertility

Gonadotroph

 FSH, LH subunits

Hypogonadism, mass effects, and hypopituitarism

Somatotroph 

GH

Gigantism (children)

Acromegaly (adults)

Corticotroph

 ACTH

Cushing's disease

Nelson's syndrome

Mammosomatotroph

Prolactin, GH

Hypogonadism, galactorrhea, acromegaly

Thyrotroph 

TSH

Hyperthyroidism

 

GH: Growth hormone

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

TSH: Thyroid-stimulating hormone

FSH: Follicle-stimulating hormone

LH: Luteinizing hormone

questions.text: A neurosurgeon uses the following forceps to hold the fascia and galea aponeurotica during craniotomy. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Allis' tissue forceps. It is used to hold skin flaps, fascias, fibrous tissue, aponeurosis, galea, and bladder wall. Delicate structures like bowel or vessel walls are avoided due to the risk of tearing. So, Allis' forceps can be used to hold the fascia and galea aponeurotica during craniotomy, to hold skin flaps and bladder wall, and to hold the vaginal wall during hysterectomy.

 Identifying points:

  • The distal blades are not opposing each other.
  • The tip has teeth in each blade that are opposing.
  • The proximal part has a ratchet/lock.  

Other important forceps used in surgery: 

i) Lane’s tissue-holding forceps

  • Stout and thick distal blades, with an oval fenestra in each blade
  • Opposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in the proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes

ii) Babcock’s forceps:

  • The distal part of the distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in the proximal part
  • Used to hold any part of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, cord, etc.

iii) Kocher’s hemostatic forceps:

Opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

Uses:

  • Hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles
  • Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, and hold resected bowel. 

iv) Lister’s sinus forceps 

  • Used for blunt dissection.
  • During Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.
  • Used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

v) Sponge-holding forceps: 

  •  Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Removing laminated membrane and the daughter cysts during operation of hydatid cyst.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy
  • Swab an abscess cavity.
  • To hold the cervix during cerclage

vi) Desjardin’s choledocholithotomy forceps: 

  • Used for bile duct stone removal. It may also be used during the removal of kidney, ureteric, or bladder stones.

This is a long and slender instrument. There are finger bows but no catch. The shaft is curved. The blades are small, without serrations, and fenestrated centrally. 

vii)  Cord holding forceps typically used to hold spermatic cords.

viii)  Pile holding forceps used to hold hemorrhoids.

questions.text: A patient presents with cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. These are manifestations of which of the following vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis are manifestations of vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency.

Riboflavin (vitamin B2)

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC.

FAD-dependent enzymes

  • Succinate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Xanthine oxidase
  • Acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesized in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries(the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularization, cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Deficiency State

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

questions.text: During wound healing by secondary intention, what are the changes seen in the collagen fibers of the scar tissue by 2 weeks?

choices.text: Type 3 collagen replaced by type 1 collagen
Type 1 collagen replaced by type 3 collagen
Type 3 collagen replaced by type 4 collagen
Type 4 collagen replaced by type 3 collagen

questions.solution:
By 2 weeks of wound healing by secondary intention, type 3 collagen is replaced by type 1 collagen.

Wound healing occurs in two distinct mechanisms—first intention/primary union and secondary intention/ secondary union.

Primary union is seen in cases where only the epithelial layer is injured. An example of such healing is seen in a clean surgical incision approximated by sutures. It begins with the activation of the coagulation cascade and subsequent clot formation. This clot attracts growth factors, cytokines, and migrating cells.

Within the first 24 hours, the neutrophils migrate to the injury site. Within 24-48 hours, epithelial cells from both edges of the wound begin to migrate and form a thin layer of epidermis over the wound. By day 3, macrophages replace neutrophils, and granulation tissue starts forming. This process of neovascularization reaches its peak on day 5. 

Deposition of collagen and fibroblast proliferation is seen in the second week. By the end of the first month, the scar is formed, which is made of cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells but covered by an essentially normal epidermis.

Wounds heal by secondary intention when the wound is large, involving a more significant loss of cells and tissues. Since the wound is large, the blood clot formed is large. This leads to increased inflammation and increased formation of granulation tissue. The provisional matrix has fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen. In two weeks, it is replaced by type I collagen. This remodeling makes the collagen more organized while increasing strength at the site of injury. By the end of 1 month, the scar tissue, mainly made of acellular connective tissue, is formed, and myofibroblasts in the scar tissue cause wound contraction.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is being evaluated for post-menopausal bleeding. Her family history is significant for ovarian and colonic cancers. The pedigree chart plotted is shown below. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm, and a provisional diagnosis of endometrial hyperplasia is established. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is defective in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a woman with endometrial hyperplasia and an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance of hereditary cancer syndromes (colonic and ovarian) narrows down the diagnosis to Lynch syndrome. It is characterized by defective mismatch repair.

Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers, including endometrial cancer (second most common).

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

This syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, with MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

HNPCC shows familial clustering of cancers at several sites, including the colorectum, endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP)

Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

 

 

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

questions.text: A patient with mitral stenosis presented with worsening dyspnea and fatigue, which are now present at rest. He also complained of a heavy pounding sensation in the chest with recurrent chest pain. You decided to evaluate the patient using echocardiography. When would you advise the patient to undergo a valvotomy?

choices.text: Mitral orifice is <1.5 sq cm with significant regurgitation

questions.solution:
Mitral valvotomy is indicated in symptomatic (NYHA Functional Class II-IV) patients with mitral stenosis (MS) with orifice of <1.5 cm2 in normal-sized adults or <1 cm2/m2 body surface area.

Treatment of mitral stenosis:

  • Administration of warfarin in patients with MS who develop atrial fibrillation.
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Mitral valvotomy: It is done in symptomatic patients whose mitral orifice is less than 1.5 cm2. This can be either percutaneous mitral valvotomy or open surgical valvotomy.
    • Mitral valve replacement: This is done in patients whose mitral valve is severely distorted and associated with significant mitral regurgitation.

Mitral stenosis is a valvular heart disease, most commonly caused by rheumatic fever. Other causes include congenital defects like cor triatriatum and parachute valve, mitral annular calcification with leaflet involvement, infective endocarditis with large vegetations and left atrial myxomas.

Patients present with dyspnea, cough, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and hemoptysis. 

In a normal mitral valve, there is no obstruction to the flow of blood from the left atrium (LA) to the left ventricle. Therefore a small LA pressure is sufficient to empty the blood into the ventricle.

When the MVA is <~2 cm2, blood flows from the LA to the left ventricle, propelled by mildly elevated atrial pressure. Hence, patients are usually asymptomatic and may develop dyspnea only when the heart rate increases, as seen in exertion, excitement, fever, etc.

questions.text: A child with severe acute malnutrition is undergoing nutritional rehabilitation. During follow-up visits, he shows significant improvement in appetite, an adequate gain of weight, and a gradual increase in subcutaneous body fat. Activity of which of the following enzymes is responsible for the restoration of fat storage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The restoration of fat storage in a child undergoing nutritional rehabilitation, as evidenced by adequate weight gain and an increase in subcutaneous body fat, occurs with the help of acetyl CoA carboxylase.

With appropriate supplementation of nutrition, the child's body will gradually enter an anabolic phase. In the well fed state, there is an abundant supply of glucose, which is converted to pyruvate, which in turn is converted to acetyl CoA. Acetyl CoA is diverted into fatty acid synthesis, in which acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme. There is also a high insulin : glucagon ratio in the well fed state. This favors dephosphorylation (activation) of acetyl CoA carboxylase, resulting in increased fatty acid synthesis. The fatty acids thus formed (most commonly palmitoyl CoA) are esterified into triacylglycerols. This process is called lipogenesis. 

Note: The enzymes acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, thiolase, and carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I are involved in fatty acid oxidation and are inactive in the well-fed state. 

Related Pearl: Enzymes active in phosphorylated and dephosphorylated state

Phosphorylated state

(Low insulin)

Dephosphorylated state

(High insulin)
  • Fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase
  • PEP carboxykinase
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Glycogen synthase
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • HMG CoA reductase

questions.text: An epidemiologist has to survey an area for conducting a sterilization program. He is plotting a population pyramid of the area. Identify the false statement regarding population pyramids.

choices.text: They show the distribution of ages across a population
They can be used to compare the male and female populations
Youngest of the population is represented at the bottom
Narrow base and wide middle are typical of developing countries

questions.solution:
Population pyramids of developing countries show a broad base and a tapering top. Hence, option D is false.

Population pyramids of developed countries typically show a narrow base and wide middle.

A population pyramid is a graphical representation of the age and sex of the population; therefore, it is also called an age and sex pyramid.

The youngest of the population is represented at the bottom and the oldest at the top of the pyramid.

Besides showing the distribution of ages across a population, the pyramid is divided across the center to separate the male and female members of the population; therefore, it can be used to compare the difference between the male and female populations of a given area.

It also shows the number of dependents in the population at any given time.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: A primigravida presented with labor pains at 38 weeks of gestation. The baby was in breech presentation and a vaginal breech delivery was planned. Identify the following maneuver performed during the delivery.
questions.solution:
The given maneuver is the modified Prague maneuver done for a chin-to-pubis delivery of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Note: If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau maneuver.

Other options:

Wood's corkscrew maneuver is used to manage shoulder dystocia. It involves the pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­screw fashion to release the impacted anterior shoulder. 

In the Zavanelli maneuver, the fetal head is rotated to the direct occiput anterior position and pushed back into the uterus so that the fetus can be delivered by cesarean section. The cardinal movements of labor are reversed. It is done as a third line of managing shoulder dystocia after failing to deliver the baby vaginally.

Lovset maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A patient presents with an antalgic gait, which had a chronic course. On examination, there was true shortening of his left lower limb.  An X-ray of the hip joint is shown below. What is the stage of the disease here?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of true shortening of the limb along with the X-ray showing mortar and pestle hip are suggestive of tuberculosis (TB) of the hip. It is seen in the stage of arthritis with subluxation.

Clinical features seen in the four stages of TB hip:

  • Stage of synovitis presents with apparent lengthening of the limb due to abduction deformity. 
  • Stage of early arthritis presents with apparent shortening of the limb due to adduction deformity.
  • Stage of advanced arthritis leads to true shortening of the limb because of the destruction of the articular cartilage of the femur and the acetabulum.
  • Stage of arthritis with subluxation leads to true shortening of the limb. The destruction of the acetabulum leads to the dislocation of the femur head. This is also known as wandering acetabulum/ mortar and pestle hip because of the widened acetabulum and diminished size of the femur head.

The TB of the hip finally results in fibrous ankylosis of the hip joint.

Note: The apparent length of the limb is measured from the umbilicus to the medial malleolus and the true length of the limb is measured from the anterior superior iliac spine to the medial malleolus. The apparent length is increased when there is abduction deformity of the limb and decreased when there is adduction deformity of the limb.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease is to undergo kidney transplantation. His son is willing to donate a kidney to him. How will the renal artery of the son's kidney be anastomosed in the recipient?

choices.text: End-to-end anastomosis with internal iliac artery
End-to-side anastomosis with internal iliac artery
End-to-end anastomosis with external iliac artery
End-to-side anastomosis with external iliac artery

questions.solution:
In a live donor kidney transplantation, the donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed with the recipient's internal iliac artery.

In the renal transplant, the renal vessels are anastomosed as follows:

  Living donor Cadaveric donor
Anastomosis End-to-end End-to-side
Recipient artery Internal iliac artery External iliac artery
Recipient vein External iliac vein External iliac vein

The below image shows the different types of anastomosis in kidney transplantation from live and deceased donors.

The usual site for kidney transplantation is the iliac fossa in the retroperitoneal position, making it a heterotopic type of transplantation. The diseased kidney is left in situ.

The optimal cold storage time for the kidney is 18 hours, and the maximum safe cold storage time for the kidney is 36 hours.

Optimal and maximum safe cold storage time for various organs are as follows:

Organs Optimal time (hours) Maximum time (hours)
1) Kidney <18 <36
2) Liver <12 <18
3) Pancreas <10 <18
4) Small intestine <4 <6
5) Heart <3 <6
6) Lungs <3 <8

Note: 

In orthotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed in its normal anatomical site. However, in heterotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed at a site different from its normal anatomical site.

questions.text: A patient with organophosphorus poisoning was given atropine. Which among the following effects of atropine is paired correctly with the receptor blocked to produce it?
questions.solution:
Atropine causes tachycardia due to the blockade of M2 receptors in the heart inhibiting the action of acetylcholine on them.

Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist. Muscarinic antagonists block the effects of acetylcholine by binding to and inhibiting muscarinic receptors on effector cells in the peripheral ganglia and the CNS. Atropine is a competitive antagonist of the muscarinic receptors.

Atropine initially blocks these presynaptic M1 receptors. This increases the amount of ACh released at the SA node and causes bradycardia. Then, the progressive increase in the atropine concentration blocks the postsynaptic M2 receptors on the SA node (decreasing the ACh release) decreasing the parasympathetic tone, thereby causing tachycardia.

Other options:

Option A: Mydriasis is caused due to M3 (mainly) and M2 receptors.

Options C and D: Decreased bronchial secretions and bronchodilatation are due to M2 and M3 receptor blockade.

questions.text: A 27-year-old photographer presented with confusion, delirium, and corrosion near the mouth. He was found with an empty bottle containing hydrocyanic acid. He is tachycardic and hypotensive. Resuscitative measures are unsuccessful, and his body is sent for postmortem analysis. What would be the color of post-mortem hypostasis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of hydrocyanic acid (HCN) poisoning, and the colour of postmortem hypostasis in case of HCN poisoning is brick red. 

HCN is a toxic chemical acid found in bitter almonds, peaches, apples, cherries, etc. It has the smell of bitter almonds. It is usually present in its glycoside form, amygdalin, along with certain co-enzymes like emulsion complex, these co-enzymes hydrolyze amygdalin to release HCN. HCN is a common chemical used in leather tanning, electroplating, metal extractions, and photographic fixing. 

Mechanism of action: It is a protoplasmic poison releasing cyanide ions, which inhibit complex IV of cellular respiratory enzyme systems. It leads to histotoxic anoxia.

Postmortem findings: 

  • External: The smell of bitter almonds, brick red postmortem hypostasis. Rigor mortis appears early, and jaws are firmly closed.
  • Internal: In suspected cyanide poisoning cases, the cranial cavity should be opened first to perceive the bitter almond smell that is marked in brain tissue. Diffuse cerebral oedema such that white and gray matter cannot be differentiated, haemorrhages in the lungs.

Toxicological analysis: Preserve lungs to demonstrate the gas in a nylon bag. The spleen is the best specimen to demonstrate cyanide poisoning.

Laboratory diagnosis includes a classical triad of

  1. Narrow arterio-venous oxygen difference,
  2. Anion-gap metabolic acidosis, and
  3. Elevated lactate concentration.

HCN may be identified by gas chromatography or spectrophotometry.

Lee-Jones Test: This test indicates the presence of cyanide. The test can be positive for salicylates, too.

Treatment: Shift the patient to a room with fresh air and remove his clothes. Establish proper airway, breathing, and circulation. Inhalational amyl nitrate is administered, and 100% oxygen therapy is also given. Wash skin and eyes with large amounts of water to remove any contact poison, if any. A slow infusion of 3% sodium nitrate solution, followed by a slow infusion of 25% sodium thiosulfate solution, is given.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

Cherry red
Cyanides

Bluish-green
Opium  Greyish/black
Asphyxia Dark purple

Septic abortion (Cl. Perfringens infection) Pale bronze

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male patient came with complaints of fever, multiple joint pain, generalized weakness, and pruritus for a few days. His laboratory test results are given below. Which of the following combination of drugs is the most appropriate for the above condition?

HCV RNA: Positive

IgG anti-HCV: Positive
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and blood investigations showing the presence of HCV RNA and IgG anti-HCV are suggestive of chronic hepatitis C. Among the given options, the combination of sofosbuvir and velpatasvir would be the most appropriate for chronic hepatitis C. 

The goal of treatment is to eradicate HCV RNA during the therapy and to document that the virus remains undetectable for at least 12 weeks after completion of therapy. This is known as a sustained virological response at 12 weeks (SVR12). The combination of Sofosbuvir (polymerase inhibitor) and Velpatasvir (NS5A inhibitor) has now been approved as the first-line treatment of hepatitis C genotypes 1-6, irrespective of whether or not the patient has previously received any treatment or has cirrhosis. Any patient with chronic hepatitis C who has detectable HCV RNA in the serum, irrespective of ALT/AST levels, is a candidate for this treatment. 

Sofosbuvir-ribavirin combination is inferior to sofosbuvir-velpatasvir drug combination therapy. Other options are not used in hepatitis C management.

Related Pearl: Direct acting antivirals (DAA) - Drugs against Hepatitis-C virus

The directly acting antivirals used in the treatment of Hepatitis C infection include:

Mechanism of action 

Example

NS5A inhibitors (asvir)
  • Velpatasvir
  • Daclatasvir
  • Ledipasvir
  • Ombitasvir
  • Elbasvir

NS5B nucleos(t)ide polymerase inhibitor (buvir)
  • Sofosbuvir

NS5B non nucleos(t)ide polymerase inhibitor (buvir)
  • Dasabuvir
  • Beclabuvir

NS3/4A inhibitors (previr)
  • Boceprevir
  • Telaprevir
  • Simeprevir
  • Paritaprevir
  • Asunaprevir
  • Grazoprevir

 The following combinations of antiviral drugs can be used:

  • Acute, chronic hepatitis, or compensated cirrhosis:
    • Velpatasvir (NS5A Inhibitor) + Sofosbuvir (NS5B inhibitor) x 12 weeks.
  • Decompensated cirrhosis:
    • Velpatasvir (NS5A Inhibitor) + Sofosbuvir (NS5B inhibitor) + Ribavirin (syntheticnucleotide analogue) x 12 weeks.

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice and vomiting 1 week after birth. She has been refusing to breastfeed. Benedict's test was positive for urine, and her blood glucose level was low. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase is the deficient enzyme.
It can predispose to Escherichia coli  sepsis in neonates.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a newborn presenting with jaundice, vomiting, and refusing to breastfeed, along with reducing sugars in urine and hypoglycemia, is suggestive of impaired galactose metabolism. Breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated in this condition.

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to convert galactose-1-phosphate to uridine diphosphate galactose. This leads to the accumulation of galactose 1-phosphate and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features:

  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the liver causes liver damage & leads to hepatomegaly, vomiting, and convulsions.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes the liver of inorganic phosphate leading to diminished ATP synthesis which affects gluconeogenesis resulting in hypoglycemia.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the nerves causes intellectual disability.
  • Accumulation of galactitol in the lens causes oil-drop cataract.
  • Patients with galactosemia are at an increased risk of developing Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis.

In uridyl transferase deficiency, the epimerase is present in adequate amounts, so that the galactosemic individual can still form UDPGal from glucose. This explains how it is possible for normal growth and development of affected children to occur despite the galactose-free diets.

Urinary reducing sugar (Benedict's test) and mucic acid test are positive. Direct enzyme assay using erythrocytes establishes the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with frequent falls, rigidity, slowness in his movements, and tremors. A lesion affecting the substanstia nigra of the brain was suspected. Which option correctly describes the tremors associated with this condition?

choices.text: Frequency 5 Hz, increased at rest, decreased on movement
Frequency 12 Hz, increased at rest, decreased on movement
Frequency 12 Hz, decreased at rest, increased on movement
Frequency 5 Hz, decreased at rest, increased on movement

questions.solution:
The likely clinical condition is Parkinson's disease (PD) in which the associated tremors increase at rest, decrease on movement, and are of frequency 5Hz.

Parkinson’s disease is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer's disease. The UK Parkinson's Disease Society Brain Bank criteria are used for the diagnosis of PD.

Cardinal motor features in PD:

  • Resting tremors
  • Bradykinesia
  • Rigidity
  • Gait disturbance/postural instability

The frequency of the typical resting tremor seen in Parkinson's is 4–6 Hz. The classic parkinsonian tremor begins as a low-frequency, pill-rolling motion of the fingers, progressing to forearm pronation/supination and elbow flexion/extension.

It is typically asymmetric, occurs at rest, and becomes less prominent with voluntary movement. More than 70% of patients with PD have tremors as the presenting feature.

Mnemonic for clinical features: TRAP - Tremors + Rigidity + Akinesia + Postural instability

  • Other motor features:
    • Micrographia
    • Masked facies (hypomimia)
    • Reduced eye blinking
    • Soft voice (hypophonia)
    • Dysphagia
  • Non-motor features:
    • Anosmia
    • Sensory disturbance (pain)
    • Mood Disorders (depression)
    • Sleep disturbances (rapid eye movement behavior disorder)
    • Autonomic:
      • GI disturbances
      • Genitourinary disturbances
      • Sexual dysfunction
      • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Cognitive impairment

 

Related Pearl: Abnormal movements

questions.text:
How will you calculate the sensitivity of a test from the information given below?
  1. x: Total population under study 
  2. y: Total diseased population out of 'x'
  3. z: Total population testing positive out of 'y'
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of a test from the given information can be calculated by z/y.

The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives i.e. z) out of the total diseased population (y). 

The specificity of a test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total non-diseased population.

The positive predictive value of the test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total positive population.

The negative predictive value of the test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total negative population.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A drug that induces apoptosis in a kidney cell is being studied. Shown below is the mechanism of cell death in this case. Which of the following proteins does not belong to the group marked as "X" in the image given?
questions.solution:
In the given image, "X" represents anti-apoptotic factors. BAK is a pro-apoptotic factor and does not belong to this group.

In order for apoptosis to occur permeabilization of the mitochondrial membrane is necessary. This is facilitated by pro-apoptotic proteins, BAX, and BAK (represented by the group "Y" in the image). This action is inhibited by anti-apoptotic proteins (represented by the group "X" in the image). 

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes (caspases) that degrade the cell nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 

Mechanism of apoptosis: There are two distinct pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway

The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • There are several proteins in the mitochondria that can induce apoptosis. These include cytochrome c and some proteins that neutralize the endogenous inhibitors of apoptosis.
  • The permeability of the mitochondria is controlled by the BCL-2 family of proteins, which act as sensors.
  • These sensors are activated when the cells are deprived of growth factors and other survival signals are exposed to agents that damage the DNA or accumulate a large number of misfolded proteins.
  • These activated sensors, in turn, activate the proapoptotic molecules, like BAX and BAK, which form channels in the mitochondrial membrane, through which cytochrome c and other mitochondrial proteins escape into the cytosol and cause activation of caspase-9, which in turn leads to the activation of the caspase cascade and, eventually, apoptosis of the cell.
  • On the other hand, if all the growth factors and other survival signals are present, then they produce more antiapoptotic members of the BH1-4 family like the BCL2, MCL 1, and BCL-XL. These proteins limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

The death-receptor (extrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • Death receptors are surface molecules that are members of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor family like the TNF 1 and Fas (CD 95).
  • These receptors are expressed on the surface of many cells and can trigger apoptosis. In the cytoplasmic region, these receptors have a death domain.
  • Fas ligand (FasL) is a membrane protein expressed mainly on activated T-lymphocytes. Fas-FasL interactions are required for thymic medullary negative selection. Defective interactions also cause autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. 
  • When these T-cells recognize Fas-expressing targets, Fas molecules are cross-linked by FasL, their cytoplasmic death domains form a binding site for an adaptor protein called Fas-associated death domain (FADD).
  • These, in turn, recruit and activate caspase-8 and -10.
  • In many cell types, caspase-8 and -10 may cleave and activate a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family called Bid, thus feeding into the mitochondrial pathway.
  • The combined activation of both pathways delivers a lethal blow to the cell.
  • Cellular proteins, notably, a caspase antagonist called FLIP, block the activation of caspases downstream of the death receptors. Interestingly, some viruses produce homologs of FLIP, and it is suggested that this is a mechanism that viruses use to keep infected cells alive.
  • The death receptor pathway is involved in the elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes and in the killing of target cells by some cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.

The following image shows a diagrammatic representation of the mechanisms of apoptosis: 

Related Pearl: Apoptotic genes

BCL-XL

Prevent leakage of cytochrome-c and
other death lnducing proteins into
cytosol.

between the other two groups

questions.text: A male COVID patient who was on oxygen support was discharged and was prescribed an oral anticoagulant acting at the site marked in the image below. Which of the following is the specific reversal agent for the prescribed oral agent?
questions.solution:
The oral agent acting on thrombin (factor IIa) is dabigatran, and idarucizumab is the specific reversal agent for dabigatran (oral direct thrombin inhibitor).

Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (Fab) that binds to dabigatran with an affinity 350 times higher than that of thrombin. The irreversible idarucizumab-dabigatran complex is then excreted by the kidneys. Idarucizumab is infused as two intravenous boluses, each of 2.5 g.

Other options:

Option A- Andexanet alfa is a specific reversal agent for oral factor Xa inhibitors. It is a recombinant analog of factor Xa which rapidly reverses the anti-factor Xa action and restores thrombin production.

Option B- Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin (IIa) inhibitor. It competitively and reversibly binds the active site of thrombin and prevents the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin. It does not require routine coagulation monitoring. It is mainly used in acute venous thromboembolism after initiating parenteral anticoagulation and in the secondary prevention of venous thromboembolism. It is also considered as the oral anticoagulant of choice in discharged COVID-19 patients. Dabigatran is contraindicated in patients having mechanical heart valves.

Option C- Protamine sulfate given intravenously can be used for the rapid reversal of heparin overdose. It binds tightly to heparin. 1 mg of protamine sulfate neutralizes 100 units of heparin. Protamine binds only long heparin molecules, thereby making it a partial reversal agent for low-molecular-weight heparin.

Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants:

  • Heparin: Protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: Vitamin K
  • Oral Xa inhibitors: Andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: Idarucizumab

questions.text: The lateral view neck x-ray of a 65-year-old male patient showed the presence of a foreign body in the larynx. You suspect that it may represent calcification of one of the laryngeal cartilages. Which of the following cartilages is most likely to undergo calcification mimicking the laryngeal foreign body?
questions.solution:
The cricoid cartilage undergoes calcification, which may mimic a foreign body on x-ray.

Only hyaline cartilage can undergo ossification (calcifications on x-ray). It mostly is seen at the age of 25–65 years. These calcifications may be confused with foreign bodies of the esophagus or larynx on x-rays.

Hyaline laryngeal cartilages:

  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • Most of the arytenoid cartilage

Elastic laryngeal cartilages:

  • Epiglottic cartilage
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage
  • Tip of the arytenoid cartilage

Related Pearl: Cartilages of Larynx
