questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits the hospital with complaints of hip pain and back pain. X-ray shows the following findings. Biopsy from the lesions confirms the diagnosis of metastatic secondaries. Which of the following is a likely source of metastasis?
questions.solution:
The patient's x-ray findings and clinical features are suggestive of osteoblastic secondaries, which are predominantly seen in prostate carcinoma.

Metastatic tumors are the most common form of skeletal malignancy, greatly outnumbering primary bone cancers.

Skeletal metastases are typically multifocal. However, carcinomas of the kidney and thyroid may present with solitary lesions. Most metastases involve the axial skeleton (vertebral column, pelvis, ribs, skull, and sternum). The red marrow in these areas, with its rich capillary network and slow blood flow, facilitates the implantation and growth of the tumor cells.

The radiographic appearance of metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely blastic (bone forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. Furthermore, some cancers are associated with predominantly one pattern or the other.

For example, prostatic adenocarcinoma is predominantly blastic, whereas malignant melanoma and carcinomas of the kidney, lung, and gastrointestinal tract produce lytic lesions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing for 2 months. He mentions that he is taking hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He works at a cement manufacturing factory. Otoscopy findings are normal. Rinne’s test result is positive in both ears. Audiometry results are shown below. What is the likely cause of his hearing loss?
questions.solution:
The pure-tone audiogram shown in the given image shows an acoustic dip at 4000 Hz, which is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss. 

The patient's employment history (working at a cement factory) suggests constant exposure to loud noise. Positive Rinne's test result in both ears suggests that air conduction is better than bone conduction, i.e. absence of conductive hearing loss or presence of sensorineural hearing loss.

Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120–155 dB, such as explosions and gunshots, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells in the organ of Corti. 

The patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in a noisy environment. This condition is irreversible and is managed with hearing aids. 

Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

Other options:

Option A: Medication adverse effects (ototoxicity) cause bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a downsloping audiogram, typically involving frequencies above 8,000 Hz and progresses to lower speech frequencies. Common drugs causing the same include aminoglycoside antibiotics, loop diuretics (not thiazides), antimalarials, cisplatin, and NSAIDs like ibuprofen, salicylates, and indomethacin.

Option B: Otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Pure-tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000 Hz, which is known as Carhart's notch. There is a loss of air conduction in the lower frequencies.

The audiogram given below shows Carhart's notch, which is seen in otosclerosis.

Option D: Presbycusis is a physiological sensorineural hearing loss occurring in individuals above 65 years of age. Audiometry shows a downsloping graph.

World Hearing Day is celebrated on March 3, 2022. Globally, over one billion people are at risk of hearing loss due to loud volumes for long periods. Hearing loss caused by loud sounds is permanent; however, it is also completely preventable. The theme for this year's campaign is "To hear for life, listen with care"

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A new drug that has been discovered is said to have the potential to bring down stress levels. The psychiatry department of your medical college decides to conduct a study comparing the effects of a placebo and the experimental drug in a group of students. The lead investigator conducting the study includes more exam-going students with a higher level of stress in the control group than in the experimental group. What is the type of bias introduced here?
questions.solution:
The type of bias introduced in the given scenario is selection bias. This type of bias occurs when the investigator does not select the subjects of a study or group randomly and when group assignment is done without randomization. 

Hence, the cases and controls in the sample may not be representative of those in the general population. The case group and control group may show systematic differences; in the given example, the control group has a higher number of stressed-out, exam-going students than the case group. 

Other options:

The Hawthorne effect describes a change in the behavior of an individual that results from their awareness of being observed.

Neyman bias or prevalence-incidence bias is due to selective survival in prevalent cases; it is usually seen in fatal diseases.

Interviewer bias is a bias in which the interviewer is aware of the hypothesis and the identity of the cases and, therefore, conducts more thorough interviews for cases than the controls.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl was brought with an enlargement of the breast. On examination, her breasts were at Tanner stage 4 and her pubic hair was at stage 1. Ultrasound examination of the pelvis showed that the uterus was enlarged for age, with ovaries almost at the adult size. Which of the following investigations is least likely to be required in the workup of this case?

LH - Luteinizing hormone

FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone

DHEAS - Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate

TSH - Thyroid-stimulating hormone

choices.text: Serum LH, FSH and estradiol levels

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of precocious puberty. Measurement of serum dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) levels is least likely to be required in the workup for this case, as there are no signs of virilization.

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years. Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 9 years. 

Precocious puberty with the secondary sexual characteristics of the patient's own gender is termed isosexual, while that with secondary sexual characteristics of the opposite gender (such as virilization in girls) is termed contrasexual. Virilization refers to features of hirsutism, clitoromegaly, hoarseness of voice, acne, breast atrophy, and male pattern of body contour and hair loss.

Classification:

  • Complete precocious puberty: Idiopathic, familial, sporadic, genetic, congenital/acquired lesions of the hypothalamic and pituitary glands, specific syndromes (McCune-Albright syndrome)
  • Incomplete precocious puberty: Premature thelarche, adrenarche, menarche
  • Pseudoprecocious puberty (GnRH independent): Ovarian tumors, adrenal hyperplasia/neoplasm, hypothyroidism, hepatoblastoma, iatrogenic-estrogen administration

Investigations in a case of precocious puberty:

  • Radiograph of the wrist for bone age
  • Measurement of serum FSH, LH, and estradiol levels
  • Measurement of serum TSH levels
  • Pelvic sonography
  • MRI of the skull

In girls with signs of virilization, all of the above investigations are done, in addition to measuring the levels of the following:

  • DHEAS
  • Testosterone
  • 17α-Hydroxyprogesterone
  • Androstenedione
  • 11-Deoxycortisol

The leuprolide stimulation test differentiates premature thelarche from true central and peripheral precocious puberty. Treatment includes injection of DMPA, cyproterone acetate, GnRH agonists, and calcium and vitamin D supplements.
